33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.faculty: UTS: Science: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.anti-requisites: 33190 Mathematical Modelling for Science AND 35101 Introduction to Linear Dynamical Systems AND 37131 Introduction to Linear Dynamical Systems AND Spks Between C10154 and C10158
33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.description: This subject develops the knowledge and skills necessary for problem-solving and mathematical modelling at an introductory level. Differential calculus is applied to model situations in science and engineering that involve oscillations. Integral calculus is used to solve selected problems involving first- and second-order differential equations, and to calculate areas, volumes, lengths and other physical quantities. Vectors, matrix multiplication and determinants are introduced and applied to problem-solving and modelling. Sequences and series are reviewed and power series introduced where power series are used to approximate more functions.
33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Describe the relevance of mathematics to engineering and science and the role which engineering and science play in the development and evolution of mathematical ideas and methods 2. Apply mathematical tools and resources to model real world problems, especially in engineering and science 3. Demonstrate correct use of mathematical terminology and concepts, and show understanding of those concepts by describing them in both formal and informal language 4. Achieve a high level of skill in the mathematical techniques covered in the subject content 5. Communicate mathematical knowledge clearly, logically and critically 6. Use appropriate mathematical software to perform calculations and explore mathematical ideas relevant to the subject content, and demonstrate knowledge of the functions of this software by interpreting output.
33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.content: Matrix multiplication and determinants, Vectors and their application to physical problems, Complex numbers, Functions and their relationship to measurement and the interpretation of physical results, Differentiation, Differential equations arising from physical problems, Oscillatory motion, Trigonometric functions and inverse trigonometric functions, Integrals, Inverse functions, Hyperbolic functions, Methods of integration, Solution of differential equations by integration, Review of sequences and series and the use of power series to find an expression for a function. An introduction to Python and its use in mathematical modelling will be given if time permits.

assessment_1.name: Final examination
assessment_1.length: Two hours and ten minutes reading time
assessment_1.criteria: Correct use of terminology, Correct choice and use of problem-solving strategies and procedures, Accurate mathematical reasoning, Correctly describe the relevance of mathematical modelling to engineering practice, Accurately describe the role of engineering and science in the development and evolution of mathematical ideas and methods.

assessment_2.name: Threshold Tests
assessment_2.criteria: Correct use of terminology, Correct choice and use of problem-solving strategies and procedures, Accurate mathematical reasoning.

33130 Mathematical Modelling 1.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject students need: 1. At least 80% must be achieved in one attempt of Threshold Test 1 2. At least 70% must be achieved in one attempt of each of Threshold Tests 2, 3 and 4 3. If the minimum requirement is not achieved in EACH of Threshold Tests 1, 2, 3 and 4 the student will not be eligible to sit for the final exam and their final exam paper will not be marked 4. At least 40% must be achieved in the final exam 5. An overall mark of 50+%. If an overall mark of 50+% is obtained but minimum requirements in an assessment are not achieved, an X grade fail may be awarded.

48230 Engineering Communication.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
48230 Engineering Communication.description: This subject develops students' professional engineering practice skills within the context of a real-life engineering project, through the Engineers Without Borders (EWB) Challenge. Students work in teams to create an appropriate design solution for a given problem as set out in the EWB Challenge Design Brief. While applying the central role of effective communication and teamwork in engineering practice, students develop an understanding of the social, cultural, economic and environmental responsibilities of a professional engineer. This subject is a starting point for students' ongoing professional development that they undertake throughout their studies and as a professional engineer in their career.
48230 Engineering Communication.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply the basic principles of communication in professional engineering contexts. 2. Find, evaluate, reference and document information sources, and conduct research to support decision making. 3. Apply the engineering design process of problem identification, formulation and solution. 4. Consider social, cultural and environmental responsibilities of professional engineering practice. 5. Collaborate effectively in team processes, including self and peer evaluation.
48230 Engineering Communication.content: Engineering design process, Finding, evaluating and referencing information, Academic integrity, Professional engineering documentation, Effective written, visual and oral communication, Teamwork processes and participation, Reflective thinking and writing.

assessment_1.name: Learning Narratives
assessment_1.intent: Encourage reflection on individual learning goals and professional engineering skills.
assessment_1.length: a) 3-minute audio recording, b) 500-word written reflection and 3-5 min video

assessment_2.name: Individual Background Research Summary
assessment_2.intent: Develop research skills and information literacy relevant to the team project.

assessment_3.name: EWB Challenge Team Proposal
assessment_3.intent: Communicate the team’s design solution in a written proposal document.

assessment_4.name: EWB Challenge Team Report
assessment_4.intent: Document and communicate the team’s design solution to a professional standard.

assessment_5.name: EWB Challenge Team Presentation
assessment_5.intent: Oral presentation summarizing the team’s design solution for the EWB Challenge.

48230 Engineering Communication.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more. Completion of OPELA with attendance of 80% of Language Development Tutorials is required for those with a Basic grade.

68037 Physical Modelling.faculty: UTS: Science: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
68037 Physical Modelling.description: This is a foundation physics subject. It covers the fundamentals of mechanics, thermal physics, electricity, fluids, waves and optics. Students are introduced to the basic techniques of measurement and technical communication. This subject aims to develop an appreciation of the physical principles governing natural processes. It is an essential foundation experience for all engineers. Through this subject, students appreciate that physics is not just a body of knowledge to be learned and understood. Together with mathematics, it provides a framework for understanding and modelling natural phenomena that is carried over into design and analysis in engineering.
68037 Physical Modelling.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Understand the conceptual basis in mechanics, thermal physics, oscillations, waves, electricity, fluids and optics. 2. Solve problems proficiently in selected areas of fundamental physics. 3. Apply mathematical models to describe and understand the natural world. 4. Measure basic physical phenomena, analyse data and verify mathematical models. 5. Demonstrate technical communication, project planning, team and time management skills. 6. Understand the nature of physics as a professional discipline of great importance to engineering innovation.
68037 Physical Modelling.content: Mechanics, thermal physics, oscillations, waves, electricity, fluids, optics, physical measurement and data analysis, project planning and team management.

assessment_1.name: Assignments
assessment_1.criteria: Accuracy and proficiency of problem solving, understanding of concepts.

assessment_2.name: Laboratory Work
assessment_2.criteria: Accuracy and proficiency of problem solving, understanding of concepts, technical written communication, project planning, team management.

assessment_3.name: Final Examination
assessment_3.criteria: Accuracy of problem solving, understanding of concepts.

68037 Physical Modelling.minimum_requirements: An overall accumulated minimum of 50% is required to pass this subject. Students are expected to attend all lectures and practical classes.

48510 Introduction to Electrical and Ele.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48510 Introduction to Electrical and Ele.description: This subject introduces students to the profession of engineering, with a focus on identifying problems in society, proposing solutions, and implementing them. It emphasizes the role of electrical and electronic engineering in the modern world and introduces fundamental concepts such as voltage, current, resistance, power, circuit analysis, and fields. A real-world problem and an electronic artefact provide a framework for both technical and non-technical engineering aspects. The subject has a strong focus on practical, hands-on experiences in the laboratory, where students construct, test, and troubleshoot basic circuits.
48510 Introduction to Electrical and Ele.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply an engineering approach to solve a real-world problem. 2. Recognise fundamental principles of electronic systems and solve simple sub-system design problems. 3. Apply circuit theory to the analysis and design of basic DC and AC electrical circuits. 4. Recognise and correctly apply electric and magnetic field theory to simple applications. 5. Design, construct, test and troubleshoot basic circuits using laboratory test equipment.
48510 Introduction to Electrical and Ele.content: The engineering process, creating new products and systems, circuit laws and analysis techniques, diodes, electrostatic and magnetic field theory, computer-based systems, microcontrollers, digital logic circuits, sensors, and AC circuit theory.
48510 Introduction to Electrical and Ele.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.faculty: UTS: Science: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.requisites: 33130 Mathematical Modelling 1 OR 33190 Mathematical Modelling for Science
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.anti-requisites: 33290 Statistics and Mathematics for Science AND 35101 Introduction to Linear Dynamical Systems AND 35102 Introduction to Analysis and Multivariable Calculus AND 35151 Introduction to Statistics AND 37131 Introduction to Linear Dynamical Systems AND 37132 Introduction to Mathematical Analysis and Modelling AND 37151 Introduction to Data Analysis AND Spks Between C10154 and C10158
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.description: This subject consists of two parts: multivariate calculus and an introduction to statistics. The mathematical part develops the mathematical skills required for mathematical modelling of systems involving more than one independent variable. The statistics part is an introduction to descriptive statistics, statistical inference and simple linear regression. Topics include linear algebra, solutions to sets of equations resulting from particular problems, eigenvectors and eigenvalues, partial derivatives, optimisation, multiple integrals and their applications, and probability with a focus on the determination of the reliability of a system of components in various engineering contexts.
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Model real-world problems in engineering practice using mathematical and statistical tools and resources. 2. Use formal mathematical and statistical terminology and informal language to express concepts. 3. Demonstrate a high level of skill in the mathematical and statistical techniques by formulating and solving problems in engineering and science. 4. Demonstrate understanding of the theoretical results that justify the use of these techniques. 5. Communicate mathematical and statistical knowledge clearly, logically and critically. 6. Use appropriate mathematical and statistical software packages. 7. Apply the subject matter to previously unseen problems, especially in engineering and science.
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.content: Topics include linear algebra, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, 3D geometry, partial derivatives, optimisation, multiple integrals, probability with applications to engineering, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, statistical inference, and linear regression. Software includes Minitab for the statistics component.
33230 Mathematical Modelling 2.minimum_requirements: Students must obtain at least 80% of the available marks in at least one attempt of each of the four mastery tests to pass the subject. Failure to meet this requirement disqualifies students from sitting the final exam.

48023 Programming Fundamentals.anti-requisites: 31267 Programming Fundamentals AND 31465 Object-oriented Programming AND 31488 Programming Foundations AND 31508 Programming Fundamentals AND 37171 Introduction to Programming for Mathematics AND 41039 Programming 1
48023 Programming Fundamentals.description: This subject provides basic skills in Java programming and software design, with no assumed knowledge of programming. It covers the topics of object-oriented (OO) programming concepts, data flow, control flow, arrays, and the basics of sorting and searching algorithms. The subject teaches and illustrates a design process using a set of design notations and design rules, and shows how to develop a correct, readable and reusable solution from a problem specification.
48023 Programming Fundamentals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate a working knowledge of the basic constructs in the object-oriented language Java by being able to complete small programs. 2. Use the BlueJ programming environment to build simple software systems. 3. Design and code a software system that correctly implements a solution to a small problem defined by a specification, and follows specific design rules. 4. Comprehend and use basic program control constructs of sequence, selection and iteration. 5. Comprehend and use code that implements arrays and the basic sorting and searching algorithms.
48023 Programming Fundamentals.content: 1. The BlueJ environment. 2. Data Flow: assignment; input, output; numeric expressions, and calculations. 3. OO Programming: class; object; constructor; visibility modifiers; local variables. 4. Control Flow: selection and repetition. 5. Data Structures and Basic Algorithms: arrays; sorting and searching. 6. Design notations, processes, and rules.

assessment_1.name: Pass / fail mastery tests
assessment_1.length: One or more hours each week

assessment_3.name: Additional lab exercises
assessment_3.length: One or more hours each week

48023 Programming Fundamentals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more. Students who complete all the pass/fail tests (Assessment Task 1) are guaranteed a minimum mark/grade for this subject of 50/PASS.

41160 Introduction to Biomedical Enginee.requisites: 33130 Mathematical Modelling 1 AND 68037 Physical Modelling AND 48510c Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering
41160 Introduction to Biomedical Enginee.description: Biomedical engineering is the application of the principles and problem-solving techniques of engineering to biology and medicine. This is evident throughout healthcare, from diagnosis and analysis to treatment and recovery, and has entered the public conscience though the proliferation of implantable medical devices, such as pacemakers and artificial hips, to more futuristic technologies such as stem cell engineering and the 3-D printing of biological organs. This subject covers fundamental mathematical and engineering concepts that underpin various branches of biomedical engineering such as biomechanics, tissue engineering, molecular transport, imaging, bioelectromagnetics, biomedical signals and systems. In addition, this subject also focuses on computational modelling for the design of biomedical devices, processes and systems.
41160 Introduction to Biomedical Enginee.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply fundamental mathematical concepts underpinning biomedical engineering related physiological systems. 2. Model biomedical systems, devices and processes using Matlab to simulate complex systems. 3. Explain mechanical, electrical, chemical properties of cells and their significance in modelling and design of medical devices, processes and systems. 4. Model, measure and process ECG, EEG and EMG signals.
41160 Introduction to Biomedical Enginee.content: Basic biomedical engineering concepts, Mathematical formulation for biomedical engineering problems, Basic concepts of ECG, EEG, EMG, MRI, x-ray, and ultrasound imaging, Introduction to Biomechanics, Fundamental mathematical concepts underpinning biomaterials, tissue engineering and biotechnology, Introductory concepts of bioinformatics, Bioelectrical, magnetic, bioelectromagnetic concepts, Biomedical signals and bio-instrumentation concepts, Dielectric spectroscopy and bioimpedence, Molecular transport and microfluidics, Computational modelling fundamentals.

assessment_1.name: Basic Computational Modelling for Design
assessment_1.criteria: Accuracy of the results, Mathematical basis and assumptions made in the model, Efficiency of Matlab coding, Analysis of results, Report with results.

assessment_2.name: Computational Modelling of Realistic Biomedical Systems and Processes
assessment_2.criteria: Knowledge of mathematical modelling and problem formulation, Development of algorithm and Pseudocode, Accurate analysis using MATLAB, Accuracy of results and presentation of report, Brief literature survey highlighting the biomedical engineering context.

assessment_3.name: Measurement and Analysis of Biomedical Signals

41160 Introduction to Biomedical Enginee.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

91400 Human Anatomy and Physiology.description: In this subject students gain excellent basic knowledge in physiology, putting them in good stead for medical-oriented subjects in subsequent years and potential entrance into the medical and dentistry fields. Students learn the anatomy (structure) and physiology (function) of the healthy human body. Lectures are complemented by a supportive practical/tutorial program. The subject content includes: homeostasis; the anatomical organisation of the body and anatomical terms; and the cardiovascular, musculoskeletal, endocrine, nervous, respiratory, gastrointestinal and urinary systems. Development of practical skills is a major part of the subject.
91400 Human Anatomy and Physiology.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Communicate effectively in ways appropriate to the discipline, audience and purpose. 2. Describe the structure and function of different organs found in the body systems. 3. Explain simply and concisely basic physiological principles. 4. Present data relating to a current and relevant physiological problem or condition, graphically and in a scientifically acceptable form, and to interpret the data in the context of your knowledge and understanding of the material covered in the subject.
91400 Human Anatomy and Physiology.content: ENDOCRINE SYSTEM: overview of major endocrine organs and hormones. CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM: heart and blood vessels, electrical and mechanical events in the cardiac cycle. NERVOUS SYSTEM: structure and function of central and peripheral nervous systems. INTRO TO A&P AND HOMEOSTASIS: medical terminology, body organisation, and homeostasis. SKELETON AND MUSCLES: bone and muscle structure, function, and physiology. RESPIRATORY SYSTEM: anatomy and physiology of the respiratory tract, gas exchange, and control of respiration. GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM: structure and function of digestive organs. EXCRETORY SYSTEM: anatomy and physiology of the kidney and associated organs.

assessment_1.name: Online Quizzes
assessment_1.criteria: You will be assessed on conceptual understanding and comprehension of basic human physiology. MCQ are assessed for correctness and accuracy of disciplinary knowledge. It may also include calculations; use of equations and the application of acquired knowledge to interpret some complex questions.

assessment_2.name: Lab Quizzes
assessment_2.criteria: You will be assessed on: accuracy of data collection, thoroughness, conceptual understanding and comprehension of basic physiology, and synthesis and interpretation of scientific data.

assessment_3.name: Oral Presentation
assessment_3.criteria: 1. Subject content. 2. Organisation and flow of the presentation. 3. Voice: clarity, pace, fluency, volume, and projection. 4. Engaged with the audience. 5. Use of visual aids.

assessment_4.name: Final Exam
assessment_4.criteria: Accuracy of information provided with respect to content covered in lectures and practical classes.

91400 Human Anatomy and Physiology.minimum_requirements: Student must obtain at least 40% of the marks available for the final examination in order to pass this subject. Students must attend all lectures and laboratory sessions, and adhere to the UTS environmental health and safety (EHS) rules, including wearing laboratory coats and closed shoes in lab sessions.

48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals.description: Design and innovation are explored as fundamental engineering activities through a contextualised, authentic project. Students work in groups to develop an engineering prototype. The project promotes learning in areas such as design context, problem framing, creativity, risk analysis, and trade-offs in engineering decision-making. Students also explore product development, risk management, and innovation processes while gaining experience in professional communication and teamwork.
48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Select and apply thinking and problem-solving approaches within the engineering design process. 2. Identify and apply system-wide requirements (risk assessment, safety, business requirements) for engineering design. 3. Apply professional communication skills to document the design process. 4. Plan and monitor group work, manage group dynamics, and evaluate team contributions.
48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals.content: Engineers as designers and innovators. Design and engineering thinking. The design process from problem definition to prototype development. New product development: lifecycles, innovation, and research. Design considerations and trade-offs: risk management, regulations, sustainability, and safety. Team dynamics in concurrent engineering teams. Communication skills for design documentation and presentations.

assessment_7.name: REPORTING: Individual Project Collaboration Statement and Reflection

48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41090 Information and Signals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41090 Information and Signals.description: This subject provides the theoretical foundations of information theory and signal processing that prepare students for both industry- and research-oriented careers. It emphasizes a strong laboratory component to give students hands-on experience in applying theoretical concepts to practical communication and signal/image processing systems. It also encourages collaborative research projects in information and signal theory.
41090 Information and Signals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply fundamental concepts in information theory and signal processing. 2. Use Fourier, Laplace, and Z-transforms to analyze practical signals and systems. 3. Develop abstraction models of practical information and signal processing systems. 4. Apply the basic concepts of data and signal processing to identify specific requirements in designing components. 5. Simulate and test communications, data, and information processing systems. 6. Apply critical thinking to propose creative ideas in signal research.
41090 Information and Signals.content: Topics include: introduction to information theory, source coding and compression, channel capacity, introduction to signal and systems, Fourier series and Fourier transform, frequency analysis, Laplace transform and system analysis, Z-transform, discrete systems.
41090 Information and Signals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31061 Database Principles.description: This subject introduces students to basic database design and implementation concepts, database design techniques, and using a relational design via Entity Relationship Diagram. Students also learn to access a database using SQL to retrieve and manipulate data.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and manage structured data to manage a database.
2. Produce an Entity-Relationship (E-R) model from specifications and perform transformation of the conceptual model into logical data structures.
3. Apply data normalisation principles and understand the impact of data redundancy.
4. Construct SQL statements to retrieve data.
5. Demonstrate use of a simple database using SQL and maintain database integrity rules.
6. Understand principles of database transaction management and recovery.
7. Distinguish between good and bad database design.
8. Communicate database designs effectively.
content_topics: SQL: data modification statements and views
Conceptual database design using E-R modelling

assessments.name: SQL Lab Test 1
assessments.intent: To test SQL skills.

assessments.name: SQL Lab Test 2
assessments.intent: To test SQL skills.

assessments.name: Class Written Exam
assessments.intent: Test basic knowledge and understanding of data integrity.

assessments.name: Distinction Test
assessments.intent: Test advanced entity relationship design skills.

assessments.name: Mini Database Project
assessments.intent: To test all advanced database development skills.

31061 Database Principles.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

91703 Physiological Systems.description: This subject extends the knowledge and understanding of cellular elements of the body introduced in 91400 Human Anatomy and Physiology. It covers cell membrane electrophysiology, cellular transport processes, ion channels, and their role in the cardiovascular system and sensory receptors. It also explores ion channelopathies like cystic fibrosis.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Develop oral presentation skills to communicate effectively in ways appropriate to the discipline, audience, and purpose.
2. Apply the principles of Electrochemical Driving Force and ion channel function to determine how membrane potentials are established and their role in physiological processes.
3. Explain how basic physiological principles allow ion channels to facilitate the formation of neural signals sent to the brain.
4. Perform problem-solving techniques in determining some electrophysiological properties of ion channels.
content_topics: Cellular physiology of the cardiovascular system
How cells in the body communicate
Ion channels and their role in sensory physiology

assessments.name: UTS Online tests
assessments.intent: This assessment evaluates disciplinary knowledge.

assessments.name: Class Quiz
assessments.intent: This assessment evaluates disciplinary knowledge and critical thinking.
criteria: Knowledge, critical thinking, and calculation skills

assessments.name: Oral Communication Skills
assessments.intent: This assessment develops professional and communication skills.
criteria: Oral communication skills based on a rubric of criteria provided to students

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: This assessment evaluates disciplinary knowledge.
criteria: Accuracy of information provided with respect to the content covered by the lecturer.

minimum_requirements.description: Any assessment worth 40% or more requires the student to gain at least 40% of the mark for that task. If 40% is not reached, an X grade fail may be awarded for the subject, irrespective of an overall mark greater than 50. It is compulsory to complete the oral presentation task to pass the subject.

65111 Chemistry 1.faculty: UTS: Science: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
65111 Chemistry 1.description: This subject develops the student's understanding of the basic principles of chemistry, covering topics such as atomic structure, stoichiometry, the periodic table, bonding, intermolecular forces, molecular geometry, equilibrium, and acid-base equilibria. It provides the requisite knowledge for 65212 Chemistry 2.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand and apply key chemistry principles.
2. Qualitatively monitor chemical reactions and explain observations using chemical equations.
3. Apply quantitative skills to solve chemistry problems.
4. Demonstrate basic practical skills, including appropriate use of laboratory equipment and proper laboratory practice.
5. Identify and understand the contribution of chemistry to the greater scientific community and real-world applications.
6. Express chemistry concepts clearly for a range of audiences through written and verbal forms.
content_topics: Atoms, Elements, and the Periodic Table - Atomic structure, ions, ionic compounds, structure and trends of the Periodic Table
Chemical Reactions - Ionic equations, solubility rules, redox, and combustion
Quantitative Chemistry - Moles, stoichiometry, limiting reagents, yield
Bonding - Ionic and covalent bonds, Lewis diagrams, shapes of molecules, VSEPR
Acid, Bases, and Equilibrium - pH, equilibrium constant, Le Chatelier principle, ICE Tables
Intermolecular Forces - Polarity, types of intermolecular forces, effect on physical properties

assessments.name: Laboratory-based Assessment
assessments.intent: This assessment evaluates disciplinary knowledge, professional responsibility, and communication.

assessments.name: Mastering Chemistry Quizzes
assessments.intent: This assessment tests disciplinary knowledge through online quizzes.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: The final exam assesses understanding of key concepts and problem-solving skills.

minimum_requirements.description: Students must achieve at least 40% in both the final exam and practical components to pass. Attendance for at least 80% of practical classes is required.

41162 Fundamentals of Biomedical Enginee.description: This subject introduces students to the field of biomedical engineering, focusing on medical and assistive devices as well as molecular diagnostic devices and genome technologies. Students work on real-life projects to process, analyse, and model physiological signals and genomic data for diagnostics.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate and collaborate in teams to manage biomedical projects.
2. Acquire, process, analyse, and model basic biomedical signals.
3. Use design skills (in software, hardware) to generate solutions in medical and assistive technologies.
4. Apply technical techniques and tools to develop models for RNA sequencing technologies.
5. Apply technical techniques to prototype a diagnostic mini PCR machine.
6. Present project findings to a variety of audiences.
content_topics: Processing and analysis of biomedical signals
Utilization of muscle activities (using electromyogam signals) to control devices
Modelling of tissue-wireless signal interaction and imaging
Molecular diagnostics and the application of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for disease diagnosis

assessments.name: Presentation: Molecular Diagnostics or Biomedical Assistive Devices
assessments.intent: Develop a prototype or solution for a project in Molecular Diagnostics or Biomedical Assistive Devices.

assessments.name: Presentation: Biomedical Signals and Devices or Sequencing Technologies
assessments.intent: Develop and present solutions in Biomedical Signals and Devices or Sequencing Technologies.

assessments.name: Journal
assessments.intent: Document participation and contribution to the selected projects.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41035 Engineering Practice Preparation 1.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41035 Engineering Practice Preparation 1.description: This subject provides students with opportunities to explore the social practices involved in seeking, obtaining, contributing to, and learning from an engineering job or internship. Students develop communication skills for professional attributes and reflect on workplace learning, with a focus on ethical, safety, interpersonal, and communication capabilities required in engineering workplaces.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate professional attributes and job seeking strategies to secure an engineering position.
2. Reflect on professional responsibilities and attributes to communicate value to potential employers, and for lifelong learning.
content_topics: Social practices of job seeking and community of practice
Workplace supervision and contributing to a workplace

assessments.name: Reflection on Peer Review Activity 1
assessments.intent: Develop capacity to give and receive feedback and conduct critical self-review. Feedback on this task will guide success in assessment task 2.

assessments.name: Reflective Learning Journal
assessments.intent: Communicate how the student has fulfilled the subject learning objectives, including a resume, professional biography, and reflective writing.

minimum_requirements.description: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject. By Week 4, all students are required to submit their Resume to Turnitin. If assessed as Not Yet Satisfactory, students must attend a consultation with a UTS Careers Consultant and improve their resume to a satisfactory level.

41036 Engineering Professional Experienc.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41036 Engineering Professional Experienc.description: This subject is a 'placeholder' for students working in industry or the community during their first engineering internship. It is taken concurrently with 41037 Work Integrated Learning 1 and focuses on developing fundamental workplace skills required of a professional engineer.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Learn, through practice, the fundamental workplace skills required of a professional engineer.
2. Complete all requirements for concurrent subject 41037 Work Integrated Learning 1.

assessments.name: Find a job suitable for an internship
assessments.intent: Students must secure an internship before undertaking this subject.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – a suitable engineering job is obtained that meets the criteria.
Timeliness – the job is secured in a timely manner.

assessments.name: Submit your internship start documentation
assessments.intent: To gain timely enrolment in this subject and provide the necessary insurance cover.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – forms are filled out correctly.
Timeliness – forms are submitted within the required time.

assessments.name: Complete co-requisite tasks in 41037 Work Integrated Learning 1
assessments.intent: Maximise learning opportunities from the workplace.
criteria: Completeness and timeliness – all required tasks in 41037 WIL1 are completed on time.

assessments.name: Submit your internship finish documentation
assessments.intent: Provide a trigger for final assessment and completion in the subject.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – forms are filled out correctly.
Timeliness – forms are submitted within the required time.

minimum_requirements.description: To pass this subject, you must work as per your approved Placement Summary Form. When you finish your internship, submit the Evaluation Form and ensure your employer completes the Host Organisation Evaluation Form within two weeks of the internship finish date.

41037 Work Integrated Learning 1.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41037 Work Integrated Learning 1.description: This subject enhances students' experiential learning through their engineering internships. A combination of compulsory and optional modules allows students to broaden their understanding of professional practice. The subject runs concurrently with 41036 Engineering Professional Experience 1.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Conduct critical self-review to identify personal and professional development needs and access resources to meet these needs.
2. Reflect on personal and professional experience within their professional context.
3. Document personal and professional development in an ePortfolio.

assessments.name: Module C1.1-EITHER C1.1b Mentoring OR C1.1a Reviewing Engineering
assessments.intent: To establish a mentoring relationship with an experienced practitioner and to plan objectives for the internship and 41037 WIL1.

assessments.name: Module C1.3 - Developing Competencies
assessments.intent: To record the development of competencies required for professional practice in a personal ePortfolio, which serves as a record of achievement and evidence of meeting UTS:FEIT Graduate Attributes and Engineers Australia competencies.

assessments.name: Elective Module 1 (optional)
assessments.intent: Elective modules are designed to broaden a student's learning from their internship beyond their immediate role and duties and beyond the organisation for whom they worked.
assessments.criteria: Depends on elective module chosen - details are on UTSOnline.

assessments.name: Elective Module 2 (optional)
assessments.intent: Elective modules are designed to broaden a student's learning from their internship beyond their immediate role and duties and beyond the organisation for whom they worked.
assessments.criteria: Depends on elective module chosen - details are on UTSOnline.

assessments.name: Subject Completion Questionnaire
assessments.intent: The questionnaire signals to the subject coordinator that the student has completed all the modules they intend to undertake and wishes for their final mark to be finalised.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48250 Engineering Economics and Finance.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
48250 Engineering Economics and Finance.description: This subject develops students' understanding of finance, economics, and the global financial system. It enhances their ability to cost and manage engineering projects and businesses through economic and financial techniques such as cash flow, valuation, and costing. Students also improve their communication in financial matters by analyzing reports and proposing strategies.
requisites: (48110 Engineering Experience 1 OR 48120 Review of Engineering Practice 1 OR 41036 Engineering Professional Experience 1)
(87 credit points of completed study in specified Bachelor of Engineering programs)
48230 Engineering Communication AND 48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply and analyse economic concepts and principles, such as supply and demand, interest rates, inflation, and business cycles to understand the macroeconomic environment.
2. Apply financial accounting, management accounting, and engineering economic principles to projects or business operations.
3. Communicate with finance and general management professionals using financial and management reporting to achieve deliverables.
content_topics: Economic context: microeconomics and macroeconomics, interest rates, national accounts, international trade
Management Accounting and Costing: cost categories, break-even analysis, budgets, standard costing
Engineering economy: cash flow valuation, interest, time value of money, net present value calculations
Accounting: double-entry accounting, balance sheets, profit and loss statements, cash flow statements, KPIs
Engineering workplace practices: proposals and tendering, professional considerations, ethics

assessments.name: Group Economic Report
assessments.intent: To analyze the macroeconomic environment with a focus on the engineering sectors and international relations between two countries.

assessments.name: Financial Accounting Presentation
assessments.intent: To apply management accounting concepts to a company and develop presentation skills.

assessments.name: Management Accounting Memorandum
assessments.intent: To apply financial accounting principles to a project or business operations.

assessments.name: Weekly quizzes
assessments.intent: To test students' understanding of weekly topics.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48520 Electronics and Circuits.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
requisites: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering
recommended_studies: Basic physics and single-variable calculus
Basic understanding of electrical circuits and their analysis
48520 Electronics and Circuits.description: This subject familiarizes students with basic electronic circuits, primarily using operational amplifiers (op-amps) and their applications. Emphasis is placed on practical, hands-on electronics, providing students with skills in circuit construction, testing, and troubleshooting. The subject also highlights the relevance of practical electronic applications in engineering and technical disciplines, often within wider social and commercial contexts.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Perform DC, AC, and transient analyses of simple passive and active linear circuits.
2. Analyse and design basic electronic circuits with operational amplifiers (op-amps) as active elements.
3. Identify various op-amp circuit topologies and their applications.
4. Build, test, and troubleshoot basic analogue passive circuits and electronic circuits containing op-amps using appropriate laboratory equipment.

assessments.name: WebTutor Exercises
assessments.intent: To evenly distribute learning throughout the session and test students' understanding of basic electronics concepts.

assessments.name: Labs
assessments.intent: To develop proficiency in circuit construction, testing, troubleshooting, and the use of test instruments.

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: To assess the understanding of the operation and ability to analyze basic electronic circuits.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: To assess overall understanding of electronics and circuits.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

recommended_studies: Knowledge of database technologies
31250 Introduction to Data Analytics.description: Data analytics is the art and science of transforming large datasets into meaningful and valuable information. This subject offers foundational knowledge in data analytics, data mining, and knowledge discovery, focusing on practical applications and techniques. Students will explore statistical methods, database management, and intelligent technologies, with a focus on solving real-world problems and communicating results professionally.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the background of data analytics, including the business and society context.
2. Use data analytics to explore and gain a broad understanding of a dataset.
3. Outline the scope and limitations of state-of-the-art data analytics methods.
4. Use data analytics methods to make predictions for a dataset.
5. Organise and implement a data analytics project in a business environment.
6. Communicate the results of a data analytics project.
content_topics: Introduction to data mining: problems, concepts, and methodologies.
Visual data exploration and mining: data visualization techniques.
Data pre-processing and transformation: techniques for data cleaning, dealing with noisy or missing data.
Classification and prediction: decision trees, support vector machines, ensemble methods.
Clustering: partitioning methods, hierarchical methods, density-based methods, k-means.
Deployment of results: representing patterns as rules or functions, model deployment, industry applications.

assessments.name: Dream Jobs
assessments.intent: Understand the application of data analytics in various industries.

assessments.name: Data Exploration and Preparation
assessments.intent: Apply data exploration techniques and prepare data for analytics.

assessments.name: Data Mining in Action
assessments.intent: Apply data mining techniques and communicate the results of a data analytics project.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

91161 Cell Biology and Genetics.description: This subject introduces students to the basic concepts of cell biology and genetics, covering cell structure, biological molecules, genetic code, and inheritance theories. The subject aims to develop students' laboratory, analytical, and communication skills in scientific problem-solving. Students will also learn to utilize modern library resources to evaluate and present scientific concepts in both oral and written formats.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Describe and explain fundamental concepts of biomolecules, cell structure, cell cycle, cellular processes, genetics, and the importance of water to life.
2. Communicate fundamental concepts of Cell Biology and Genetics in oral and written formats to a target audience with basic scientific knowledge.
3. Accurately follow experimental procedures to examine biomolecules in a laboratory setting.
4. Analyse scientific data and come to correct, reasoned conclusions.
5. Present scientific data in graphical, tabular, and written formats.
6. Research a specific scientific topic relevant to Cell Biology and Genetics, including literature searches of published materials.
content_topics: 1. Cell structure and cellular processes (eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells, cell membrane transport, energy and metabolism, cellular communication)
2. Properties of biomolecules (carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids)
3. Basic genetics (genetic code, transcription, translation, cell division, inheritance theories, population genetics)
4. Genetic diseases (inherited diseases, gene expression mutations, genetics of sex and gender identity)

assessments.name: Mastering Biology Quizzes
assessments.intent: Test understanding of cell biology and genetics concepts covered during the course.
assessments.criteria: Ability to answer multiple choice questions based on lecture and practical material.

assessments.name: Practical Reports/Datasheets
assessments.intent: Evaluate laboratory and analytical skills in cell biology and genetics experiments.
assessments.criteria: Ability to follow experimental protocols, answer short questions, perform calculations, draw graphs, and analyse data.

assessments.name: Poster
assessments.intent: Develop communication skills through the preparation and presentation of scientific posters based on published research.
assessments.criteria: Source relevant information, prepare a clear scientific poster, write descriptions, and give a 3-minute oral presentation.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Assess understanding of key concepts in cell biology and genetics.
assessments.criteria: Ability to correctly answer multiple choice questions covering theory and practical aspects.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more, and at least 40% on any assessment worth 40% or more. Attendance at all lectures and laboratory sessions is expected.

41161 Biomedical Industry Frameworks.description: This subject introduces students to the various frameworks, procedures, and regulations common within the biotech/medical device industry. Students learn to identify standard mechanisms related to quality systems, regulatory affairs, design processes, and risk analyses essential for operating within the industry. Students also gain an understanding of regulatory environments both in Australia and overseas, preparing them for roles in biotech businesses.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse the biomedical industry regulations to understand the various aspects of health-related systems and products.
2. Identify standard mechanisms associated with quality systems.
3. Evaluate regulatory affairs, design processes, and risk analysis.
4. Analyse regulatory environments both within Australia and overseas.
5. Present findings to a variety of audiences including stakeholders.
content_topics: Industry Overview – regulated industries, local & international biotech industry, product types, latest innovations, and industry trends.
The Design & Development Process – phases of the process, their purpose, and intent.
Regulatory Affairs & its role in the business – regional bodies, essential principles, requirements for products, gaining approval.
Quality Management Systems (QMS) – standards, device control files, quality systems, customer-facing systems.
Risk Management – definition and importance, standard tools, adverse events.
Ethics – clinical trials, animal testing, gaining customer feedback.

assessments.name: Pitch
assessments.intent: Pitch a new MedTech idea, defining a MedTech market need and customer, and conducting initial market research.

assessments.name: Design for User Case Study
assessments.intent: Provide a specific case study of 'design for user' in medical device technology.

assessments.name: Final Presentation
assessments.intent: Group presentation of the end-to-end process required to deliver a new MedTech device to market.

assessments.name: Final Report
assessments.intent: Provide an overview of the end-to-end process required to deliver a new MedTech device to market.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41038 Engineering Practice Reflection 1.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41038 Engineering Practice Reflection 1.description: This subject helps students reflect on their professional experience from their first internship. Through written and oral reflections, students develop their professional identity, confidence, and resilience, which will shape their future studies. The subject provides opportunities for peer interaction, feedback, and continuous updates to resumes and portfolios.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Reflect on professional experience, and conduct critical self and peer review to plan for professional development.
2. Articulate, in both written and verbal formats, the development of their professional identity to date.
content_topics: Resume and portfolio updates based on recent experiences.

assessments.name: Review of Peers' Draft Reflections
assessments.intent: Give and receive feedback on reflections about internships and refine written reflections.
assessments.length: Approx. 1500 words for the draft reflections, and a paragraph summarizing feedback from peers.

assessments.name: Completed Reflections
assessments.intent: Establish a professional identity, reflecting on internship experiences.
criteria: React to and evaluate the experience, identifying feelings and analyzing difficulties.
Relate the experience to academic/professional literature.
Explain lessons learned (retrospective) and future intentions (prospective).
Language use communicates meaning clearly with a professional degree of accuracy.

assessments.name: Three-Slide Presentation
assessments.intent: Assess students' ability to verbally establish a professional identity and discuss their professional experience.

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48260 Engineering Project Management.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
48260 Engineering Project Management.description: This subject introduces students to modern project management practices and provides the skills necessary to scope, plan, execute, and close engineering projects. Students will learn about project delivery, risk management, resource scheduling, and stakeholder engagement, with a focus on interdisciplinary collaboration relevant to all fields of engineering practice.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Scope a project to satisfy stakeholder needs.
2. Estimate project costs and resources.
3. Develop a Work Breakdown Structure.
4. Identify risks and develop a risk plan.
5. Collaborate as part of a team to deliver an industry-standard project plan.
content_topics: Project delivery: definition, timing, costing, and planning

assessments.name: Group Project
assessments.intent: Organize and work as a team to define, produce, and present outcomes, and monitor the project management process.

assessments.name: Group Presentation
assessments.intent: Assess oral communication skills and ability to present arguments to specialist and non-specialist audiences.

assessments.name: Online Quizzes
assessments.intent: Test understanding of key project management concepts.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41163 Fundamentals of Biomedical Enginee.description: This subject introduces students to the fields of biomaterials, biomechanics, health innovation, and economics. Students work collaboratively to develop and implement real-life solutions to enhance people's health through the development of biomaterials, biomechanics models, and economically viable solutions for the health sector.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate and collaborate in teams to manage a range of biomedical projects.
2. Use design skills (in software, business hardware) to generate solutions in biomaterials, health informatics, and health economics.
3. Apply technical techniques and tools to develop models in biomechanics.
4. Analyse models, systems, and materials to solve problems in health systems.
5. Present findings to a variety of audiences including stakeholders.
content_topics: Design skills related to the problem addressed (software, business, hardware)
Understand the process of synthesising biomaterials

assessments.name: Health Innovation project
assessments.intent: Demonstration of team and individual ability in designing and implementing an innovative health solution, with effective communication.

assessments.name: Biomaterials or Biomechanics project
assessments.intent: Demonstration of team and individual ability in designing and implementing a Biomaterials or Biomechanics solution, with effective communication.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

requisites: 68041 Physical Aspects of Nature OR 68101 Foundations of Physics OR 68037 Physical Modelling
91705 Medical Devices and Diagnostics.description: This subject introduces the science behind devices encountered in medical practice as well as emerging technologies. Topics covered include biomedical implants, devices for in vitro diagnostics, oximeters, medical lasers, electrophysiology, microfluidic devices, DNA/RNA diagnostics, clinical trials, and medical device regulations. It examines the ethical, legal, social, and economic impacts of devices in medical practice.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify the scope and role of medical devices and the medical device industry in our health care system.
2. Explain the processes involved in the national and international regulatory environment for medical devices.
3. Describe the principal components of modern medical devices used in monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment.
4. Apply scientific principles underpinning physiological signal measurement.
5. Apply scientific principles pertaining to implantable technologies.
6. Research and communicate scientific, technical, and regulatory information within the healthcare industry.
7. Analyze ethical, social, cultural, and economic considerations related to medical devices.
content_topics: Regulation of medical devices and diagnostic technologies
Principles of monitoring and diagnostic devices

assessments.name: Mini-review manuscript
assessments.intent: Develop inquiry-oriented research skills and communication skills through writing a professional literature review on a selected medical device topic.

assessments.name: Oral Presentation
assessments.intent: Deliver a comprehensive oral presentation on a selected medical device or diagnostic topic.

assessments.name: Formal Examination
assessments.intent: Test the understanding of key disciplinary knowledge through multiple-choice questions.

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

42026 Biomedical Polymers.description: This subject provides knowledge of biomedical polymers used in cutting-edge technologies such as stem cells and 3D bioprinting for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Students learn about the chemical structure of polymers, their biological function, and their application in tissue engineering and 3D bioprinting for medical purposes.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Acquire knowledge in the latest developments in biomaterials, stem cells, bioprinting, and nanotechnology using biomedical polymers.
2. Identify the differences between natural and synthetic biomedical polymers used for in vitro and in vivo applications.
3. Apply and develop engineering skills to use biomedical polymers for research and clinical applications.
4. Develop communication skills to work independently and within a team.
content_topics: Polymers - Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
Silk Fibroin as a Natural Polymer for Tissue Engineering
3D Bioprinting of in vitro disease models

assessments.name: Lab notes
assessments.intent: Assess ability to take detailed notes during lab activities in the SuperLab.
criteria: Clarity and detail of lab notes recorded in LabArchives

assessments.name: Group presentation
assessments.intent: Develop ability to present a group project on engineering and testing new tissues using biomedical polymers and 3D bioprinters.

assessments.name: Project report
assessments.intent: Assess critical thinking and ability to appraise research findings and create solutions for biomedical polymer applications.
criteria: Practicality and functionality of the proposed solution

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

requisites: 41163 Fundamentals of Biomedical Engineering Studio B
recommended_studies: 48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Engineering
41165 Biomaterials and Biomechanics Stud.description: This subject introduces students to orthopaedic biomechanics and various musculoskeletal joint disorders. It covers computational modelling tools to investigate biomechanics and treatment approaches, including finite element modelling in healthy, pathological, and clinically treated musculoskeletal joints.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate and collaborate in teams to manage biomedical projects.
2. Develop a clinical and biomechanical understanding of a musculoskeletal disorder.
3. Analyse mathematical and finite element models of a musculoskeletal joint.
4. Write a scientific report and present findings to a non-specialist audience.
content_topics: Basics of finite element modelling in Strand7
Comparing theoretical and numerical solutions (beam example)
Radiology and other diagnostic techniques in orthopaedics
Towards building patient-specific finite element models

assessments.name: Project plan (Report and Presentation)
assessments.intent: Demonstration of team’s and individual’s ability on the clinical understanding of chosen musculoskeletal disorder, treatment efficacy, and development of a feasible plan for mathematical and computational modelling.
criteria: Report and Presentation carry 25% of the final mark
Clinical understanding, feasibility of the modelling plan, and communication effectiveness

assessments.name: Final Project Report (and Presentation)
assessments.intent: Demonstration of the team’s and individual’s ability to develop a realistic mathematical and computational model of a musculoskeletal disorder and communicate findings.
criteria: Quality of scientific report and presentation

assessments.name: Final Strand7 Model and Solution files
assessments.intent: Demonstration of team’s and individual’s ability to develop realistic and functional finite element models of musculoskeletal joints.
criteria: Accuracy and functionality of finite element models

minimum_requirements.description: To pass this subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of >=50%.

requisites: 120 credit points of completed study in specified engineering courses
49261 Biomedical Instrumentation.description: This subject focuses on the principles and design of medical instruments commonly used in hospitals. It emphasizes hands-on learning and professional practice, exploring the physiological and electrophysiological aspects of cardiovascular disease, biopotential measurement, critical-care analytes, and therapeutic biomedical devices. The subject also encourages good design practices.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explore the development status and trend of classical and modern biomedical instruments.
2. Master the working principle and main components of common biomedical instruments.
3. Apply general design steps for the development of typical biomedical instruments.
4. Develop medical instruments using engineering knowledge by working in laboratories in a team.
content_topics: Physiological background of the human nervous and circulatory systems
Design objectives for electrophysiological instrumentation (e.g., EMG, EEG, ECG)
General biomedical instruments for monitoring and assessment
Advanced applications: hands-free control systems, power wheelchairs, left ventricle assist devices

assessments.name: Historical Perspective of Biomedical Instrumentation
assessments.intent: Literature review of a particular biomedical instrumentation.

assessments.name: Development of a Biomedical System
assessments.intent: Design and implement a simple biomedical amplifier (ECG or EEG).

assessments.name: Major Group Project
assessments.intent: Develop and implement a biomedical instrumentation or control system.
criteria: Introduction: Aims, literature survey, project specifications (10/100)
Methods: modules, methodology, analysis, novel ideas (40/100)
Results: Design modules tested, results against specifications, optimization, hardware/software quality (40/100)

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

requisites: 41162 Fundamentals of Biomedical Engineering Studio A
recommended_studies: 42906 Biomedical Signal Processing
49275 Neural Networks and Fuzzy Logic
48560 Introductory Control
48570 Data Acquisition and Distribution
41164 Biomedical and Assistive Devices S.description: This studio focuses on the development of biomedical instrumentation, electromagnetic therapeutic devices, and assistive devices. Students work on projects related to diagnostic and therapeutic devices aimed at improving the quality of life, particularly for the elderly and disabled. It covers the use of signal processing, data acquisition, and bio-mechatronics, with project demonstrations using MATLAB, ANSYS HFSS, and Labview.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate and collaborate in teams to manage biomedical projects.
2. Research and evaluate current biomedical devices literature to understand the research frontier.
3. Apply general design rules for the development of biomedical instruments and assistive devices.
4. Acquire, process, analyse and model/control biomedical signals.
5. Use design skills (in software and hardware) to generate solutions in medical and assistive technologies.
6. Develop skills in using algorithms for signal processing and classification.
7. Present findings to a variety of audiences including stakeholders.
content_topics: Design steps of biomedical instrumentation and assistive devices
Electromagnetic wave interaction with the human body and thermal therapy device modelling
Processing and analysis of biomedical signals
System modelling and controller design for rehabilitation and assistive devices
Utilization of muscle activities (electromyogram signals) to control devices
Design and analysis of standalone biomedical devices

assessments.name: Project stage 1
assessments.intent: Demonstrate the ability to source materials, conduct literature reviews, and produce functional specifications for project implementation.

assessments.name: Project stage 2 (Report and Presentation)
assessments.intent: Demonstrate team and individual ability to progress project design and early functional implementation.

assessments.name: Project stage 3: Delivery of functional working project (Report and Presentation)
assessments.intent: Demonstrate the ability to design and implement standalone elements of biomedical instrumentation or therapeutic/assistive devices, analyze real-time system performance, and communicate effectively.

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

requisites: (31005 Machine Learning OR 41160 Introduction to Biomedical Engineering) AND 120 credit points of completed study in specific engineering or engineering-related courses.
recommended_studies: Knowledge of cell biology
Basic programming skills
42001 Bioinformatics.description: Bioinformatics is the interdisciplinary science of turning large biological datasets into meaningful and actionable information. It requires knowledge in biology, engineering, and computer science, including understanding biological contexts, biotechnologies, computer science methods, statistical approaches, and visualization techniques. The subject introduces the acquisition, analysis, and interpretation of experimental genomic data and prepares students to initiate, conduct, and communicate bioinformatics projects to domain experts such as biologists, engineers, and medical professionals.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand and explain the biological context and the biotechnologies applied in modern genomics projects.
2. Understand common data formats and efficiently store, process, analyze, interpret, and critically evaluate genomic data.
3. Organize, implement, and communicate real-world bioinformatics projects to domain experts.
content_topics: Introduction to the human genome: organization, regulation, expression
Biotechnologies for genome measurement: DNA-seq, ChIP-seq, RNA-seq
Efficient organization and processing of genomic data: Unix
Introduction to sequence alignments and computational considerations
Processing, analysis, and visualization of genomic data: DNA-seq, RNA-seq, ChIP-seq
Interpretation of genomic data: DNA sequence variation, RNA expression variation, DNA and chromatin binding variation

assessments.name: Biological and Technological Context
assessments.intent: Students research and present a genomics topic, highlighting its relation to health, biotechnology, and bioinformatics.

assessments.name: Genomic Data Exploration and Preparation
assessments.intent: Students develop and present a genomics data analysis pipeline, processing real-world data with a critical evaluation of the pipeline and results interpretation in a biological/medical context.

assessments.name: Integrative Genomics in Action
assessments.intent: Students develop additional genomics data analysis pipelines, process multiple datasets, and integrate these diverse datasets for biological system analysis and medical interpretation.

course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - Identify, engage, interpret and analyze stakeholders' needs, applying expert judgment to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - Apply problem-solving and decision-making methodologies to explore and synthesize complex ideas.
D.1: Technically Proficient - Apply theoretical and conceptual knowledge to research and evaluate systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - Work as an effective team member, communicate efficiently within cross-disciplinary contexts.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Workshop/laboratory activities combined with research and development assignments.
Preparation using materials on UTSOnline for face-to-face classes.
Hands-on experience in biological data processing, analysis, and interpretation.
Guest lectures on real-world bioinformatics applications.

minimum_requirements.description: Students must achieve an overall pass in the subject to meet the completion requirements.

requisites: 41162 Fundamentals of Biomedical Engineering Studio A
recommended_studies: 91161 Cell Biology and Genetics
42001 Bioinformatics
41166 Healthomics and Molecular Diagnost.description: This subject familiarizes students with advanced molecular diagnostics and their role in biology, the health industry, and society. It focuses on designing and building PCR machines aimed at solving real-life health problems. The subject uses a collaborative studio mode, emphasizing design thinking, concept development, and communication skills tailored to the molecular diagnostics industry.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate and collaborate in teams to manage biomedical projects.
2. Use design skills to generate solutions in medical technologies.
3. Apply techniques and tools to develop models in molecular diagnosis and healthomics.
4. Research and understand the engineering aspects of state-of-the-art biomedical diagnostic tools like PCR machines and various DNA/RNA sequencing approaches.
5. Present findings to a variety of audiences including stakeholders and industry representatives.
content_topics: Analyzing biological data and gene expressions

assessments.name: Pitch #1
assessments.intent: Develop research and presentation skills to articulate problem background and initial project understanding.

assessments.name: Pitch #2
assessments.intent: Ensure students are meeting milestones and project deliverables.

assessments.name: Final Seminar
assessments.intent: Showcase engineering background knowledge and present progress on diagnostic technologies (PCR machine), with a focus on communication skills.

assessments.name: Final Report
assessments.intent: Summarize the engineering background and issues related to diagnostic technologies (PCR machine) and articulate the final design in a written report.

minimum_requirements.description: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

26101 Health Economics and Evaluation.description: This subject provides students with an understanding of the economics of health and health care, and enables them to apply analytical economics skills to resource allocation problems in health systems. Students learn principles, techniques, and real-world applications of health technology assessment (HTA), clinical evidence synthesis, patient outcomes, and economic modelling.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the key concepts of microeconomics applied to health and health care.
2. Discuss characteristics of the Australian health care system, including its advantages and disadvantages.
3. Describe the role and value of health technology assessment in product development, market access, and reimbursement.
4. Apply methods for economic evaluation of health technologies.
content_topics: Microeconomics applied to health and health care
Equity and efficiency in health care provision
Overview of the Australian health care system
The role and value of health technology assessment (HTA)

assessments.name: Written home assignments
assessments.intent: Apply microeconomic concepts to health and healthcare.

assessments.name: HTA Consultancy Project
assessments.intent: Develop a model to perform an economic evaluation of a medical device and use it to inform decision-making.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: Test comprehensive understanding of key concepts and ability to apply economic evaluations in healthcare contexts.

minimum_requirements.description: Students must achieve at least 50% of the total marks to pass the subject.

41167 Health Innovation Studio.description: This studio provides a practice-based learning environment for biomedical engineering students, focusing on reflective design practice, teamwork, and solving complex health challenges. Students apply health economics theory and innovative design methods to create and evaluate solutions for real-world healthcare problems posed by key players in the industry.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Collaborate with peers and other stakeholders in the design process.
2. Apply design thinking to an array of health and healthcare challenges.
3. Apply technical capability in creative and innovative development techniques and tools to address health and healthcare challenges.
4. Present solution background, design, implementation, results and conclusions to a customer.
5. Evaluate the value of an innovative solution using appropriate economic evaluation methods.
content_topics: Analysing a challenge posed by a stakeholder in the healthcare field
Design skills related to the problem addressed (software, business, hardware)
Quantify the value of a healthcare solution

assessments.name: Health Innovation project - Early solution
assessments.intent: Demonstrate the ability to design and implement an innovative health solution and communicate effectively.

assessments.name: Reflective ability assessment
assessments.intent: Reflect on learning and communicate effectively with peers.
assessments.length: 200-word entry per top five moments over 10 weeks, plus additional media as appropriate.

assessments.name: Process assessment
assessments.intent: Learn to make and record process decisions.

assessments.name: Product design and assessment
assessments.intent: Build solutions satisfying customer requirements and assess them.

assessments.name: Pitch of the solution to the customer
assessments.intent: Present innovative solutions to a range of audiences.

48270 Entrepreneurship and Commercialisa.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
48270 Entrepreneurship and Commercialisa.description: This subject develops students' understanding of the various roles within an enterprise, using a business planning framework to cover topics such as strategy, marketing, operations, personnel, and finance. The subject has a strong practical orientation, using case studies of business startups to help students apply the concepts covered and gain insight into the commercial world.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse a market or industry to identify opportunities for innovation.
2. Propose and design a new product or service in relation to current opportunities.
3. Analyse the viability of a new product or service and develop a business plan.
4. Present documentation, and communicate with stakeholders on a new product or service.

assessments.name: Market Analysis
assessments.intent: Understand a particular market and its competition, and identify new opportunities or threats for a start-up or existing business.

assessments.name: Video Pitch and Peer Review
assessments.intent: Explore opportunities in a market and pitch them verbally in a video format, while reviewing peers’ videos and providing feedback.

assessments.name: Business Plan
assessments.intent: Develop a business plan for a start-up business or a new product/service of an existing business.

assessments.name: Pitch and Viva Voce
assessments.intent: Test understanding of concepts covered in the subject and work through the business plan.
assessments.length: 2-minute Pitch plus 5 minutes for oral exam

41045 Engineering Practice Preparation 2.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41045 Engineering Practice Preparation 2.description: This subject helps students develop as professional engineers and prepares them for the second stage of the Engineering Practice Program. Through six workshops, students enhance their understanding of employment processes, ethical decision-making, social responsibility, leadership, and workplace culture. The workshops involve collaborative activities, peer reflection, and communication skill development relevant to professional engineering practice. Reflective practice is embedded to foster ongoing professional growth and lifelong learning.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Articulate preparedness for participating in an engineering workplace as appropriate for a senior internship.
2. Document and communicate capabilities to contribute to a workplace and engage in workplace learning.
content_topics: Leadership and followership in engineering teams
Workplace culture and its impact on engineering practice
Reflection and personal development for professional engineering

assessments.name: Developing Professional Practice
assessments.intent: Engage in pre-class, in-class, and post-class activities, focusing on communication skills, collaboration, and learning insights.

assessments.name: Preparing for the Workplace
assessments.intent: Set learning goals and plan activities for the senior internship based on Engineers Australia Competency Standards.

assessments.name: Engineering Practice in Context
assessments.intent: Analyse a case study to explore leadership, ethics, and social responsibility in engineering practice.

assessments.name: Workplace Cultures for Engineers
