assessments.intent: Reflect on past work placement to understand the importance of workplace culture in engineering.

41046 Engineering Professional Experienc.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41046 Engineering Professional Experienc.description: This subject acts as a placeholder for students while they are working in industry or community roles for their second engineering internship. It prepares students to participate in the workplace and complete all the necessary requirements for the concurrent Work Integrated Learning 2 (41047) subject.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Participate in an engineering workplace.
2. Complete all requirements for the concurrent subject 41047 Work Integrated Learning 2.

assessments.name: Find a job suitable for a senior internship
assessments.intent: Students must secure an internship before undertaking this subject.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – a suitable engineering job is obtained that meets the criteria outlined in the Engineering Practice Program Guide.

assessments.name: Submit your internship start documentation
assessments.intent: To gain timely enrolment in this subject and provide the necessary insurance cover.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – forms are filled out correctly.
Timeliness – forms are submitted within the required time.

assessments.name: Complete co-requisite tasks in 41047 WIL2
assessments.intent: Maximise learning opportunities from the workplace.
criteria: Completeness; timeliness - all required tasks in 41047 WIL2 are completed on time.

assessments.name: Submit your internship finish documentation
assessments.intent: To provide a trigger for final assessment and completion in the subject.
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark
criteria: Completeness – forms are filled out correctly.
Timeliness – forms are submitted within the required time.

41047 Work Integrated Learning 2.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41047 Work Integrated Learning 2.description: This subject is designed to enhance and broaden students' experiential learning concurrently with their internship. While students in an organisation typically engage with a narrow range of tasks, this subject offers various modules to expand their understanding of professional practice in the context of their chosen field.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate personal and professional development within the broader context of their profession and through concurrent internship experience.
2. Document their professional and personal development in an e-portfolio that may be used for seeking employment and/or professional accreditation.
3. Discuss systems and processes for personal and professional development within their professional context.
content_topics: Personal and professional development during internships
Systems and processes for professional development
Creation and curation of an e-portfolio for professional accreditation

assessments.name: Compulsory Module C2.3 - Reflect on Learnings and Development
assessments.intent: Record evidence of professional development and learn from past experiences by analysing episodes. This will serve as a record of achievement and evidence of meeting UTS:FEIT graduate attributes and Engineers Australia Stage 2 competencies.

assessments.name: Elective Module
assessments.intent: This allows students to broaden their learning in specific areas of interest through an elective module of their choice.

41029 Engineering Research Preparation.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41029 Engineering Research Preparation.description: This subject is the preparation and planning phase of the capstone project, focusing on the development of research design, project management, and critical communication skills. It aims to consolidate the application of engineering knowledge and solve complex engineering problems in students' final year. The implementation phase follows in the 41030 Engineering Capstone subject.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Critically analyse engineering problems from both technical and societal perspectives, and relate research interests and/or questions to engineering challenges faced in professional practice.
2. Apply academically rigorous research methodologies in problem-solving, using philosophical concepts underpinning research design and problem formulation.
3. Apply contemporary project management skills and knowledge to plan the management of the Capstone project and communicate with internationally accepted terminologies.
content_topics: Application of research and project management methodologies

assessments.name: Problem Analysis Brief
assessments.intent: To clarify the aims of research and associated risks and stakeholder concerns.

assessments.name: Project Management Plan
assessments.intent: To demonstrate the student's capability of managing and completing the proposed project.

assessments.name: Research Proposal
assessments.intent: To test the student's ability to apply research methodology and control project progress in the following capstone subject 41030. It also strengthens the student's capability to synthesise solutions from different perspectives.

41048 Engineering Practice Reflection 2.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41048 Engineering Practice Reflection 2.description: This subject enables students to reflect on their workplace practice from previous subjects in the Professional Practice Program. It focuses on summarising their experience and learning for use when applying for a graduate engineering role, pursuing chartered status with Engineers Australia, or contributing to professional development in engineering.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate personal commitment to, and capability to fulfill, their obligations to the engineering community.
2. Communicate succinctly their professional capabilities and attributes to potential employers and the wider professional engineering community.

assessments.name: Curated graduate employment e-portfolio
assessments.intent: Students communicate their professional capabilities and attributes to potential employers and the professional engineering community.

assessments.name: Reflection on Peer Review Activity 1
assessments.intent: Students develop the capacity to both give and receive feedback and conduct critical self-review.

assessments.name: Personal commitment to and capability to fulfill obligations to the engineering profession
assessments.intent: Students demonstrate personal commitment to and capability in fulfilling their obligations to the professional engineering community.

minimum_requirements: Present Assessment Task 3 during the week 8 lecture
Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more

41030 Engineering Capstone.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
41030 Engineering Capstone.description: This subject is the second phase of the capstone project and involves the implementation and write-up of the final project. Students complete their project based on the preparation done in 41029 Engineering Research Preparation.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Independently or as part of a team identify and apply relevant problem-solving methodologies.
2. Ensure that all aspects of the project are based on fundamental principles.
3. Critically review and apply relevant standards and codes of practice.
4. Collect knowledge using research to identify and investigate complex problems.
5. Design and conduct appropriate experiments, analyse result data, and formulate conclusions.
6. Identify constraints, uncertainties, and risks of the system.
7. Conceptualize alternative approaches and evaluate potential outcomes.
8. Competently address problems involving uncertainty and ambiguity.

assessments.name: Final Report
assessments.intent: To document a professional engineering project to academic standards and demonstrate competencies expected of a professional engineer.
assessments.length: Length of the final report should reflect the content of the study undertaken.

minimum_requirements: Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more

48310 Introduction to Civil and Environm.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48310 Introduction to Civil and Environm.description: This subject introduces students to Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) by focusing on the processes, terminology, and skills required in the field. Students will learn about the role of CEE in supporting urban and rural infrastructure, including hands-on practice with engineering drawing, CAD software, and GIS mapping.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the fundamentals of Civil and Environmental Engineering processes and terminology.
2. Identify the concepts and ramifications of CEE.
3. Conduct engineering drawing with hand drafting, CAD software, and GIS software.
4. Comprehend the need to work within acceptable standards and expectations.
5. Assess various options for Civil Engineering works in principle.
6. Recognise the balance between theoretical knowledge and practical experience.

assessments.name: Drawing Assignment
assessments.intent: To develop the ability to interpret and create engineering drawings, which are fundamental in the civil engineering profession.

assessments.name: Theoretical Test
assessments.intent: To assess fundamental knowledge of topics covered in the subject related to Civil and Environmental Engineering.

assessments.name: Engineering Drawing with CAD
assessments.intent: To complete a civil engineering drawing project using AutoCAD.

assessments.name: Geographical Information Systems (GIS)
assessments.intent: To complete a map drawing task using ArcGIS software.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: To assess understanding of Civil and Environmental Engineering principles in preparation for real-world application during internships.

minimum_requirements: Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48320 Surveying.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48320 Surveying.description: This subject teaches the fundamental theory and practice of basic surveying skills, including the use of surveying equipment such as levels and theodolites. Students will also learn how to perform calculations, reduce observations, and manage errors associated with these tools, while also gaining an awareness of modern developments in surveying technologies and professional practices.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify and apply the theory and practice of basic surveying skills.
2. Use basic surveying equipment such as levels and theodolites, and perform the calculations and reductions of observations associated with such equipment.
3. Assess the likely errors that may occur during observations, and of methods to eliminate or minimise such errors.
4. Use applications of modern computer programs to reduce data for and the plotting of detail and contour plans.
5. Recognise the role of the professional surveyor, and modern developments in surveying.
content_topics: Levelling: field methods, booking and reduction by Rise and Fall method and the Height of Plane of Collimation method
Bearings and Angles, including the use of the theodolite
Preparation of a detail and contour plan
Design and set out of Horizontal and Vertical curves, Areas and volume estimation
Modern Developments in Surveying Equipment and Techniques

assessments.name: Practical Exercises and Reports
assessments.intent: To assess students' ability to apply surveying skills in practical settings, using equipment and tools covered in the subject.

assessments.name: Pre-class quizzes
assessments.intent: To evaluate students' understanding of key concepts before practical and lecture sessions.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: To assess students' overall understanding of the theory and practice of surveying, including error minimisation and the use of modern surveying techniques.

assessments.name: Practical Exam
assessments.intent: To evaluate students' ability to apply practical surveying skills, focusing on the use of levels, theodolites, and error management.

minimum_requirements: Participate in Assessment Task 4 Practical Exam.
Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

60101 Chemistry and Materials Science.faculty: UTS: Science: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
60101 Chemistry and Materials Science.description: This subject develops a solid science foundation for further materials and engineering-related studies and facilitates the working relationship between engineers, materials scientists, and other scientists. It covers chemical bonding, structure-property relationships, mechanical properties, heat treatment, materials degradation, and more. Laboratory work imparts practical skills and reinforces theoretical concepts.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand and apply the basic principles of materials science and engineering, particularly that microstructure controls properties and processing controls microstructure.
2. Describe the different mechanical and physical behaviors of materials.
3. Evaluate the role of standards in material performance.
4. Understand and use technical terms related to materials science and engineering.
5. Solve simple materials selection problems and critically assess materials selection procedures.
6. Understand and apply various chemistry terms, molar calculations, and chemical equations.
7. Prepare a professional consultancy report evaluating mechanical properties of materials.
content_topics: Overview of materials and their applications.
Chemistry basics, periodic table, pH, balancing chemical equations, acids/bases.
Mechanical properties of materials and related testing methods.
Strengthening mechanisms, metals and alloys, steels, and aluminum alloys.
Heat treatment and applications in steel.
Ceramics, polymers, and composites: structure, properties, and applications.

assessments.name: Quizzes
assessments.intent: To assess students' understanding of disciplinary knowledge and technical proficiency in materials science.
assessments.criteria: Correct choice of answers. Questions will be marked against the marking scheme provided with the quiz.

assessments.name: Laboratory and Tutorials
assessments.intent: To develop research, inquiry, and critical thinking skills, as well as technical proficiency.
assessments.criteria: Correct use of data collected from lab sessions, correct interpretation through calculations and graphing.

assessments.name: Consultancy Report Writing
assessments.intent: To develop communication skills, professional responsibility, and the ability to analyze and report on material performance.
assessments.criteria: Report will be marked against the criteria provided in the tutorial booklet.

minimum_requirements: Students must obtain at least 50% of the marks available for the final examination to pass the subject. If they do not, they will be awarded an X (fail) grade regardless of total marks obtained.
Students are expected to attend all lectures and practical sessions.

48321 Engineering Mechanics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48321 Engineering Mechanics.description: This subject aims to assist students in acquiring a fundamental understanding of static equilibrium concepts, commonly used in the analysis and design of engineered structures. It focuses on the analysis of statically determinate beams and trusses under various loading and support conditions. Students will develop skills in applying static equilibrium conditions and gain an appreciation for civil engineering design.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply the concept of equilibrium to systems which can be modeled as particles in 2D, and to rigid bodies in 2D.
2. Simplify and clarify mechanics problems using free body diagrams.
3. Analyze simple statically determinate structures such as beams, pin-jointed trusses, and pin-jointed frames under various loadings and support conditions.
4. Determine internal actions in statically determinate structures and draw internal action diagrams such as Axial Force (AFD), Shear Force (SFD), and Bending Moment Diagrams (BMD).
5. Determine simple dynamic variables and solve simple dynamic problems involving kinematics, energy, and momentum.
content_topics: SI units and physical dimensions in statics.
Equilibrium of rigid bodies and free-body diagrams (FBD).
Pin-jointed trusses: Method of joints and method of sections.
Analysis of beams: Shear force (SFD) and bending moment diagrams (BMD).
Shear force and bending moment diagrams of simple frames.
Fundamental concepts in dynamics: Kinematics of a particle, conservation of energy and momentum.

assessments.name: Three Assignments (Summative)
assessments.intent: To provide students with practice in problem solving and applying concepts to real or model structures.
assessments.criteria: Ability to apply equilibrium concepts and analyze structures.

assessments.name: Four Topic Quizzes (Formative)
assessments.intent: To allow students to demonstrate their learning and address knowledge gaps collaboratively with peers.
assessments.length: 2-hour process: individual quiz, collaborative quiz, and review session.
assessments.criteria: Demonstration of conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills.

assessments.name: Final Exam (Summative)
assessments.intent: To demonstrate knowledge of mechanics concepts and problem-solving skills at the level needed for subsequent subjects like Mechanics of Solids.
assessments.criteria: Knowledge of mechanics concepts and ability to apply them in solving problems.

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

48221 Engineering Computations.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

recommended_studies: 48321 Engineering Mechanics
48331 Mechanics of Solids

48221 Engineering Computations.description: This subject provides engineering students with essential computing knowledge, numerical techniques, and programming skills for engineering problem solving. It covers numerical methods, Excel spreadsheets, and Visual Basic programming, with a focus on civil and mechanical engineering applications.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain basic numerical techniques and engineering computational techniques in support of professional engineering practice.
2. Independently acquire knowledge and skills in the utilisation of engineering computational tools.
3. Use practical skills to solve engineering problems with various computational tools.
content_topics: 1. General concepts and basic knowledge: Computer hardware, operating systems, software, networking, and the internet.
2. Numerical techniques/methods: Matrix operations, least square method, solving nonlinear equations, numerical differentiation and integration, optimisations, Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT).
3. Spreadsheets and VBA: Basics of Excel spreadsheets, advanced spreadsheets, Visual Basic for Applications (VBA), macros, and user-defined functions.
4. Programming: Programming constructs (variables, types, instructions, branching, looping, subroutines, input/output) and algorithm design, focusing on Visual Basic in Excel.

assessments.name: Activity Gauge - Assessing learning activities
assessments.intent: To assess students' ability to solve mathematical and engineering problems using numerical methods through a variety of learning activities.
assessments.description: Weekly assessments including pre- and post-lecture quizzes, on-class activities, and tutorial performance.

assessments.name: Group Project
assessments.intent: To encourage group learning, management, discussions, and the application of learned knowledge to solve engineering problems as a team.
assessments.description: The project runs through the session with two stages, requiring group reports and assessments at each stage.

assessments.name: Final Examination (Open book)
assessments.intent: To assess students' understanding of spreadsheet and VBA applications in solving numerical and engineering problems.

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

48331 Mechanics of Solids.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

recommended_studies: Revision of 48321 Engineering Mechanics and 48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Engineering before the semester

48331 Mechanics of Solids.description: This subject enables students to acquire a fundamental understanding of the behaviour of structural components commonly used in engineered structures and machines. Students will develop skills to model and analyse components under various loading and support conditions using principles of equilibrium and material relationships.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model and analyse the behaviour of structural and machine components subjected to various loading and support conditions.
2. Understand and apply the concept of stress and strain to analyse and design structural members and machine parts.
3. Solve practical problems by evaluating the relationship between stress and strain.
4. Analyse composite beams and shafts.
5. Determine deflections and deformations of loaded flexural members.
6. Analyse structural members and machine parts under inelastic and plastic conditions.
7. Develop communication skills within an engineering context.
content_topics: Axial (normal) stress and strain, shear stress and strain.
Members under combined bending and axial load.
Analysis of slender columns and stability.
Inelastic bending analysis, elasto-plastic material behaviour.

assessments.name: Online Quizzes
assessments.intent: To provide additional practice for problem solving and to help students stay up to date with lecture material.
assessments.criteria: Online quizzes are summative and will contribute to the final mark of the subject.

assessments.name: Online Assignments
assessments.intent: To provide problem-solving practice and ensure students are caught up with lecture material.
assessments.criteria: Four online assignments contributing to 8.75% each. Access through Pearson resources.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Validation of learning on fundamental concepts in Mechanics of Solids and their application to solving problems.
assessments.criteria: Marks are based on logical workings and final quantitative results.

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

48340 Construction.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

prerequisites: 48310 Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering

48340 Construction.description: This subject provides a broad-based introduction to the construction industry and the technical and managerial skills needed by engineering professionals. Students will develop an understanding that leadership in construction projects requires a holistic approach, blending technical skill, logical reasoning, and management.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Show awareness of equipment, processes, and methodology in construction.
2. Estimate productivity of earth-moving equipment using cycle time data and balance machinery fleets.
3. Understand preliminary and detailed cost estimating.
4. Demonstrate understanding of project management.
5. Identify day-to-day problems encountered on construction sites.
6. Participate in planning construction projects and solving construction problems.

assessments.name: Notebook
assessments.intent: Students critically observe construction activities and report on them.

assessments.name: Team Planning Assignment
assessments.intent: Students work in groups to develop a project plan from engineering drawings.
assessments.criteria: Each item in the assignment brief must be addressed.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: Students demonstrate understanding of construction processes, equipment, and project management.

assessments.name: Online Quizzes
assessments.intent: Provide continuous formative assessment throughout the session.

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

48330 Soil Behaviour.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48330 Soil Behaviour.description: This subject introduces geosciences and soil as an engineering material. It includes hands-on geology and soil laboratory sessions, research projects, and debates that allow students to gain insights into soil behaviour and communicate effectively in real-world civil and geotechnical engineering design and construction projects.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Determine and interpret natural processes for civil engineering design and construction.
2. Communicate with geologists, earth scientists, and others studying the ground for infrastructure design.
3. Apply fundamental knowledge of soil behaviour in Civil Engineering projects.
4. Identify and evaluate aspects of soil behaviour impacting the environment.
5. Analyse and solve soil-related problems involving water flow and settlement.
6. Apply research skills in geotechnical engineering.
content_topics: Introduction to soil engineering: typical problems and the engineer's role
Geological fundamentals: classification and properties of rock
Geomorphology: rock weathering, soil formation, and landforms
Nature of soil: particulate nature, classification, and clay minerals
Introduction to soil mechanics: soil compaction, phase relationships
Water in soil: groundwater flow, permeability, and flow nets
Stress analysis: effective stress principle and in-situ stresses
Settlement of soils: consolidation theories and settlement estimation
Shear strength: Mohr-Coulomb failure law and testing

assessments.name: Soil Mechanics Assignments
assessments.intent: Practice problem solving and evaluate approaches related to soil mechanics.

assessments.name: Debate Activity
assessments.intent: Engage in a debate to solve real civil/geotechnical challenges, fostering critical thinking and research.
assessments.weight: Mandatory, not contributing to the final mark

assessments.name: Practicals and Laboratory Reports
assessments.intent: Hands-on soil tests to identify uncertainties and errors, strengthen statistical analysis, and practice report writing.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Evaluate understanding of soil mechanics and geology through problem solving and real-life applications.

assessments.name: Research Project
assessments.intent: Encourage students to be research-oriented and engage in geotechnical research.

assessments.name: Site Visit
assessments.intent: Demonstrate real-world understanding and teamwork through site observation and group discussion.
assessments.weight: Mandatory, not contributing to the final mark

assessments.name: Online Quiz
assessments.intent: Formative assessment to evaluate student learning and progress.
assessments.weight: Mandatory, not contributing to the final mark

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

48349 Structural Analysis.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48349 Structural Analysis.description: This subject covers classical theory of structures and its application to load-bearing structures such as buildings, bridges, and industrial enclosures. Students will learn to analyse the response of linear elastic structures under mechanical loads and environmental effects like temperature changes and foundation settlements. Topics include the analysis of statically determinate and indeterminate structures, as well as deformation calculations.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse statically determinate load-bearing structural frames and trusses by computing support reactions and internal forces.
2. Draw internal action diagrams showing the distribution of axial forces, shear forces, and bending moments.
3. Determine elastic deformations in structures under mechanical loads, temperature changes, and foundation settlements.
4. Analyse statically indeterminate structures using the Force Method and Moment Distribution Method.
5. Qualitatively derive support reactions, deformed shape, and internal action diagrams through diagrammatic reasoning.
content_topics: Analysis of statically determinate load-bearing frames and trusses
Qualitative analysis of structures, predicting support reactions, deformed shape, and internal actions
Principles of Work and Virtual Work
Elastic deformations from applied loads, temperature changes, and foundation settlements
Force Method for statically indeterminate structures
Moment Distribution Method for plane frames
Presentation of results using internal action diagrams (axial forces, shear forces, bending moments)

assessments.name: Weekly online quizzes (best 8 of 9 quizzes)
assessments.intent: Assess student progress on a weekly basis through online quizzes to reinforce lecture material.
assessments.criteria: Online quizzes will be marked automatically, with unique data sets for each student. Correct numerical answers within a prescribed error tolerance will attract marks.

assessments.name: eTasks
assessments.intent: Students complete challenging structural analysis problems using individual data sets to apply concepts covered in class.
assessments.criteria: The eTasks will be marked using a programmed algorithm, rewarding correct numerical answers within a prescribed error tolerance.

assessments.name: Tests (best 3 of 4 tests)
assessments.intent: Simulate exam conditions and assess students' ability to select and apply structural analysis methods.
assessments.criteria: Best 3 out of 4 tests will be counted. No make-up or supplementary tests.

assessments.name: Final examination (centrally conducted)
assessments.intent: Comprehensive assessment covering the entire subject content. It tests students' abilities in selecting, applying methods of analysis, and presenting results clearly.
assessments.length: Two hours plus 10 minutes reading time
assessments.criteria: Marks are based on accuracy of computations, use of relevant equations, and clear presentation of force and moment diagrams.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48352 Construction Materials.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

prerequisites: 60101 Chemistry and Materials Science OR 65111 Chemistry 1

48352 Construction Materials.description: This subject provides students with fundamental knowledge of the most common construction materials, such as concrete and steel, focusing on their properties and applications. Students will also learn to interpret Australian Standard test methods for material testing and assess the environmental effects on material performance. Topics include concrete production, properties of metals, and structural steels.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate fundamental knowledge of construction materials and predict their behavior in engineering applications.
2. Interpret and apply Australian Standard test methods for material testing.
3. Evaluate environmental effects on material performance, properties, and failure modes.
4. Select appropriate construction materials to meet prescriptive and performance-based requirements.
content_topics: Fresh and hardened properties of concrete
Time-dependent deformation and durability of concrete

assessments.name: Online Quizzes
assessments.intent: Allow students to assess their knowledge and understanding of concepts and self-assess their progress.
assessments.criteria: Quizzes will be marked based on correct answers, with multiple attempts allowed for practice.

assessments.name: Materials Design Report
assessments.intent: Students will solve a design problem using concrete or steel as the material, demonstrating problem-solving and research skills.
assessments.criteria: Reports will be assessed based on the quality of problem-solving, research, and justification of materials used in design.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Assess students' knowledge of construction materials, design principles, and problem-solving learned in the subject.
assessments.criteria: The exam will evaluate knowledge of construction materials and problem-solving abilities applied to real-world scenarios.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48353 Concrete Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48353 Concrete Design.description: This subject covers reinforced concrete (RC) and prestressed concrete (PSC) design. Students will learn about the behavior and design of RC beams, slabs, columns, and PSC beams, focusing on both serviceability and strength according to the Australian Standards. The subject builds on knowledge of statics, solid mechanics, and structural analysis, preparing students for professional practice in structural design.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Discuss the behavior and design of RC beams, slabs, columns, and PSC beams for serviceability and strength.
2. Apply the Limit State Design philosophy of Australian Standards for structural design.
3. Discuss the material properties of concrete, reinforcement, and prestressing steel.
4. Analyze RC flexural members, beams, slabs, and columns for strength according to AS3600.
5. Apply AS3600 to the analysis, design, and detailing of PSC flexural members for serviceability and strength.
content_topics: Serviceability and ultimate design for moment and shear in RC beams and slabs
Prestressed concrete analysis, equivalent loads, load balancing techniques

assessments.name: Design Assignments
assessments.intent: Assess students' ability to apply structural design concepts in RC and PSC design.

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: Test students' understanding of RC and PSC design principles.

assessments.name: Design Project
assessments.intent: Provide students with practical experience in collaborative structural design for concrete structures.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: Comprehensive assessment of students' knowledge of concrete design.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48641 Fluid Mechanics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

recommended_studies: Background in physics, mechanics, and applied mathematics

48641 Fluid Mechanics.description: This subject aims to provide students with a solid understanding of fluid behaviour in both static and flowing conditions. Key topics include fluid properties, conservation laws, flow in pipes, external flow, boundary layers, flow measurements, and environmental fluid mechanics. Students will develop practical skills in analyzing and designing engineering systems involving fluids, and engage in projects and lab work to reinforce theoretical concepts.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify and use key concepts and fundamental principles related to fluid behaviour in static and flowing conditions.
2. Analyze and design engineering systems and devices involving fluids and flow.
3. Recognize possible applications and links to other disciplines, and engage in further specialized study or research.
content_topics: Conservation laws: mass, energy, and momentum

assessments.name: Laboratory 1
assessments.intent: Group collaboration to gain practical experience in fluid mechanics experiments.

assessments.name: Laboratory 2
assessments.intent: Further experimentation to develop practical understanding of fluid behaviour.

assessments.name: Project
assessments.intent: Open-ended research-like study where students work collaboratively to solve fluid mechanics problems.

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: Assess students’ knowledge of fluid mechanics concepts and their ability to solve related problems.

assessments.name: Final examination
assessments.intent: Comprehensive assessment of students’ understanding of fluid mechanics principles and their applications.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48370 Road and Transport Engineering.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

prerequisites: 48310 Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering

48370 Road and Transport Engineering.description: This subject introduces students to the discipline of transport engineering, focusing on transport planning and traffic engineering. Key topics include sustainable design, public transport provision, 4-step transport modelling, and traffic flow theory. Students gain practical skills in evaluating transport systems and developing transport management plans.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse the relationships between transport users, infrastructure, vehicles, and transport modes for sustainable transport systems.
2. Apply basic terminology, empirical data analysis, and modelling concepts in transport planning and traffic engineering.
3. Examine interactions between land-use development, transport infrastructure, and traffic operations to create transport management plans.
content_topics: Introduction to Road and Transport Engineering
Variability in Traffic and Queuing Theory
The 4-Step Transport Modelling Process: Trip Generation, Trip Distribution, Mode Choice, and Traffic Assignment

assessments.name: Transport Modelling and Operations
assessments.intent: Evaluate a student's ability to apply traffic engineering concepts and solve operational problems in road networks.

assessments.name: Transport Planning
assessments.intent: Assess a student's ability to define transport systems and relationships and analyse operational impacts on performance.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Test students' ability to perform calculations and interpret models related to traffic and transport.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48350 Environmental and Sanitation Engin.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48350 Environmental and Sanitation Engin.description: This subject introduces civil engineering students to essential environmental concepts and the environmental consequences of typical engineering activities. Students develop an awareness of environmental issues, preventive and management strategies to minimise pollution, and concepts of water pollution control mechanisms.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Acquire an awareness of environmental issues relevant to civil engineering-related activities.
2. Reinforce the implication of construction processes within a natural system.
3. Demonstrate familiarity with preventive and management strategies to combat water, soil, air, and noise pollution.
4. Identify concepts of water pollution control mechanisms and their impact on design.
content_topics: Design of water and wastewater treatment systems
Project case studies emphasizing environmental issues

assessments.name: Two Laboratory Practicals
assessments.intent: Gain practical experience in measuring basic water quality parameters and applying classroom concepts.

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: Provide formative feedback to reflect students' learning and understanding of the subject.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Review topics covered and assess students' knowledge and understanding of the subject.

assessments.name: Treatment Plant Field Visit Report
assessments.intent: Explore real-life water and wastewater treatment processes and link theoretical knowledge with real practice.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48366 Steel and Timber Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48366 Steel and Timber Design.description: This subject builds on students' knowledge of statics, solid mechanics, and structural analysis of indeterminate structures. It introduces the Limit State Design (LSD) philosophy, structural steel, and timber design topics in accordance with Australian Standards.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse and design structural steel members and connections in accordance with AS4100 and AS1170.0.
2. Apply knowledge of timber design and properties to design timber elements in accordance with AS1720.1 and AS1170.0.
content_topics: Steel material properties for design and section types
Design of steel members carrying axial compression
Steel beam design for strength and serviceability
Steel beam-column design with second-order effects
Timber material properties for design and supply
Timber connections: nailed, bolted, and screwed

assessments.name: Online Quiz (revision exercise)
assessments.intent: To provide formative feedback and assess students' understanding of key topics.

assessments.name: Online Tasks (four online tasks)
assessments.intent: Gain practical experience in structural design calculations and decisions.

assessments.name: In-Class Quiz
assessments.intent: Assess competence in timber and steel design concepts and problem-solving.

assessments.name: Final Examination
assessments.intent: Comprehensive assessment of the fundamental concepts, problem-solving skills, and design procedures in timber and steel design.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48389 Computer Modelling and Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

prerequisites: 144 credit points in relevant Bachelor of Engineering courses

48389 Computer Modelling and Design.description: This subject introduces senior civil engineering students to the preparation and analysis of computer models of load bearing structures. It covers establishing loads on buildings according to Australian standards and applying them to computer models.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Establish loads on buildings in compliance with Australian standards.
2. Apply the theory and algorithms used to develop frame analysis software.
3. Model structural frameworks and perform linear elastic analyses for static loads.
4. Model 2D and 3D framework structures and interpret computer output.
content_topics: Computer modelling and analysis of structural frameworks
Integration of structural design with modelling and analysis

assessments.name: eTask - Computer methods of structural analysis
assessments.intent: Test understanding of computer modelling of structural frameworks and use of structural analysis software.

assessments.name: Quiz 1
assessments.intent: Test ability to model plane frames and trusses, establish permanent and imposed actions based on AS1170.

assessments.name: Quiz 2
assessments.intent: Test competency in computerised methods for 2D/3D trusses, frames, grillages; analyze static loads, temperature effects, foundation settlement.

assessments.name: Design Assignment
assessments.intent: Test understanding of calculating structural loads, modeling structures, and producing design outputs.
assessments.criteria: Present final design in AutoCAD with proper dimensions and scaled physical model.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48362 Hydraulics and Hydrology.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48362 Hydraulics and Hydrology.description: This subject provides students with the opportunity to consolidate knowledge around open channel hydraulics and hydrology. It focuses on applying hydraulic and hydrological methods to engineering applications, extending the knowledge from fluid mechanics, and introducing water engineering design skills.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Critically analyse water demands and resources, and explain the distribution and properties of earth's waters.
2. Apply hydraulic and hydrologic procedures to engineering applications, expanding knowledge of fluid flow principles.
3. Perform mathematical modelling used in hydraulics and hydrology.
content_topics: Unit Hydrographs, Yield Analysis, Evaporation, and Groundwater
Energy Principles for Open Channel Flow
HEC-RAS Steady Flow and Unsteady Flow Modelling
teaching_and_learning: 2 x 2-hour lecture sessions per week, with a mix of hydraulics and hydrology topics.
Students participate in problem-solving activities, discussions, and hands-on computer modelling sessions.
All teaching materials are available on UTSOnline.

assessments.name: Assignments
assessments.intent: Demonstrate understanding of hydraulic and hydrology modelling, and communicate subject knowledge through written reports.
assessments.length: Written reports vary with assignment tasks, but not more than 10 pages.

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: Test understanding of theoretical concepts and fundamental analytical aspects of hydraulics and hydrology.

minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

16314 Construction Technology 3.faculty: UTS: Design, Architecture and Building: School of the Built Environment
16314 Construction Technology 3.description: This subject focuses on construction technology for industrial buildings, building quality, dispute resolution, and the remedial building industry. The primary elements of industrial buildings, such as warehouses and factories, are examined in detail, with a particular focus on site conditions, soil contamination, structural principles, and building quality management.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Describe the interrelationship, behaviour, and function of components in steel-framed construction.
2. Describe conventional construction methods, materials, terminology, and details for industrial buildings.
3. Demonstrate an understanding of the purpose and application of standard building elements.
4. Apply statutory regulations governing construction in Australia to the management of industrial construction projects.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: P.2 Apply the body of knowledge underpinning construction project management practice.
P.7 Analyse and advise on alternative design solutions to promote value in projects.
P.9 Contribute to the effective acquisition and management of assets throughout their lifecycle.
content_topics: Site Investigation Techniques and Risk Assessment
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Face-to-face lectures using media and electronic resources.
Class discussions, online learning, and independent research.
Collaborative in-class reviews and site visits.
Feedback is provided throughout the learning process, including formative and summative feedback on assessments.

assessments.name: Site Visit and Report
assessments.intent: Gain insight into an active industrial building project and observe real-life application of class material.

criteria.1: Demonstrate understanding of steel frame construction components, functions, and behaviors.
criteria.2: Demonstrate understanding of conventional methods of industrial building construction.
criteria.3: Demonstrate the ability to make informed decisions regarding the use of standard building elements.

assessments.name: Industry Practice Critique Report
assessments.intent: Critique current construction management methods to develop personal approaches to building quality.

criteria.1: Demonstrate understanding of conventional methods of industrial building construction.
criteria.2: Demonstrate the ability to make informed decisions on building elements.
criteria.3: Demonstrate understanding of statutory regulations governing construction.

assessments.name: In-Class Video Content Assessment
assessments.intent: Demonstrate understanding of video content presented in-class related to construction management and building quality.

criteria.1: Demonstrate understanding of how construction management influences building quality.
criteria.2: Demonstrate understanding of how building regulation influences construction management.

minimum_requirements: Students must attend no less than 80% of formal teaching sessions to remain eligible for assessment.
Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

16912 Construction Project Management Pr.faculty: UTS: Design, Architecture and Building: School of the Built Environment
16912 Construction Project Management Pr.description: This subject introduces students to the fundamental principles of project management as outlined by the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) and other management theories. Students will learn core competencies like creating project schedules, developing work breakdown structures, and producing risk registers, with a focus on real-world applications in construction.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate foundational knowledge in project management principles, terminology, and tools relevant to construction project management.
2. Apply project management terminology, tools, and techniques to create a project management plan.
3. Demonstrate effective written and oral communication in project management contexts.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1 Apply a variety of communication skills and technologies in professional contexts.
C.2 Work effectively in project teams in professional contexts.
P.2 Apply the body of knowledge underpinning construction project management practice.
R.1 Source, evaluate, and use information to approach new projects and problems.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Weekly face-to-face lectures and workshops.
Case studies and practical exercises applying project management concepts.
Workshops designed for practice-oriented learning with feedback from instructors.
Use of SPARK for self- and peer-assessment in group projects.

assessments.name: Weekly Diary and Individual Quiz
assessments.intent: The diary helps students reflect on weekly concepts, supporting quiz completion and feedback.

criteria.2: Apply project management tools and techniques effectively.

assessments.name: Project Management Plan (Group Assessment)
assessments.intent: Students demonstrate the ability to apply project management principles using written communication.

criteria.1: Apply project management principles in creating a project management plan.
criteria.2: Demonstrate effective communication and collaboration within a team.

assessments.name: Video and Individual Project Management Plan
assessments.intent: Students apply project management principles in a new context and demonstrate oral communication skills.

criteria.1: Summarise key points of the project management plan concisely.
criteria.2: Demonstrate effective oral and written communication.

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject.

16263 Design Team Management.faculty: UTS: Design, Architecture and Building: School of the Built Environment
16263 Design Team Management.recommended_studies: 3rd year Construction Project Management, 4th year Civil Engineering, Master of Architecture students
16263 Design Team Management.description: This subject examines the management of design teams within multidisciplinary, cross-functional projects. Students learn theoretical models of the design process, the practical aspects of design management, and the use of Building Information Modelling (BIM) and other digital technologies for optimizing collaboration and performance within teams. Core learning is supplemented with case studies from industry experts.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the design processes
2. Appreciate the importance of team culture and communication
3. Apply knowledge of team behavior to specific projects
4. Understand and apply information and knowledge management within design teams
5. Demonstrate knowledge of alternative contractual relationships within teams
6. Evaluate design using selected methodologies
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1 Apply a variety of communication skills and technologies in professional contexts
C.2 Work effectively in project teams in professional contexts
I.1 Provide innovative and creative solutions to industry/project issues
P.5 Develop strategic advice for clients on costs and benefits in construction projects
P.7 Analyse and advise on alternative design solutions to achieve value on projects
R.1 Source, evaluate, and use information to approach new projects or problems
content_topics: Best practices in project process management
The design process from different AEC perspectives
Managing information using BIM and international standards
Contemporary issues in design team management
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Face-to-face classes with theoretical and practice-based lectures
Guest lectures from industry specialists
Discussion of case studies and industry issues
Online quizzes to assess understanding of guest lectures
Formative and summative feedback through lectures and tutorials
Self-study and research into core topics independently

assessments.name: Quizzes
assessments.intent: Assist students in understanding design processes, digital technologies, and practical challenges in collaborative design

criteria.1: Demonstrate understanding of information/knowledge sharing and management
criteria.2: Recognize different roles and responsibilities within design teams

assessments.name: Group Activities/Exercises
assessments.intent: Evaluate design development using selected methodologies

assessments.name: Industry/Field Study
assessments.intent: Study contemporary management of design teams and demonstrate professional reporting and critical thinking

criteria.1: Demonstrate knowledge of digital technologies and procurement methods
criteria.3: Show effective report writing and presentation skills

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve a minimum aggregate mark of 50% to pass the subject.

16422 Construction Technology 4.faculty: UTS: Design, Architecture and Building: School of the Built Environment
16422 Construction Technology 4.description: This subject examines construction technology for multi-storey commercial buildings. Students learn about high-rise construction techniques, materials handling, building services, structural principles, and regulatory compliance. The subject also explores internal fitouts and the integration of various building systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the interrelationship, behaviour, and function of components in multi-storey buildings
2. Understand conventional construction methods, materials, and terminology for multi-storey buildings
3. Understand construction interfaces between different building elements
4. Relate academic studies to practical applications
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1 Apply a variety of communication skills and technologies in professional contexts
P.2 Apply the body of knowledge underpinning construction project management practice
P.9 Contribute to the effective acquisition and management of assets throughout their life cycle
content_topics: Building techniques for multi-storey construction systems
Formwork types and temporary support systems
High-rise construction systems and materials (steel, post-tension structures)
Building services: data and communication, mechanical ventilation, fire services, security systems
Site establishment requirements for commercial buildings
Structural support systems, both temporary and permanent
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Face-to-face lectures with media and electronic resources
Group work, student presentations, and experiential exercises
Pre-reading of subject material to facilitate better class discussions
Field trips to ongoing construction projects
Group assignments focused on practical applications of high-rise construction
Formal closed-book examination to assess understanding of content

assessments.name: Site Visit
assessments.intent: Gain insight into high-rise construction project management and related methodologies

criteria.1: On-time attendance at the construction project site with personal protective equipment

assessments.name: Group Report and Presentation
assessments.intent: Understand the management and methodologies of high-rise construction projects

criteria.1: Understanding of concepts related to multi-storey buildings
criteria.2: Demonstrated understanding of conventional construction methods and materials

assessments.name: Formal Examination
assessments.intent: Examine understanding of common high-rise construction technologies, regulations, and methodologies

criteria.2: Demonstrated understanding of conventional methods and materials

minimum_requirements: Students must attend no less than 80% of formal teaching sessions (lectures and tutorials) to be eligible for assessment.

48840 Water Supply and Wastewater Engine.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48840 Water Supply and Wastewater Engine.description: This subject provides civil and environmental engineering students with a detailed understanding of water pollution control, potable water and sewage treatment process design, sewerage and water reticulation systems, and advanced technologies used in upgrading water and wastewater treatment plants, desalination, and water re-use.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify water pollution control objectives and water quality parameters
2. Understand the design of potable water and sewage treatment processes
3. Identify technologies used in upgrading water and wastewater treatment plants and water reuse
4. Recognize public health and environmental objectives in water supply and wastewater disposal
5. Understand membrane and other processes used in water reclamation and desalination
6. Carry out water supply and wastewater engineering projects
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1 Socially Responsible: Identify and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, uncertainties, and risks to define system requirements
C.1 Design Oriented: Apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to meet specified requirements
content_topics: Sewerage systems and water supply systems – water quality and quantity
Design concepts for sewerage and water reticulation systems
Total water cycle management and sewage treatment
Primary, secondary, and tertiary treatment processes
Water reuse practices including membrane processes
New water quality standards and technologies for upgrading water treatment processes
Water recycling and water re-use technologies
Case studies on water reclamation projects
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Lectures, tutorials, in-class assignments, and laboratory sessions
Use of case studies presented by experienced lecturers and practitioners
Emphasis on practical applications and current technologies in water and wastewater engineering
Hands-on computer and experimental laboratories

assessments.name: Wastewater treatment and management
assessments.intent: To test knowledge of wastewater treatment and management
assessments.criteria: Short-answer questions with quantitative and qualitative responses

assessments.name: Drinking water treatment and management
assessments.intent: Process description and design of water treatment processes
assessments.criteria: Single answers and problem-solving methodology with detailed discussions

assessments.name: Laboratory/Practical
assessments.intent: Conduct experiments to validate theoretical concepts
assessments.criteria: Laboratory report submission for each experiment

assessments.name: Mid Session Quiz
assessments.intent: Assessment of knowledge gained in lectures and laboratories
assessments.criteria: Closed-book quiz on wastewater treatment concepts and sewerage systems

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: Comprehensive assessment of knowledge from lectures and labs
assessments.criteria: Exam on design, operation, and maintenance of water and wastewater treatment processes

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject

48860 Pollution Control and Waste Manage.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48860 Pollution Control and Waste Manage.description: This subject focuses on tackling the problems of solid and hazardous waste minimisation, generation, treatment, and disposal. It also covers air and noise pollution control technologies and explores the related social, environmental, and regulatory issues.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply principles of waste minimisation, source reduction, and material use in the design of solid and hazardous waste management systems
2. Develop technical knowledge and design skills related to solid waste generation, collection, and disposal
3. Develop technical knowledge and design skills related to hazardous waste treatment and management
4. Assess air and noise pollution problems and apply control approaches to real problems in civil and environmental engineering practice
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1 Socially Responsible: Identify and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, uncertainties, and risks to define system requirements
C.1 Design Oriented: Apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes
E.1 Collaborative and Communicative: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating effectively across different contexts
content_topics: Solid waste characterisation, generation, and composition analysis
Types of waste disposal methods and their social and environmental issues
Design, operation, and maintenance of sanitary landfills
Hazardous waste generation, classification, and process information
Collection, storage, and transport of toxic waste
Design of hazardous waste treatment and stabilisation methodologies
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Pre-work and face-to-face sessions conducted in block format (three sessions of 1.5 days each)
Group activities and self-learning supported by preparatory reading materials
Field trip to waste management facilities to deepen practical knowledge
Class time for group problem-solving and discussions

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: To combine prior research and peer collaboration with formal assessment to provide feedback on learning

assessments.name: Research reports
assessments.intent: Research specific topics and submit findings via Turnitin
assessments.length: No longer than 2 pages each (reference list can be an extra page)

assessments.name: Major project
assessments.intent: Design a waste management system for a chosen suburb and critically examine a real case scenario of a landfill or waste management facility
assessments.length: No longer than 20 pages, including reference list

assessments.name: Final exam
assessments.intent: Formal assessment of knowledge gained during the course

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject

48821 Principles of Environmental Engine.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
48821 Principles of Environmental Engine.description: This subject teaches fundamental chemical, physical, and biological principles to analyse data and formulate design solutions for environmental problems, particularly related to water and air quality.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Describe fundamental environmental engineering concepts and apply them to environmental problems
2. Design and evaluate a waste treatment system
3. Carry out simple material balances relevant for environmental systems
4. Communicate engineering investigation outcomes in professionally varied ways
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1 Socially Responsible: Identify, engage, and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints to define system requirements
C.1 Design Oriented: Apply problem solving and design methodologies to develop systems that meet specified requirements
D.1 Technically Proficient: Apply mathematics, discipline fundamentals, and tools to evaluate and operate systems
E.1 Collaborative and Communicative: Work as an effective member or leader in diverse teams and communicate across contexts
content_topics: Chemistry fundamentals: units, stoichiometry, chemical equilibrium, and kinetics
Chemical transformation processes: volatilization, acid-base chemistry, oxidation-reduction, precipitation
Material balances: mass balance with reactions, reactors
Water quality engineering and management: dissolved oxygen, nutrient management
Air quality engineering, noise pollution and control
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Face-to-face lectures and laboratory sessions with a mix of taught material and group-based problem solving activities
In-class problem solving strategies, research skills, practice design problems, and critical reviews of anonymized student exemplars
Out-of-class activities include peer review, quizzes, and review of technical knowledge

assessments.name: Knowledge Quiz (Formative)
assessments.intent: To develop and self-test students' understanding of key concepts
assessments.weight: Mandatory task that does not contribute to subject mark

assessments.name: Quiz
assessments.intent: To provide feedback on students' learning and encourage collaborative group discussions

assessments.name: Waste Treatment Design Project
assessments.intent: To integrate fundamental concepts of reactors, reaction kinetics, and chemical transformations with laboratory experiences

assessments.name: Project Communication
assessments.intent: To communicate key knowledge from the project to an end user through multimedia presentation

assessments.name: Final Exam
assessments.intent: To evaluate the student's understanding and communication of key concepts

minimum_requirements: Students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more to pass the subject

41011 Environmental Chemical Processes.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
41011 Environmental Chemical Processes.description: This subject covers chemical processes related to environmental issues, including air, energy, climate change, toxic chemicals, and water. It focuses on the sources, reactions, transport, effects, and fates of chemicals in the air, water, and soil, with an emphasis on laboratory skills and environmental engineering processes.
content_topics: 2. Water, air, soil and their impurities
5. Environmental sample analysis and measurement issues
6. Chemical and instrumental measurements of environmental samples

48850 Environmental Planning and Law.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering

C10062 Bachelor of Engineering Bachelor of Arts International Studies Diploma Engineering Practice
C10063 Bachelor of Engineering Bachelor of Arts International Studies

C09072 Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) Bachelor of Science

48850 Environmental Planning and Law.description: This subject introduces key environmental law and planning legislation, with emphasis on NSW. It covers environmental planning history, environmental law principles, development planning, environmental impact assessment, and planning constraints.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply environmental and planning legislation to engineering contexts.
2. Analyse the balance between development and environmental protection.
3. Describe and apply considerations in the planning process.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: Graduates identify and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints to define system requirements. (B.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: Graduates work effectively within cross-disciplinary contexts. (E.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Interactive lectures with case studies and discussions.
Tutorial sessions with role play and group exercises.
Collaborative learning and feedback through small group activities.
content_topics: 1. Environmental Law: Evolution, legal framework in Australia, pollution-related legislation.
2. Environmental Planning: Urban planning, neighbourhood concepts, case studies.

41009 Renewable Energy Technology.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
41009 Renewable Energy Technology.description: This subject explores renewable energy technologies focusing on sources like solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biofuels. It covers energy flows, design concepts, operational issues, and policy challenges. Students also examine real-world case studies to design renewable energy projects.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Demonstrate knowledge of renewable energy technology concepts and issues.
2. Evaluate technical advances and operational processes of renewable energy.
3. Perform calculations on energy generation and design renewable energy projects.
4. Assess renewable energy systems based on environmental, economic, and social criteria.
5. Apply alternative energy technologies in environmental engineering practice.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, and identify constraints to define system requirements. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem solving and design methodologies to develop components and processes. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate systems. (D.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Face-to-face lectures, tutorials, and class discussions.
Field visits and guest lectures from Australian industry experts.
Online materials and seminar presentations via UTSOnline.
Individual research and team activities for report submissions.
content_topics: 2. Energy flows and non-fossil fuel sources.
3. Renewable energy systems: solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biofuel.
4. Renewable energy planning, policies, and challenges.
5. Technological advances in renewable energy systems.
6. Case studies on the assessment of renewable energy technologies.
minimum_requirements: Attend the field trip.
Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48881 Water and Environmental Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Civil and Environmental Engineering
requisites: 144 credit points of completed study in applicable programs
48881 Water and Environmental Design.description: This subject involves designing a land-based effluent treatment site and conducting a cultural impact assessment for a proposed land development project. Students apply technical knowledge, predictive modelling, and stakeholder engagement to address environmental, social, and technical challenges, producing professional written and multimedia reports.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply environmental engineering knowledge and concepts to problems.
2. Apply investigation, modeling, and analysis methods to an engineering problem.
3. Identify cultural sensitivity and design stakeholder consultation processes.
4. Communicate design outcomes in varied and professionally relevant ways.
5. Reflect upon and communicate learning from professionally relevant experiences.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and software tools to evaluate, implement, and operate systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in cross-disciplinary teams. (E.1)
Reflective: FEIT graduates critically review their performance to improve themselves and their teams. (F.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Three in-class face-to-face blocks with structured content and group-based problem-solving.
Problem-oriented learning, requiring high levels of autonomy and independent critical thinking.
Out-of-class activities include case study review and reflective learning.
Learner Resource Material (LRM) provided via UTSOnline for technical knowledge.
content_topics: Cultural, heritage, and traditions impact assessment

assessment_task_1.title: Cultural and Heritage Impact Assessment Report

minimum_requirements: Achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48441 Introductory Digital Systems.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

requisites.prerequisite: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering

48441 Introductory Digital Systems.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic electrical engineering circuits and soldering skills.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.description: This subject enables students to master the fundamentals of digital and programmable electronic circuits, small computer system hardware architecture, and low-level programming. Topics include digital sequential circuits, microcontroller hardware, assembly language, interrupts, input/output, and hardware interfacing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design combinational and sequential logic circuits.
2. Implement and evaluate logic circuits using appropriate software tools.
3. Analyse digital logic circuits.
4. Design and implement programmable logic devices and microcontrollers and related input/output components.
5. Identify basic assembly programming techniques to construct and implement basic assembly programs.
6. Write and evaluate assembly programs using appropriate software tools.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, and risks. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and software tools to evaluate and implement systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams, communicating and collaborating in cross-disciplinary contexts. (E.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Problem-based learning approach involving designing and analysing digital logic and microcontroller circuits.
Interactive lectures, face-to-face tutorials, and hands-on lab activities.
Students are expected to watch videos on UTSOnline and prepare before attending classes and labs.
Lab activities include hardware kit use, circuit design, and assembly language programming.
Immediate feedback from lab tutors during lab sessions.
content_topics: State diagrams and their application in digital circuit design.
Basic hardware architectures of digital computers.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48521 Fundamentals of Electrical Enginee.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

prerequisites: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering

48521 Fundamentals of Electrical Enginee.recommended_studies: Basic physics, single-variable calculus, and basic electric circuit theory are essential.
48521 Fundamentals of Electrical Enginee.description: This subject revisits concepts from Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering and introduces students to basic electrostatic and electromagnetic theory, magnetic devices, semiconductor devices, electronic amplifiers, and electrical measurements. Students also gain practical skills needed for their first Engineering Experience internship.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the key conceptual underpinnings and principles of electromagnetic phenomena, electrical machines, electronic amplifiers, and their applications.
2. Utilise electronic measurement equipment and implement basic construction of semiconductor and magnetic devices in laboratory.
3. Predict and measure basic quantities in electric and magnetic circuits; analyse and design them.
4. Mathematically model a wide variety of electromagnetic and electronic phenomena.
5. Apply technical terms and notation in classroom discussions and assessment tasks.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, and risks. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and software tools to evaluate, implement and operate systems. (D.1)
content_topics: Electrostatics: conductors, semiconductors, insulators, Coulomb's & Gauss' Laws, dielectrics, capacitance.
Electromagnetics: Biot-Savart Law, Lorentz Law, Ampere's Law, moving fields, induced voltage.
Magnetic devices: permanent magnets, transformers, moving coils, magnetic actuators, simple machines.
Electronic devices and amplifiers: P-N junctions, diodes, FETs, BJTs, MOSFETs, single-stage and differential amplifiers, operational amplifiers.
Electrical measurements: electromechanical meters, electronic meters, bridges, responses, errors.
48521 Fundamentals of Electrical Enginee.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.description: This subject introduces students to high-level procedural programming using C. Topics include conditional statements, iteration, functions, arrays, file processing, data structures, and memory management using pointers. Students also learn to compile C source code using the GNU toolchain, link binary object files, and run executables, following the complete development cycle, from problem analysis to testing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, develop, and test programs in C to solve data-related problems.
2. Identify and explain the use of programming tools, standard libraries, and OS functions to support program execution.
3. Follow professional programming practices to align with industry expectations.
4. Collaborate effectively as a team member to solve complex problems using C.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and decision-making methodologies to develop systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and operate systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams and communicate across contexts. (E.1)
content_topics: Fundamental programming concepts: program development cycle, GNU toolchain, compiling C source code, linking, debugging, and testing.
Procedural programming in C: primitive data types, operators, typecasting, functions, pass by reference/value.
Control and loop statements: logical expressions, conditionals, and loops.
Arrays: creation, manipulation, and string handling.
Structures and file processing: user-defined structures, binary/text file handling.
Pointers: dynamic memory management, linked lists.
Advanced topics: user-defined libraries, command line parsing, programming in the large.

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz
assessment_task_1.intent: Reinforce and assess understanding of basic and fundamental C programming concepts.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignment
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess understanding of C programming concepts and application to real-world Data Engineering.

assessment_task_3.title: Group Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess ability to deliver programming solutions as a group.
assessment_task_3.length: Project report no more than 10 pages.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
