assessment_task_4.intent: Evaluate understanding of fundamental programming concepts and C programming, along with professional coding practices.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48530 Circuit Analysis and Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48530 Circuit Analysis and Design.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic electrical circuits and devices, and basic circuit analysis skills
48530 Circuit Analysis and Design.description: This subject provides a thorough understanding of circuit analysis with a focus on frequency domain analysis techniques. Students use theoretical models, computer-aided design, and experimental verification of circuit behavior using laboratory equipment. Topics include sinusoidal steady-state analysis, Laplace transformation, power in AC circuits, transfer functions, Bode plots, two-port circuits, and more.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse linear circuits at an appropriate level of accuracy.
2. Transform circuit problems into simplified equivalent forms for easier solutions.
3. Analyse circuits using advanced frequency-domain transformation techniques.
4. Design circuits to achieve required specifications and confirm compliance experimentally.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop systems that meet specified requirements.
D.1: Apply mathematics, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
E.1: Work effectively as a member or leader of diverse teams, communicating effectively in cross-disciplinary contexts.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.class_time: Used for tutorials and laboratories. Attendance and participation in scheduled classes is essential.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.lecture_videos: Narrated lecture videos accessed via UTSOnline. Students must watch these before tutorials.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.tutorials: Students form small groups to solve problems and present their solutions.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.laboratories: Hands-on circuit construction and testing. Pre-lab work includes preparatory design to achieve specifications.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.design_project: A team-based project requiring students to design and test a circuit to meet a product specification.

content_topics: Time and frequency response of electric circuits
Frequency response of first- and second-order filters
Fourier series and periodic function responses
Bode plots for frequency response prediction

assessment_task_1.title: Groupwork Laboratory Assignments
assessment_task_1.intent: Assess groupwork design projects and laboratory testing.

assessment_task_2.title: Tutorial Quizzes
assessment_task_2.intent: Encourage even learning load and provide feedback on understanding.

assessment_task_3.title: Individual Laboratory Assignments
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess students' understanding of material covered in labs.

assessment_task_4.title: Design Project
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess teamwork in designing a circuit to meet product specifications.

48530 Circuit Analysis and Design.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48531 Electromechanical Automation.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48531 Electromechanical Automation.description: This subject consolidates knowledge of electric and magnetic fields, electric and magnetic circuits, and electromechanical energy conversion. Students model electromechanical automation systems using DC and AC motors, design closed-loop control systems, and work with machines at mains supply voltage and PLCs. Skills in electrical safety, measurements, design validation, and experimental verification are also developed.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply fundamentals of electric and magnetic fields to solve circuit problems and interpret electromechanical energy conversion.
2. Model electromechanical automation systems using DC and AC motors and design closed-loop control systems.
3. Work with electric machines and PLCs in automation systems at normal mains supply voltage.
4. Demonstrate laboratory skills in electrical safety, measurements, design validation, and experimental verification.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify, interpret, and analyze stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components and systems.
D.1: Apply mathematical and discipline fundamentals, tools, and techniques to operate systems.
E.1: Work effectively as a member or leader in diverse teams, communicating across disciplines.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.lectures: Two-hour face-to-face lectures supported by online material, hand-outs, and tutorial notes.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.tutorials: Two-hour tutorials focused on solving problems related to automation systems and energy conversion.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.laboratories: Three-hour weekly laboratory sessions where students engage in practical exercises, experiments, and validation of theoretical concepts.

content_topics: Modelling and control for automation systems (PID, closed-loop control, state feedback)
Machines and systems (VR motors, DC/AC motors, microactuators, PLCs)
Fundamentals of fields, circuits, and devices (electrostatics, electromagnetic induction, circuits, devices)

assessment_task_1.title: Laboratory Work
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop practical skills in measurements, parameter calculations, and validation of theoretical concepts.
assessment_task_1.length: Lab duration is 2 hours each for 4 labs
criteria: Correct lab prework and understanding of electromagnetic concepts.
Correct use of lab equipment and quality of lab reports.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess knowledge of electromagnetic fields, circuits, and electromechanical systems.
criteria: Comprehension of basic concepts of electric and magnetic fields, and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_3.title: Assignment
assessment_task_3.intent: Develop technical knowledge of electromechanical automation systems and explore modern automation advances.
criteria: Comprehensive knowledge of electromechanical automation systems.
Overall quality of written report and oral seminar presentation.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess problem-solving skills and knowledge of electromechanical automation systems.
criteria: Correct problem-solving answers and reasoning for electromechanical systems.
Correct explanations reflecting practical experience and knowledge.

48531 Electromechanical Automation.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48540 Signals and Systems.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48540 Signals and Systems.recommended_studies: Circuit analysis in both the time and frequency domains, including the use of differential equations and transform methods.
48540 Signals and Systems.description: This subject covers system analysis techniques, focusing on the analysis and design of control and communication systems. Students model, simulate, and test real-world systems and apply theoretical knowledge through laboratory experiments and a group project. Topics include signal types, differential/difference equations, transforms, feedback, stability, and system design techniques.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply mathematical tools associated with transform theory to analyse and design continuous-time and discrete-time systems.
2. Analyse, design, simulate, and test parts of a communication system and a control system in both time-domain and frequency-domain.
3. Model real and complex systems using a hierarchical approach, and simplify them with appropriate assumptions.
4. Measure time and frequency characteristics of signals and systems using laboratory equipment.
5. Communicate technical ideas, decisions, calculations, and experimental results in a written document.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify and analyse stakeholder needs, establish priorities, and define system requirements.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes.
D.1: Apply mathematical and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
E.1: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating across cross-disciplinary contexts.
F.1: Critically self-review performance to improve individually and as part of a team.

lectures_and_tutorials.schedule: Two 2-hour sessions per week, including collaborative problem-solving and hands-on lab activities.
lectures_and_tutorials.preparation: Study notes and readings before each session, complete pre-lab work, and participate in collaborative discussions.
lectures_and_tutorials.labs: Formal lab sessions to apply theory, using appropriate equipment and software tools.

project_work.group_project: A design and implementation project focusing on communication and control systems, culminating in a formal report.

content_topics: Signals and Systems in the Time-Domain
Signals and Systems in the Frequency-Domain

assessment_task_1.title: Labs 1-5
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop skills in modelling and applying signal theory in practical contexts.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz
assessment_task_2.intent: Test knowledge of continuous-time signals and systems.

assessment_task_3.title: Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Design, simulate, test, and demonstrate a control and communication scheme.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Test knowledge of discrete-time systems, control systems, and communication systems.

48540 Signals and Systems.minimum_requirements: To pass, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48560 Control Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48560 Control Studio A.description: The objective of this subject is to enable students to model and validate control systems, and to design and implement both analog and digital controllers so that the controlled systems conform to given specifications. Students work on reduced scale models of actual industrial processes. Theoretical content is kept to the minimum required to produce successful designs, with a focus on laboratory work.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model typical control systems and provide appropriate validation for the model.
2. Design and implement analogue controllers, digital controllers, or state-variable controllers so that the controlled systems conform to given specifications.
3. Explore situations where model uncertainty, disturbances, and typical nonlinearities such as limiter, backlash, or deadband are present.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify, engage, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, establish priorities, and define system requirements.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes.
D.1: Apply mathematical and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
E.1: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating across cross-disciplinary contexts.

structure.tutorials_discussions: 2 hours per week, focusing on control design concepts.
structure.project_sessions: 2 hours per week for hands-on project work on industrial process models.
structure.seminar: A seminar to demonstrate the project work.
structure.pre-study: Students must conduct pre-study of relevant content before class tutorials.

projects.approach: Students follow the usual industrial sequence: calibrate transducers and actuators, conduct dynamic response testing, model verification, and controller design and implementation.

assessment_task_1.title: Oral Presentation of Project
assessment_task_1.intent: Present project outcomes, focusing on design and implementation.

assessment_task_2.title: Demonstration of Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrate the practical implementation of the project design.

assessment_task_3.title: Individual Major Project Report
assessment_task_3.intent: Provide a detailed report on the project work, including modelling, design, and implementation.

assessment_task_4.title: Assignments (containing 4 assignments)
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess understanding of system modelling and controller design.

assessment_task_5.title: Open Book Exam
assessment_task_5.intent: Evaluate students' understanding of the subject.

48560 Control Studio A.minimum_requirements: To pass, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48582 Power Systems Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48582 Power Systems Studio A.recommended_studies: Power circuit theory knowledge is essential for this subject.
48582 Power Systems Studio A.description: The primary objective of this subject is the development of a working knowledge of power systems analysis and design. Detailed topics include synchronous machines, fault analysis, power system stability, load flow analysis, transmission line performance, and mechanical design of transmission lines. Students engage in hands-on experimental learning through the completion of a design project, working collaboratively in studios with peers, academic staff, and industry mentors.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model power system components and predict their operation in their steady and transient states.
2. Perform basic design and analysis for power systems in different scenarios.
3. Apply theoretical concepts to practical situations according to industries' needs.
4. Use computer packages to solve a variety of problems in the power systems field.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify, engage, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, establish priorities, and define system requirements.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes.
D.1: Apply abstraction, mathematics and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
E.1: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating across cross-disciplinary contexts.
F.1: Critically self-review performance to improve themselves, their teams, and society.

studio_environment.method: Agile methodology, including weekly sprints and scrums for peer and tutor feedback.
tasks: Assess, design, and implement the project.
Collaboration with peers, academic staff, and industry mentors.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.online_modules: Short educational modules provide foundational knowledge in power system components and analysis.

labs.method: Laboratory sessions are structured to reinforce theory with practical tasks.
labs.requirements: Pre-lab work must be completed before each session, with strict adherence to safety protocols.

content_topics: Synchronous machine model: equivalent circuit, two-axis model, transient analysis.
Power system stability: Swing equation, steady state stability, multi-machine systems.
Active and reactive power control: Automatic generation control (AGC), tie-line frequency bias control.
Load Flow Analysis: Newton-Raphson method, fast decoupled load flow.
Transmission Line Performance: Power transfer capacity, thermal limit, stability limit, line reactive compensation.
Mechanical design of transmission lines: Catenary curve equation, sag, tension, wind and ice loading.
Substation fundamentals and design: Substation classifications, layout, equipment, earthing, and insulation coordination.

assessment_task_1.title: Individual Learning Contract Agreement
assessment_task_1.intent: To establish a self-learning plan for power systems analysis and design.

assessment_task_2.title: Individual Learning Contract Finalisation
assessment_task_2.intent: To demonstrate completion of the self-learning plan.

assessment_task_3.title: Team Product/Prototype Proposal
assessment_task_3.intent: To design and plan the development of a power systems product or prototype.

assessment_task_4.title: Team Product/Prototype Delivery 1
assessment_task_4.intent: To demonstrate significant progress towards product/prototype development.

assessment_task_5.title: Team Product/Prototype Delivery 2
assessment_task_5.intent: To deliver the final product or prototype and summarise the design process.

48582 Power Systems Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48561 Renewable Energy Systems Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48561 Renewable Energy Systems Studio A.recommended_studies: Knowledge and skills of design, numerical and circuitry simulation, and construction; testing of electronic circuits.
48561 Renewable Energy Systems Studio A.description: Power electronics is an enabling technology that manages and converts electric power from one form and level to another. Applications include motor drives, renewable energy systems, battery chargers, energy storage systems, data centres, UPS, and HVDC. The objectives of this studio are to enable students to evaluate and design power electronic circuits and apply them to motor drive applications. Students also address issues such as the impact of these systems on utility supply and environmental considerations.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse the impact of power electronic and drive systems on utility supply and environment.
2. Develop power electronic circuits according to customised specifications and industry standards.
3. Analyse, design, implement and test power electronic devices, circuits, and systems using appropriate mathematical models, simulation tools, and datasheets.
4. Demonstrate design approach to problem solving using communication and collaboration between various people.
5. Reflect on challenges and achievements to identify future learning needs.

studio_based_learning.method: Studio and laboratory sessions leading to project development.
studio_based_learning.approach: Teams design and develop power electronics applications, guided by tutors.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.online_resources: Students access online videos, quizzes, and tutorials for foundational knowledge.
teaching_and_learning_strategies.weekly_feedback: Tutors provide weekly feedback and guidance during studio sessions.

content_topics: DC/DC power converters (buck, boost, buck-boost, full-bridge converters)
Voltage and current harmonics of rectifiers and inverters

assessment_task_1.title: Design and Reflection Journal
assessment_task_1.intent: To develop a practical engineering habit of journaling ideas, discussions, and results.

assessment_task_2.title: Team Prototype Proposal
assessment_task_2.intent: To design and plan the development of a power electronics application.

assessment_task_3.title: Team Prototype Delivery 1
assessment_task_3.intent: To demonstrate significant progress towards delivering the prototype.

assessment_task_4.title: Team Prototype Delivery 2
assessment_task_4.intent: To deliver the final prototype and summarize the design process.

48561 Renewable Energy Systems Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic digital systems and microprocessor/computer architecture is essential for this subject.
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.description: This subject focuses on the analysis, design, and implementation of an advanced computing node. It provides an in-depth understanding of digital hardware design at the medium scale computer system building block level. Students will engage in computer-aided design using VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable VLSI implementation technologies, and will explore topics such as digital design processes, functional design, advanced digital architectures, and memory and I/O systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse, design, and implement a programmable digital system based on a user requirement specification, and investigate advanced digital systems architectures.
2. Demonstrate in-depth understanding of the analysis, design, and implementation of advanced digital hardware at the medium scale computer system building block level.
3. Utilise computer-aided design, including the use of VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable FPGA implementation technologies, Register transfer level, Data path and control units.

problem_based_learning.method: Weekly lectures, tutorials, and laboratory assignments, focusing on developing solutions to complex design challenges.
problem_based_learning.approach: A series of staged laboratory tasks allows students to build up a complete system, culminating in a framework used for the final assignment.

student_support.preparation: Students are required to study notes, readings, and prepare questions prior to teaching activities.
student_support.collaboration: In labs, students work in groups of 2, engaging in collaborative discussions facilitated by academic staff.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.feedback: Academic staff provide immediate feedback during lectures, tutorials, and labs, with assignment demonstrations and one-on-one consultations for specific tasks.

content_topics: Review of basic digital techniques and their application to the design of state machines used in control units
Digital hardware design process and Programmable Logic

assessment_task_1.title: Assignments
assessment_task_1.intent: To gain practical experience in hardware design through design, simulation, and implementation of an application-specific digital system in hardware (FPGA or CPLD).
assessment_task_1.criteria: Assessment criteria will be published with each assignment's requirements.

assessment_task_2.title: Class Quizzes
assessment_task_2.intent: To test students' knowledge of digital systems, RTL, and VHDL language, as well as their ability to code for PLD and FPGA systems.
assessment_task_2.length: Each quiz will take up to two hours
assessment_task_2.criteria: Criteria will be included in the quiz paper.

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48580 Control Studio B.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48580 Control Studio B.recommended_studies: Previous study of simple control systems using transfer functions and state-variables is essential.
48580 Control Studio B.description: This subject focuses on advanced control engineering design for multivariable systems. Students will learn to model, simulate, and design control systems for complex and nonlinear systems. The studio provides a practice-based environment for students to work on real-world control systems, focusing on theory, simulation, design, and practical validation. Teams will develop autonomous multivariable control systems using advanced control techniques, with an emphasis on teamwork and reflection.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Mathematically model, simulate, and analyse multivariable (not necessarily linear) systems for control purposes.
2. Propose, design, and validate advanced control strategies to create a multivariable autonomous control system conforming to given specifications.
3. Identify model uncertainties and/or disturbances that can affect control system performance to enhance robustness.
4. Translate theoretical advanced control designs into control algorithms for practical implementation.
content_topics: Modelling and simulation of multivariable systems
System model identification of multivariable systems
Multivariable nonlinear stability analysis in the Lyapunov sense
Optimal control and filtering of multivariable systems

assessment_task_1.title: Project requirements and solution design rationale
assessment_task_1.intent: To demonstrate understanding of control system requirements and propose a feasible solution design.

assessment_task_2.title: Interim project demonstration
assessment_task_2.intent: To demonstrate knowledge of state feedback control of multivariable systems, including modelling, analysis, control design, and simulation.

assessment_task_3.title: Final project demonstration
assessment_task_3.intent: To demonstrate practical skills in implementing advanced control strategies and evaluating system performance.

assessment_task_4.title: Final project report
assessment_task_4.intent: To demonstrate understanding of the challenges, requirements, and methods used in designing autonomous advanced control systems.

assessment_task_5.title: Assignments
assessment_task_5.intent: To demonstrate theoretical knowledge of advanced control systems design.

48580 Control Studio B.minimum_requirements: To pass this subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or greater.

48583 Power Systems Studio B.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48583 Power Systems Studio B.recommended_studies: Power circuit theory knowledge is essential; understanding of complex numbers, power circuit analysis, fault calculations, fundamentals of electrical machines, and MATLAB programming.
48583 Power Systems Studio B.description: This subject focuses on the working knowledge of power systems operation and protection. Students will learn about the National Electricity Market (NEM), demand-side management, load forecasting, transmission and distribution network protection, communication systems, and design standards for instrument transformers.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify elements of the supply chain and how they function in the National Electricity Market.
2. Explain demand-side management options including smart meters.
3. Recognize load forecasting and optimal load scheduling for secure energy supply and use.
4. Design protection schemes for transmission and distribution networks.
5. Explain communications in power systems, including communication media, architectures, automation, standards, protocols, and security.
6. Illustrate basic design, connection, and standards of current and voltage instrument transformers for protection and metering applications.
content_topics: Electricity Supply Chain Fundamentals, Demand-Side Management, and Load Forecasting
Protection of Transmission and Distribution Networks
Instrument transformers: Current transformers, Potential transformers, Transient behaviour of CTs, Vector diagrams
Protective relays: Classification of relays, Microprocessor-based relays, Distance relays
Protection of generators and transformers: Differential protection, Harmonic blocking
Protection of transmission lines: Overcurrent protection, Distance protection, Differential pilot wire protection
Circuit breakers: Arc phenomena, Recovery rate theory, Air blast circuit breakers, SF6 circuit breaker
Power system planning: Load forecasting, Economic operation of power system, Power output control
Operation and control of power systems: SCADA/EMS, Dynamic security assessment, State estimation
Power markets: Electricity market characteristics, Spot marketing, Security of power system operation

assessment_task_1.title: Power system labs - 3 experiments
assessment_task_1.intent: To assess practical understanding of power system elements and protection schemes.

assessment_task_2.title: Power system software lab - 1 experiment
assessment_task_2.intent: To assess the ability to model power systems using software tools.

assessment_task_3.title: Assignment
assessment_task_3.intent: To evaluate the theoretical understanding of power system operation, protection, and communication.

assessment_task_4.title: Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: To test comprehensive understanding of power system protection and transformer design.

48583 Power Systems Studio B.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48550 Renewable Energy Systems Studio B.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48550 Renewable Energy Systems Studio B.description: This subject introduces students to contemporary renewable energy technologies and design techniques, focusing on sustainability, environmental issues, energy resources, and power generation from renewable sources such as solar, wind, and fuel cells. Students gain hands-on experience through a group project, focusing on system design, analysis, and implementation.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply contemporary renewable energy technologies to design generating and storage systems.
2. Design a renewable energy system with considerations of technical, sustainability, and environmental issues.
3. Calculate, design, and apply circuit and energy analysis techniques to practical problems and projects.
4. Write technical and professional engineering reports skilfully through design projects that include research, theory deployment, and system calculation and simulation.
5. Clearly present work to an audience using appropriate audiovisual tools.
content_topics: Sustainability and environmental issues related to energy
Energy resources and renewable electrical power generation
Energy storage techniques (batteries, supercapacitors, SMES, compressed air)
Stand-alone and grid-connected renewable power systems
Electrical performance, power quality, protection, and power plant economy

assessment_task_1.title: Group Project
assessment_task_1.intent: To design a renewable energy or energy utilization system, including research, design, simulation, hardware implementation, and reporting.

assessment_task_2.title: Final Examination
assessment_task_2.intent: To assess students' understanding of renewable energy concepts and their problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_3.title: Individual Assignments
assessment_task_3.intent: To conduct a case study on a specific aspect of renewable energy, interpreting raw data and writing a detailed report.

48550 Renewable Energy Systems Studio B.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48570 Embedded Systems Studio B.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48570 Embedded Systems Studio B.description: This subject offers students the opportunity to design, build, and evaluate embedded systems based on a microcontroller. Students develop an embedded system from concept to final product, working through weekly milestones and identifying learning needs as they progress.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse requirements for embedded systems development.
2. Evaluate modular components such as microcontrollers, sensors, and actuators using datasheets to inform technology choices.
3. Design, implement, and test an embedded system to meet user requirements.
4. Reflect on technology choices, collaboration, challenges, and achievements to improve design choices.
content_topics: Embedded software toolchains and development environments
Embedded and cloud processing for device actions
Visualisation of collected data to provide insights and evaluations

assessment_task_1.title: Individual Learning Contract
assessment_task_1.intent: To provide an opportunity for guided self-learning of topics related to embedded systems.

assessment_task_2.title: Embedded Systems Project
assessment_task_2.intent: To demonstrate the ability to design, implement, test, and evaluate a product based on an embedded system.

assessment_task_3.title: Final Report
assessment_task_3.intent: To demonstrate professional written and oral communication skills in documenting and describing an embedded systems product.

length.presentation: 10 minutes presentation, followed by a Q&A session

48570 Embedded Systems Studio B.minimum_requirements: To pass this subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or greater.

49274 Advanced Robotics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

pre_requisites: 120 credit points in Bachelor of Engineering or equivalent programs
48430 Fundamentals of C Programming OR 48623 Mechatronics 2

49274 Advanced Robotics.description: This subject provides an overview of mobile robotics technologies, covering sensing, mapping, navigation, and control. The focus is on developing essential skills for designing robotic systems for practical applications through lectures, case studies, and laboratory assignments.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Simulate and implement algorithms for mobile robots
2. Plan time, manage work, and be an active team member in group projects
3. Analyse problems in mobile robot applications and propose appropriate engineering solutions
4. Illustrate detailed knowledge of the software and hardware architecture through programming and design of a modern robotic system
5. Demonstrate knowledge of sensors, actuators, and control techniques through robotic applications
6. Prototype advanced robotic systems
content_topics: Robot fundamentals and practical systems case studies
Sensing, control, data fusion, localisation, and path planning
System design with practical demonstrations using iRobot iCreate, Pioneer, HOMER, and Fetch
Group project: design and development of complex robotics systems

assessment_task_1.title: Localization of a Mobile Robot using Particle Filter
assessment_task_1.intent: Assess understanding of mobile robot localization through particle filter implementation.

assessment_task_2.title: Plan a Path for a Mobile Robot
assessment_task_2.intent: Evaluate students' ability to plan paths for robots.

assessment_task_3.title: Project Demonstration
assessment_task_3.intent: Demonstrate practical skills in advanced robotics system development.

assessment_task_4.title: Project Documentation
assessment_task_4.intent: Evaluate the students' ability to document and report on the project.

assessment_task_5.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_5.intent: Test students' understanding of advanced robotics concepts and their practical applications.

49274 Advanced Robotics.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48434 Embedded Software.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48434 Embedded Software.description: This subject focuses on the design, implementation, and testing of software modules for embedded systems. Students work in teams to develop software, interpret specifications, and test applications for embedded systems using hardware abstraction layers and data structures. A project-based approach enables students to design embedded systems software and gain debugging skills.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, write, and test various software modules such as hardware abstraction layers, data structures, and interrupt service routines.
2. Design, write, and test an embedded application that is modular, hierarchical, and meets real-time constraints.
3. Use various software tools to write, execute, and test embedded software applications.
4. Test software performance in embedded systems using appropriate laboratory equipment.
5. Research and evaluate knowledge from various sources.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop skills in handling microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupts, and interfacing.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz
assessment_task_2.intent: Test knowledge in microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupt handling, and interfacing.

assessment_task_3.title: Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Design, implement, and test a complete embedded system.

48434 Embedded Software.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48571 Electrical Machines.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

requisites.recommended_studies: Advanced physics, calculus, circuit theory, and machine principles are essential.

48571 Electrical Machines.description: This subject introduces modern electrical machines and drives, covering electrical machine technology, power electronic converters, transformers, DC machines, synchronous machines, induction machines, and switched reluctance machines. Issues like variable speed drives and energy efficiency are addressed. Students participate in lectures, tutorials, labs, and assignments that focus on practical measurement and numerical simulation of drive systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify, interpret, and analyze stakeholder needs of electrical machines and drive systems and their socio-economic role.
2. Practice sound judgment and resource management in the lab and assignments.
3. Apply technical expertise to solve electrical machine and drive system problems.
4. Follow new technological developments in electrical machines and drives.
5. Develop technical writing and presentation skills through lab work and assignments.
6. Be aware of global perspectives and specifications related to electrical machines.
content_topics: MATLAB/Simulink models of power electronic converters

assessment_task_1.title: Laboratories
assessment_task_1.intent: Verify electrical machine theory and practice measurement of electrical machine parameters and performance.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignments
assessment_task_2.intent: Strengthen concepts of electrical drives and improve understanding of motor control strategies.

assessment_task_3.title: Quiz
assessment_task_3.intent: Examine understanding of fundamental concepts of electrical machines and drive systems.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Examination
assessment_task_4.intent: Examine understanding of concepts, knowledge, and problem-solving skills related to electrical machines and drives.

48571 Electrical Machines.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48572 Power Circuit Theory.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

requisites.recommended_studies: Understanding of electric circuit theory, differential equations, complex numbers, AC circuit analysis, MATLAB programming, and fundamentals of electrical machines.

48572 Power Circuit Theory.description: This subject introduces basic methods for analyzing and designing electric power networks. It builds on prior circuit analysis concepts to develop knowledge of power system theory and practice, covering steady-state, transient, and faulted conditions in power systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply models in power system apparatus for system modeling and analysis.
2. Develop techniques for analyzing power systems in steady-state, transient, and faulted conditions.
3. Apply technical terms and notations used in the power system industry.
4. Use modern computer tools for power system analysis.
5. Utilize specialized laboratory equipment to test power system parameters and behaviors.
6. Convey technical information in a written form relevant to the industry.
7. Manage knowledge independently from beyond the classroom.
content_topics: Equivalent circuits of power lines and cables
Per unit system, power flow, and load modeling

assessment_task_1.title: Labs 1-3
assessment_task_1.intent: Test skill and understanding of complex laboratory apparatus and verify theoretical predictions of power system behavior.

assessment_task_2.title: Quizzes
assessment_task_2.intent: Provide opportunities to demonstrate knowledge and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_3.title: Exam
assessment_task_3.intent: Test knowledge of power system components, steady-state behavior, and fault calculations.

assessment_task_4.title: Assignment
assessment_task_4.intent: Test the application of theoretical knowledge to real-world power system scenarios.

48572 Power Circuit Theory.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41088 Professional Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

pre_requisites: (48240 Design and Innovation Fundamentals AND 48260c Engineering Project Management)

41088 Professional Studio A.description: This studio subject provides students with the opportunity to apply their knowledge in product development and problem solving. It is the first of two professional studios in the Data and Electronic Engineering majors. Students will engage in individual self-directed study and team-based project work to assess, design, and implement a product.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Define the requirements of a product in conjunction with stakeholders.
2. Demonstrate a systematic design and thinking process for product development or problem-solving.
3. Model, prototype, and/or build a product according to specifications.
4. Work effectively in a team to develop a complex product or solve problems.
5. Demonstrate continuous improvement and independence in a team environment.

assessment_task_1.title: Individual Learning Agreement
assessment_task_1.intent: Allows students to document their learning direction and set session goals.

assessment_task_2.title: Individual Learning Contract Completion
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrates that students have achieved their goals set in the learning contract.
assessment_task_2.length: Strictly limited to 8 pages of text, diagrams, and tables (3000 to 6000 words).

assessment_task_3.title: Team Project Plan and Product/Prototype Requirement Specifications
assessment_task_3.intent: Negotiate scope and outcomes with stakeholders, and develop a requirements document and project plan.

assessment_task_4.title: Team Product/Prototype Delivery
assessment_task_4.intent: Demonstrate ability to deliver a product or prototype, solve problems, create solutions, and manage tasks.

41088 Professional Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41089 Professional Studio B.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41089 Professional Studio B.description: This studio subject allows students to apply their knowledge in product development and problem-solving through individual study and team-based project work. Students assess, design, and implement products using a structured engineering approach, guided by academic staff and industry mentors.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Define the requirements of a product in conjunction with stakeholders.
2. Demonstrate a systematic design and thinking process for product development or problem-solving.
3. Model, prototype, and/or build a product according to specifications.
4. Work effectively in a team to develop a complex product or solve problems.
5. Demonstrate continuous improvement and independence in a team environment.

assessment_task_1.title: Individual Learning Agreement
assessment_task_1.intent: Allows students to document their learning direction and set session goals.

assessment_task_2.title: Individual Learning Contract Completion
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrates that students have achieved their goals set in the learning contract.
assessment_task_2.length: Strictly limited to 8 pages of text, diagrams, and tables (3000 to 6000 words).

assessment_task_3.title: Team Project Plan and Product/Prototype Requirement Specifications
assessment_task_3.intent: Negotiate scope and outcomes with stakeholders, and develop a requirements document and project plan.

assessment_task_4.title: Team Product/Prototype Delivery
assessment_task_4.intent: Demonstrate ability to deliver a product or prototype, solve problems, create solutions, and manage tasks.

41089 Professional Studio B.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mec.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mec.description: This subject introduces students to engineering sketching and drawing, CAD solid modelling, engineering mechanics, mechanical systems, and components. Students learn to graphically represent mechanical components using standard techniques, apply engineering mechanics, and build mechanical systems through a design process.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Communicate details of simple mechanical components and devices using freehand sketching, drawing instruments, and CAD software.
2. Create computer models of mechanical components using CAD solid modelling software.
3. Apply engineering mechanics to analyze simple machines, mechanisms, and structures.
4. Use an engineering design process to design and build mechanical devices.
5. Acquire, process, and interpret mechanical system data to improve performance.
6. Document and communicate design ideas, decisions, calculations, and outcomes.
content_topics: Motion and power transmission, energy conversion

assessment_task_1.title: Engineering Drawing Assignment
assessment_task_1.intent: Demonstrate competence in engineering drawing and sketching.
assessment_task_1.length: A set of engineering drawings including: parallel oblique projection, isometric, orthogonal, and section views.

assessment_task_2.title: Computer-Aided Design (CAD) Assignment
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrate competence in CAD solid modelling.

assessment_task_3.title: Engineering Mechanics Quiz - Moment Equilibrium
assessment_task_3.intent: Demonstrate mastery of basic engineering mechanics.

assessment_task_4.title: Engineering Functional Prototyping Project
assessment_task_4.intent: Demonstrate application of engineering mechanics and design in building a functional prototype.

assessment_task_5.title: Weekly Recap Quizzes
assessment_task_5.intent: Allow students to self-reflect on learning progress and provide an overview of general progress to teaching staff.

48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mec.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Enginee.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

prerequisites: 48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
requisites.recommended_studies: Knowledge of equilibrium of particles and solving a system of linear algebraic equations is essential.

48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Enginee.description: This subject builds on the concepts introduced in prior subjects and provides a comprehensive overview of elementary mechanics. It lays the foundation for future subjects such as Machine Dynamics and Mechanics of Solids, focusing on Newtonian mechanics through topics like force vectors, equilibrium, friction, kinematics, and more.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply Newtonian mechanics, a fundamental science underlying engineering practice.
2. Draw Free-Body Diagrams, evaluate force systems, and understand the modelling concept.
3. Apply principles of particle mechanics and understand its limitations.
4. Use basic engineering concepts such as equilibrium, force, acceleration, work, energy, power, impulse, and momentum.
5. Apply analytical skills in statics, dynamics, and mechanics.
6. Apply Free-Body Diagrams, structural analysis, dry friction, kinematics, and other mechanics principles.
content_topics: Force vectors and force system resultants
Equilibrium of rigid bodies in 2D and 3D
Pin-connected trusses, Method of Joints, and Method of Sections
Shear force and bending moment diagrams
Kinematics of a particle, rectilinear and curvilinear motion
Kinetics of a particle, Newton's Second Law of Motion
Principle of work and energy, conservation of energy
Principle of linear impulse and momentum

assessment_task_1.title: Five Remote (Online) Quizzes
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop and test understanding of Newtonian mechanics, Free-Body Diagrams, and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_2.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess understanding of elementary mechanics (statics, mechanics of materials, and dynamics) and lay the foundation for further study.

48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Enginee.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48621 Manufacturing Engineering.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

prerequisites: 48610 Introduction to Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
requisites.recommended_studies: Students should review knowledge from chemistry and physics, focusing on fundamentals of materials, mechanics, and electrics. It is suggested to study Chapters 1-4 in the required textbook before Week 1 for understanding materials related to manufacturing.

48621 Manufacturing Engineering.description: This subject explains the principles of modern manufacturing, covering processes like casting, forming, machining, and joining of materials. Students will learn to identify the manufacturing processes for products made of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Additionally, they will enhance their technical writing and problem-solving skills related to manufacturing and production processes.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain and provide examples of manufacturing processes involved in casting, forming, machining, and joining of materials.
2. Identify and describe the manufacturing process for products made of different materials.
3. Demonstrate improved technical written and graphical communication skills through specified laboratory and site visit reports.
4. Apply basic problem-solving skills related to manufacturing and production.
5. Evaluate processes and materials available, recognizing connections between them and engineering design.
6. Explain social issues like material and energy resources and environmental protection.
content_topics: Manufacturing processes: casting, forming, machining, and joining
Evaluation of processes for different materials: metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites
Technical communication through project and lab reports
Social issues: material and energy resources, environmental impact

assessment_task_1.title: Minor Project
assessment_task_1.intent: Help students understand the relevance of manufacturing to engineering, identify various manufacturing processes, and justify process choices.
assessment_task_1.criteria: Marking criteria for project reports are available on UTSOnline.

assessment_task_2.title: Major Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Familiarize students with the manufacture and assembly of a complex engineering subsystem involving volume production.
assessment_task_2.criteria: Marking criteria for project reports are available on UTSOnline.

assessment_task_3.title: Practical Handwork Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Enable students to practice basic manufacturing processes by fabricating simple products.
assessment_task_3.criteria: Marking criteria for project reports are available on UTSOnline.

assessment_task_4.title: Metrology
assessment_task_4.intent: Help students understand fundamental principles of measurement, calibration, and the relevance of standards in manufacturing.

48621 Manufacturing Engineering.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48600 Mechanical Design 1.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48600 Mechanical Design 1.description: This subject is the first in a set of three engineering design subjects. It covers the mechanical design process, graphical presentation of engineering ideas and components, CAD, engineering materials and processes, and aspects of engineering knowledge. A major two-phase design-and-build project is a key component.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Use CAD solid modelling software to create part and assembly models and generate detailed and pictorial drawings of engineering components.
2. Apply the concept of design intent when creating CAD solid and assembly models.
3. Apply the principles of geometric dimensioning and tolerancing.
4. Apply the principles of mechanism analysis and design.
5. Apply good mechanical design practice to design and build a mechanical device.
6. Apply mechatronics principles to develop a mechatronic system to control a mechanical device.
7. Communicate and document design ideas, decisions, justifications, calculations, and outcomes effectively.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
content_topics: Mechanical systems and components (e.g., bearings, cams, springs)
Structural details for strength and stiffness

assessment_task_1.title: Computer Aided Design (CAD)
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop and demonstrate CAD skills using solid modelling software to create parts, assemblies, and generate drawings to Australian Standard AS1100.
assessment_task_1.length: Calculations and drawing production of designed components and assemblies.

assessment_task_2.title: Design and Build Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Work in teams to apply mechanical and mechatronic design principles to build a mechanical device, meeting performance criteria and specifications.

48600 Mechanical Design 1.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48640 Machine Dynamics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

recommended_studies: Understanding of mathematics, especially trigonometry, differential and integral calculus, and vectors
Review of 48620 Fundamentals of Mechanical Engineering

48640 Machine Dynamics.description: This subject introduces the kinematics and dynamics of rigid bodies in planar motion and vibration of mechanical systems. Students will learn to model rigid body kinematics, apply Newtonian mechanics, and analyze vibrations in single-degree-of-freedom mechanical systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Illustrate basic mechanics concepts such as rigid body, force, motion, work, energy, power, impulse and momentum, and the relationships between them.
2. Break down a simple machine or a mechanical system into a series of rigid bodies and evaluate the kinematics and kinetics between them.

3. Apply velocity and acceleration equations of a rigid body in planar motion for determining its motion status, including angular velocity and acceleration, and linear velocity and acceleration of its any given points.

4. Explain Newtonian mechanics, the relationships between the forces/moments and accelerations of a rigid body in planar motion; the velocities and work, & energies of a rigid body, or rigid bodies; and the relationships between linear/angular momentums and impulses.

5. Apply the above kinematics and kinetics theories to model and quantify the various physical processes such as a rigid body’s dynamic states at each instant in relation to external forces, the state changes between two instants, and impact problems between rigid bodies.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
content_topics: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies in planar motion
Kinetics of rigid bodies using Newton’s 2nd law, work and energy, and momentum equations
Introduction to free vibration of a single degree of freedom mechanical system

assessment_task_1.title: Kinematics of Rigid Body - Velocity Equations
assessment_task_1.intent: Understand how to conduct velocity analysis in planar rigid body dynamics.

assessment_task_2.title: Kinematics of Rigid Body - Acceleration Equations
assessment_task_2.intent: Understand how to conduct acceleration analysis in planar rigid body dynamics.

assessment_task_3.title: Kinetic Equation of Motion
assessment_task_3.intent: Use kinetic equation of motion to solve problems of translation or rotation about a fixed axis in planar rigid body dynamics.

assessment_task_4.title: Work and Energy Equations & Linear and Angular Momentum Equations
assessment_task_4.intent: Use work and energy, impulse and momentum methods to solve problems in planar rigid body dynamics.

assessment_task_5.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_5.intent: Test understanding of the fundamental methods and ability to solve problems in planar rigid body dynamics.

48640 Machine Dynamics.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48642 Strength of Engineering Materials.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

recommended_studies: Knowledge of mechanics of solids including stress formulas and moment of inertia

48642 Strength of Engineering Materials.description: This subject builds upon concepts from earlier subjects such as mechanics of solids, chemistry, and materials science. It focuses on the mechanical behavior of materials, failure modes, stress analysis, and the practical aspects of mechanical design. Students will learn to apply stress analysis, material selection, and failure predictions to mechanical design problems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Describe the mechanical design process as it applies to machine elements.
2. Describe how and why structures and machine components fail.
3. Determine the stress and strain in a machine component.
4. Realise the importance of stress analysis and material selection in machine element design.
5. Predict, or design to avoid, failure given the material, environment and loading conditions.
6. Use analytical skills in stress analysis and knowledge of material properties in mechanical design.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
content_topics: Material behaviour: Properties, selection, strain analysis, deformation, strain energy methods
Stress analysis: Normal and shear stress, combined stress, impact, stress in structures and machine components
Failure modes: Theories/criteria for yield, fracture, fatigue

assessment_task_1.title: Problem Solving Tasks
assessment_task_1.intent: Evaluate the ability to perform stress analysis, shaft design, fatigue and failure analysis, strain energy, and impact loading.

assessment_task_2.title: Lab Work & Reports
assessment_task_2.intent: Develop the ability to interpret and analyze data related to mechanical properties of materials and communicate effectively through lab reports.

48642 Strength of Engineering Materials.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48650 Mechanical Design 2.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

recommended_studies: 48331 Mechanics of Solids

48650 Mechanical Design 2.description: This subject extends the concepts from earlier subjects and provides a link between engineering science and practice, focusing on technical aspects of mechanical design. It emphasizes engineering analysis and technical decision-making to tackle real-world design challenges.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply engineering knowledge and science in real-world practice.
2. Extend beyond technical basics and appreciate design choices in an engineering context.
3. Confidently apply professional background to identify areas requiring attention.
4. Critique the engineering work of peers and improve it.
5. Conduct relevant technical analysis to back recommendations.
6. Communicate and document design ideas, decisions, justifications, calculations, and outcomes effectively.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
content_topics: Elements: Gears, frictional devices, brakes, clutches, shafts, bearings, lubrication, springs

assessment_task_1.title: Quizzes x5
assessment_task_1.intent: Assess students' understanding of fundamental concepts through short questions/calculations.
assessment_task_1.criteria: The quizzes will cover material from lectures and tutorials and probe the engineering analysis, design choices, and approach.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignments x2
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess students' ability to identify and conduct relevant engineering analysis and make appropriate technical design decisions.
assessment_task_2.criteria: Assignment 1 critiques the 'Junior Engineer's Design Proposal,' while Assignment 2 includes component analysis exercises and a practical design task.

48650 Mechanical Design 2.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48651 Thermodynamics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48651 Thermodynamics.description: This subject provides a fundamental understanding of applied thermodynamics from an engineering perspective. Topics include thermodynamic properties of substances, work and heat, the first and second laws of thermodynamics, power cycles, and practical applications such as steam engines, refrigeration cycles, and gas turbine engines.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Determine the thermodynamic properties of pure substances.
2. Apply the first and second laws of thermodynamics in an engineering context.
3. Recognize the differences between ideal and real processes, analyze power cycles, and determine thermal efficiency.
4. Formulate basic models to analyze and design thermal systems, and understand methods to increase thermal efficiency.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
content_topics: The first law of thermodynamics and applications
The second law of thermodynamics and applications
Thermodynamic power cycles for engines and refrigerators

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz 1 (Thermodynamic properties, work transfer)
assessment_task_1.intent: To understand basic thermodynamic properties and apply knowledge to thermodynamic work transfer.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz 2 (The first law of thermodynamics)
assessment_task_2.intent: To apply the first law of thermodynamics to real-life engineering problems.

assessment_task_3.title: Laboratory report - Air Compressors
assessment_task_3.intent: To apply knowledge of the second law of thermodynamics and entropy to analyze the thermal behavior of a closed system.

assessment_task_4.title: Quiz 3 (The second law of thermodynamics, entropy)

48651 Thermodynamics.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48660 Dynamics and Control.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
recommended_studies: Engineering mechanics including statics and dynamics
Machine dynamics
48660 Dynamics and Control.description: This subject covers the behavior of linear dynamic systems typically encountered in mechanical engineering and how these systems can be controlled to achieve desired outcomes. Topics include dynamic models, Matlab and Simulink, feedback properties, PID control, and the root-locus design method.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Illustrate fundamental understanding of the behavior of linear dynamic systems in mechanical and mechatronic engineering.
2. Explain how real practical dynamic systems can be controlled for desired response.
3. Develop dynamic models of single and two degree-of-freedom systems and verify them in simulation or experiments.
4. Analyze dynamic system responses in simulations and experiments.
5. Comprehend feedback properties and design controllers for mechanical and mechatronic systems.
6. Recognize differences between ideal/simulated and real system responses.
7. Understand and implement control systems.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1. Pre-class and post-class materials such as textbooks, videos, lecture notes, and self-assessment questions will be available online.
2. Lectures and tutorials will focus on applying principles and theories to solve practical problems with student participation and discussion.
3. Labs will provide hands-on experience with dynamic systems and control.
4. Remotely accessible labs will allow students to conduct experiments remotely.
5. Students will complete two projects and one lab report on dynamic modeling, control design, and experimental analysis.
6. Online quizzes will assess students' progress and provide immediate feedback.
content_topics: Modelling and analyzing dynamics of single degree-of-freedom (DOF) systems

assessment_task_1.title: Project 1 - Part 1: Modelling of a practical dynamic system

assessment_task_2.title: Project 2: Modelling of a 2 DOF system, vibration analysis, and experimental verification

assessment_task_4.title: Project 1 - Parts 2 and 3: Design of controllers and experimental verification

48660 Dynamics and Control.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48663 Advanced Manufacturing.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48663 Advanced Manufacturing.description: This subject enables students to understand key aspects of modern manufacturing environments, including volume production, quality control, modern metrology, and computer-aided systems. Students gain hands-on experience with CAD/CAM for CNC machining, rapid prototyping, and industrial robotics.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify and explain the design and manufacturing process in various environments ranging from low to high volume.
2. Use quality management techniques to apply process quality control.
3. Apply modern metrology techniques to the manufacturing industry.
4. Demonstrate the use of CAD/CAM in manufacturing.
5. Apply the concepts of reverse engineering and rapid prototyping.
6. Investigate the viability of industrial robots in fabrication, welding, and assembly.
7. Apply contemporary manufacturing concepts such as Design for Manufacture (DFM) and Just in Time (JIT).
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1. Preparative work ('pre-work'), in-class activities, and post-class activities.
2. Lectures and laboratories covering quality management, metrology, CAD/CAM, CNC, 3D scanning, additive manufacturing, and industrial robots.
3. Practical lab sessions with modern manufacturing equipment.
4. Project-based learning where students design, fabricate, and troubleshoot manufacturing systems.
5. Group collaboration to simulate real-world engineering settings.
content_topics: Production planning: JIT, Kanban, group technology

assessment_task_1.title: G-Coding, CNC, CAD/CAM and Additive Manufacturing

48663 Advanced Manufacturing.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48601 Mechanical Vibration and Measureme.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
recommended_studies: Students are expected to have a well-established understanding of the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies.
Fundamental understanding of vibration of damped and undamped single degree of freedom systems and undamped two degree of freedom systems is also recommended.
48601 Mechanical Vibration and Measureme.description: This subject introduces advanced topics in vibration analysis and measurement with applications in real engineering problems. Students learn advanced methods for rigid and flexible body modeling, analysis of mechanical systems, and experimental approaches to data acquisition and signal processing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the concepts and dynamic modeling methods of multi-rigid body systems and flexible body systems.
2. Demonstrate proficiency in obtaining analytical and numerical solutions.
3. Apply skills in instrumentation, measurement, and signal processing through vibration testing.
4. Apply the learned vibration theory to solve engineering problems.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1. Online lectures, group learning tasks, and practical labs involving hands-on activities.
2. Computer laboratory activities using MATLAB®/Simulink for modeling and data interpretation.
3. Pre-class activities including video lectures, practice problems, and computer and lab pre-work.
4. Assessment via quizzes, lab reports, projects, and online assessments.
5. Feedback is provided through UTSOnline quizzes, tutorials, and lab sessions.
content_topics: Free and forced vibration of MDOF damped systems
Numerical methods such as transfer matrix method and finite element method
Sensors for displacement, velocity, and acceleration measurements
Signal processing: windowing, filtering, spectrum analysis
Introduction to acoustics, sensors, and instrument systems
Special topics: experimental modal analysis, structural health monitoring
Applications: torsional vibration, vehicle dynamics, vibration of tall buildings

assessment_task_1.title: Week 1 online assessment
assessment_task_1.intent: To confirm knowledge and understanding of prerequisite material.

assessment_task_2.title: Practical and remote laboratory sessions (two assessments)
assessment_task_2.intent: To establish comprehension of practical session activities and content.

assessment_task_3.title: In-class tests (two tests)
assessment_task_3.intent: To confirm ability to model simplified dynamic systems and solve equations.

assessment_task_4.title: Project 1: Modelling and experimental testing of half car test rig
assessment_task_4.intent: To assess ability to numerically model and experimentally validate a simplified dynamic system and work in a team.

assessment_task_5.title: Project 2: Modelling and experimental validation of multi-storey tower
assessment_task_5.intent: To assess ability to model, validate, and synthesize advanced configurations, and prepare a technical document.

48601 Mechanical Vibration and Measureme.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48661 Heat Transfer.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
recommended_studies: A good review of Fluid Mechanics is recommended.
48661 Heat Transfer.description: This subject provides grounding in key concepts and principles of heat transfer, including conduction, convection, and radiation. It covers the operation and design of machines associated with thermal energy such as heat exchangers, and emphasizes practical engineering applications.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify and explain the three modes of heat transfer: Conduction, convection, and radiation.
2. Apply knowledge for design and analysis of heat transfer systems.
3. Demonstrate teamwork and communication skills in various modes (written, oral).
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1. Lecture slides are available online before face-to-face class. Students are encouraged to review them beforehand.
2. Class time is used for facilitated learning, discussions, and feedback.
3. Tutorials focus on problem-solving and feedback on understanding.
4. Three quizzes are conducted throughout the session to provide timely feedback.
5. A lab session provides practical experience, supported by online lab notes.
content_topics: Design and analysis of compact and non-compact heat exchangers
48661 Heat Transfer.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48670 Mechanical and Mechatronic Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48670 Mechanical and Mechatronic Design.description: This subject aims to extend students' competence in designing engineered systems and components, while familiarizing them with modern design methodologies. Emphasis is placed on team/client interactions, need exploration, project development, and delivery.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Develop engineering solutions to real-world problems using design methodologies.
2. Engage with stakeholders to analyze and evaluate the needs of engineering solutions.
3. Formulate project specifications, including negotiated deliverables and evaluation criteria.
4. Critique engineering solutions and justify design decisions.
5. Shape the direction of an engineering project to achieve desired outcomes.
6. Develop communication media for stakeholders, engineering, and design contexts.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Project-based learning involving teamwork on an engineering project throughout the session.
Learning materials provided via UTSOnline in weekly modules.
Classes focus on collaborative activities such as exercises, group discussions, role-playing, and quizzes.
Design reviews at two stages to assess progress and provide feedback.
Peer reviews incorporated throughout the subject via progress reports and presentations.
Grades scaled individually using SPARK+.

assessment_task_1.title: Interview and Pitch
assessment_task_1.criteria: Marks are based on the ability to attract a project offer, professional presentation, and client engagement.

assessment_task_2.title: Progress Reports
assessment_task_2.criteria: Marks are awarded for effectiveness in reporting progress, recommendations, and short-term planning.

assessment_task_3.title: Design Review
assessment_task_3.criteria: Marks are awarded for translating project/client needs into specifications and evaluating potential solutions.

assessment_task_4.title: Poster Presentation
assessment_task_4.criteria: Marks are based on presenting project motivation, design process, outcomes, and recommendations.

assessment_task_5.title: Design Report
assessment_task_5.criteria: Marks awarded for justification of design choices and documentation of engineering solutions.

assessment_task_6.title: Client Delivery
assessment_task_6.criteria: Marks are awarded based on setting and delivering client deliverables, interaction, and client feedback.

48670 Mechanical and Mechatronic Design.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48622 Mechatronics 1.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

prerequisites: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering

recommended_studies: Basic knowledge in electrical engineering and programming
48622 Mechatronics 1.description: This subject enables students to master the fundamentals of digital and programmable electronic circuits and their engineering applications. It covers microcontrollers, low-level programming, and hardware interfacing design techniques.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain and apply the fundamentals of digital and programmable electronic circuits.
2. Explain and apply the fundamentals of microcontrollers.
3. Identify the principles of low-level programming and write simple embedded software.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Interactive lecture sessions with tutorials and practical work using hardware kits.
Students are expected to watch UTSOnline videos and complete practice quizzes before class.
Laboratory sessions to help students with practical assignments and embedded software development.
content: State diagram and its application in digital circuit design
Hardware integration with software at the machine level
Architecture of a typical register-based central processing unit
Computer system buses, input/output devices, interrupts

assessment_task_1.title: Assignment 1: FPGA Demonstration
assessment_task_1.intent: To demonstrate achieving functional requirements to solve a problem.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignment 2: MCU Programming Task
assessment_task_2.intent: To configure and program the MCU microcontroller to meet functional requirements.

assessment_task_3.title: Review Quizzes
assessment_task_3.intent: Gauge understanding of topics to inform projects.

48622 Mechatronics 1.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48623 Mechatronics 2.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
48623 Mechatronics 2.description: This subject builds on Mechatronics 1 and provides comprehensive hands-on experience in mechatronics system design, with concepts of sensing, actuation, control, and microprocessor-based system design demonstrated through robotics platforms.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Implement mechatronic solutions to a given specification.
2. Produce software solutions for a modern microprocessor-based mechatronic system.
3. Apply knowledge of control, sensors, and actuators to control a mechatronic system.
4. Demonstrate competence in developing advanced microprocessor-based mechatronic products.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Brief lectures followed by class activities.
Students are expected to review online materials before class and participate in collaborative group work and hands-on activities.
Guided learning with milestones and deliverables throughout the session.
content: Development and testing of prototype systems

assessment_task_1.title: C Programming Quiz
assessment_task_1.intent: Evaluate C language skills essential for the subject.

assessment_task_2.title: Actuation and Sensing
assessment_task_2.intent: Evaluate skills in interfacing sensors and actuators.

assessment_task_3.title: System Integration
assessment_task_3.intent: Evaluate skills in system integration.

assessment_task_4.title: Demonstration and Competition

assessment_task_6.intent: Assess deeper knowledge gained through lectures, labs, and projects.
