41012 Programming for Mechatronic System.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
41012 Programming for Mechatronic System.recommended_studies: Knowledge of the C language and digital systems is essential.
41012 Programming for Mechatronic System.description: This subject covers the theoretical foundations of object-oriented programming and design using C++. Students learn to design and implement code for mechatronics systems, with a focus on creating modular, reusable, reliable, and maintainable code.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design classes that are reusable, reliable, and maintainable.
2. Apply theoretical knowledge of sensors and control to practical programming problems.
3. Select appropriate class structures and data handling methods for specific tasks.
4. Implement and test object-oriented applications of moderate complexity.
5. Communicate programming design decisions, dependencies, interconnections, use cases, and testing procedures in a written document.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Brief interactive lectures followed by class activities such as collaborative discussions, problem solving, and hands-on coding tasks.
Students are expected to review online materials before class.
Peer code reviews to evaluate technical solutions.
content: Object-Oriented Paradigm: objects, classes, abstraction, inheritance, polymorphism
Initialization and memory handling: compile-time/runtime, heap, and stack
C++ STL containers and data structures
Robotics Operating System (ROS) and component-based software engineering
Tools for automation and documentation generation (CMake, Doxygen)

assessment_task_1.title: Developing Sensor Class
assessment_task_1.intent: Enhance skills in developing a sensor class using classes, functions, pointers, and macros.

assessment_task_2.title: Utilising Abstraction for Sensor Classes
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess skills in abstraction, encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism.

assessment_task_3.title: Threading, Synchronisation, and Data Integrity
assessment_task_3.intent: Evaluate threading, data synchronization, and documentation skills.

assessment_task_4.title: Individual Project
assessment_task_4.intent: Design, test, and evaluate code for sensor data analysis and robotic actions.

assessment_task_5.title: Review Quizzes
assessment_task_5.intent: Test knowledge of Object-Oriented Programming with C++.

41012 Programming for Mechatronic System.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41013 Robotics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering
41013 Robotics.description: This subject introduces students to industrial robotics, focusing on the mathematics, algorithms, and control systems used in robot manipulation. Students will work in teams to design and build simulated industrial robots, modeling robot arms and writing control software to perform motion tasks. Ethical considerations related to robotics, safety engineering, and the societal impacts of robots on the workforce are also addressed.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Describe mathematically and programmatically the relative position/orientation of robots and objects.
2. Describe which safety systems can be used in robotics and reflect on safety engineering.
3. Reflect on the role of robots, their future impact, and ethical implications.
4. Model robots in a workspace to enable collision detection and avoidance.
5. Describe, implement, and apply path planning techniques for industrial robots.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Learning through online lectures, interactive tutorials/labs, collaborative quizzes, and assignments.
In-class individual and group quizzes to assess understanding and promote collaborative learning.
Hands-on lab exercises, team projects, and reflective activities to apply robotics theory in practical settings.
content: Foundations of robotics: kinematics and dynamics for manipulator and mobile robots.
Motion planning: path and trajectory planning with collision detection/avoidance.
Industrial robotics safety and ethical considerations.

assessment_task_1.title: Review Quizzes
assessment_task_1.criteria: Four quizzes worth 5% each, based on pre-work, with multiple attempts allowed for reaching understanding benchmarks.

assessment_task_2.title: Lab Assignment 1
assessment_task_2.intent: Mathematical and programmatic description of robot joints and objects, Matlab coding, and reflection on robot advantages and disadvantages.

assessment_task_3.title: Lab Assignment 2
assessment_task_3.intent: Design, model, and demonstrate a robotic system performing a task in a specific environment with safety considerations.

assessment_task_4.title: Reflection on Societal Impact of Robotics and Robot/Environment Interaction Modeling
assessment_task_4.intent: Discussion on safety, societal impact of robots, and reflection on mathematical and programming skills learned.

41013 Robotics.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41014 Sensors and Control for Mechatroni.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering

recommended_studies.basic_knowledge: Basic knowledge of classical control techniques.

41014 Sensors and Control for Mechatroni.description: This subject aims to develop a theoretical and practical understanding of sensing, signal processing, and control techniques used in mechatronic systems. It includes active and passive sensors, feedback control, image processing, and state-space modeling. The subject emphasizes practical applications, with case studies exploring the use of sensors and control techniques in real-world engineering problems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Implement sensors and processing techniques and control strategies.
2. Apply knowledge of image processing and active sensor processing.
3. Apply knowledge of advanced control techniques.
4. Design sensors, signal processing, and control solutions to practical problems.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Online preparatory materials for in-class activities.
Practical tutorial problems to apply learned techniques.
Practical project problems to design integrated systems using sensors and control techniques.
Collaborative group work and active hands-on work.
content: Passive Sensors: Visual imaging and image processing, Infrared imaging.
Active Sensors: Operating principles, time of flight (TOF) measurement, sensor data processing, detection, and tracking.
State-space modeling of dynamic systems: linear continuous-time model, linear discrete-time model.
Control system design: Lyapunov stability, controllability, observability, stabilization, pole assignment.
Linear optimal control: linear quadratic control, observer design.

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz 1
assessment_task_1.intent: To assess competence in image processing techniques.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz 2
assessment_task_2.intent: To assess competence in sensors, sensor processing, and control techniques.

assessment_task_3.title: Project
assessment_task_3.intent: For students to apply sensing and control strategies to achieve an integrated solution to given specifications in a robotics system.

assessment_task_4.title: Timed Take Home Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: To assess deeper knowledge gained through lectures, lab classes, and projects.

41014 Sensors and Control for Mechatroni.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41082 Introduction to Data Engineering.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41082 Introduction to Data Engineering.description: This subject introduces students to the foundations of data engineering and the data industry. It covers the gathering, processing, and analysis of data, as well as decision-making and actuation in relation to data. The subject emphasizes practical, hands-on experience using MATLAB for modeling and data engineering tasks.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Use practical skills to model and simulate complex and complicated systems.
2. Understand, collect, and store data.
3. Validate and authenticate data.
4. Integrate the elements of the Data Engineering program, its stages, and its studios.
5. Create an item of software in the MATLAB environment that performs a data gathering task.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Fieldwork and laboratory programs involving team and individual projects.
Online lectures and resources for self-paced learning.
Establishment of study groups for collaborative learning.
Plenary resource sessions for guidance and information on teaching staff's expectations.
Use of supplementary learning materials such as Lynda.com online courses.
content: Introduction to data: what it is, how it is collected, represented, manipulated, and secured.
Introduction to complex systems and their theory.
Systems modeling using MATLAB and Simulink.

assessment_task_1.title: Learning MATLAB for Modeling Engineering Systems
assessment_task_1.intent: To model complex systems using MATLAB and learn key features of the software.

assessment_task_2.title: Model and Optimization of a Complex System using MATLAB
assessment_task_2.intent: To introduce optimization techniques and machine learning on a benchmark problem using MATLAB.

assessment_task_3.title: Create an App using MATLAB Appdesigner
assessment_task_3.intent: To design a MATLAB app with a GUI for one of the tasks done earlier in the session.

41082 Introduction to Data Engineering.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41092 Network Fundamentals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41092 Network Fundamentals.recommended_studies: Basic programming skills, e.g., C++ or Python, are recommended to complete the programming projects.
41092 Network Fundamentals.description: This subject provides a modern introduction to computer networking, including layered network architecture and the TCP/IP protocol suite. Students develop practical skills in network traffic observation, building network applications through socket programming, and working with Cisco network equipment. Problem-solving and design skills are also emphasized to help students select appropriate network services and develop network applications for optimized data performance.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the key architectural principles of the Internet, namely protocol layering and service models.
2. Analyse various components of the Internet, including Applications, Transport, Network, Addressing, and Data Link, to select the most appropriate network services.
3. Examine and explain end-to-end packet delivery throughout the network system to gain insight into the behaviour of the Internet.
4. Design and implement network applications to provide a service, such as web and email.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: A 1-hour lecture and 2-hour tutorial/laboratory each week.
Hands-on workshops using Cisco network equipment and network traffic observation tools.
Pre-class preparation, including textbook reading and video notes.
Teamwork and group activities to simulate real-world engineering workplaces.
Quizzes and project assessments to test understanding and practical skills.
content: 1. Computer Networks and the Internet: The network edge and core, protocol layers, network performance measures.
2. Application Layer: Web and HTTP, Email and DNS, socket programming for network applications.
3. Transport Layer: UDP, TCP, principles of congestion control, reliable data transfer.
4. Network Layer: IP, IPv4 and IPv6 addressing, routers, service models.
6. Link Layer: Ethernet, VLANs, multiple access links, error detection, and correction techniques.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Wireshark and hands-on labs for experiments, observations, and analysis.

assessment_task_2.title: Projects
assessment_task_2.intent: Develop skills in network design, development, and implementation.

assessment_task_3.title: Quiz
assessment_task_3.intent: Test conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Written Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess overall understanding of network concepts and problem-solving skills.

41092 Network Fundamentals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41084 Fundamentals Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
requisites: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering
41084 Fundamentals Studio A.description: This studio subject allows students to apply their knowledge to practical challenges in Data and Electronic Engineering. Students engage in team-based product development, applying engineering principles to assess, design, and implement solutions. Individual learning contracts (ILCs) guide personal development, while the team collaboratively works on a product or prototype for an industry partner or academic mentor.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model, prototype and/or build a product based on the needs of a product owner.
2. Work effectively in a team to solve complex problems.
3. Work independently to fulfil the requirements of their Individual Learning Contracts.
4. Teach knowledge and/or skills to peers in the studio.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: The studio consists of two parallel activities – individual work through ILCs and team-based product development.
Students develop an ILC at the beginning of the session, which is revisited and assessed at the end.
Teams choose a product/prototype to work on, guided by a product owner.
Team work includes managing project deliverables and timelines, documented in a shared UTSOnline WiKi.
Nine hours per week commitment is expected, including three hours of scheduled studio time for team and individual meetings.
content: Individual Learning Contracts (ILCs) to guide personal learning.
Team-based product development with industry mentors or academic staff.
Collaboration and reporting through UTSOnline WiKi.

assessment_task_1.title: Individual Learning Contract Agreement
assessment_task_1.intent: Identify and document learning goals for the session.

assessment_task_2.title: Individual Learning Contract Finalisation
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrate the achievement of personal learning goals.

assessment_task_4.title: Team Product/Prototype Delivery
assessment_task_4.intent: Deliver the final product or prototype to meet the agreed scope.

assessment_task_5.title: Personal Design Journal
assessment_task_5.intent: Reflect on personal and team-based experiences throughout the studio.

41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.description: This subject introduces students to programming hardware devices to collect data, make control decisions and cause actions in the physical world. Students develop theoretical and practical understanding in sensing, actuation, hardware control, signal measurement, data processing, and image processing. Students bring their own devices for practical system implementation, combining virtual learning environments and hands-on activities.

2. Interface embedded processors to sensors and actuators.

4. Select and specify appropriate sensors, actuators, and control hardware.

41085 Fundamentals Studio B.description: This is a studio subject where students apply knowledge to real-world projects through individual and team efforts. Students work on product-based projects, learning to model, design, and implement solutions collaboratively. The subject focuses on developing practical skills through real-time application of engineering concepts and fostering teamwork.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model, prototype and/or build a Product based on the needs of a Product Owner.
2. Work effectively in a team to solve complex problems.
3. Work independently to fulfil the requirements of their Individual Learning Contracts.
4. Teach knowledge and/or skills to peers in the Studio.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative

41083 Data Engineering Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41083 Data Engineering Design.description: This subject focuses on the creation and prototyping of new data engineering systems, with an emphasis on human-centred design and innovation. Students are encouraged to explore real-world applications of data-intensive systems and present their solutions through prototypes. The subject encourages collaboration and interdisciplinary problem-solving using design thinking approaches.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Build technical capability in design and innovative development techniques to prototype future applications of data-intensive systems.
2. Reflect on and identify learning needs and seek answers independently.
3. Explain results and outcomes through multiple modes of reflection and communication.
4. Critically apply communication skills (written and verbal).
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: This subject is conducted as a studio focusing on collaborative research, analysis, and design using human-centred approaches.
Students participate in iterative idea generation, feedback, and critical reflection.
Projects are presented by students and teams work on prototyping solutions, guided by feedback from peers and teaching staff.
The subject emphasizes teamwork, project management, communication, and real-world problem-solving.

assessment_task_1.title: Reflection and weekly participation
assessment_task_1.length: An average of 200-word entry per top five moment over 10 weeks, plus other additional media as appropriate.
assessment_task_1.intent: Demonstrate communication skills and reflect on learning.

assessment_task_2.title: Individual video pitch on a possible early solution

41086 Applications Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
requisites: (48 credit points of completed study in Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) and related programs)
41086 Applications Studio A.description: This studio subject focuses on translating knowledge into action by providing students with an environment to develop products or prototypes based on real-world needs. The subject encourages teamwork and independent study through a project-based approach that follows the classic engineering design process of assess, design, and implement.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Model, prototype and/or build a Product based on the needs of a Product Owner.
2. Work effectively in a team to solve complex problems.
3. Work independently to fulfill the requirements of their Individual Learning Contracts.
4. Teach knowledge and/or skills to peers in the Studio.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: The Studio is carried out through parallel activities: Individual and Team work.
Students will collaborate in teams to select and develop a product or prototype, guided by a Product Owner and academic mentor.
The individual learning process is formalized through an Individual Learning Contract (ILC) at the start of the session, revisited and finalized at the end.
The team reports progress through ongoing updates on a UTSOnline Wiki, including a final product/prototype submission.
Active participation in class discussions, presentations, and peer teaching sessions is encouraged.
content: Engineering design process: assess, design, implement

assessment_task_5.title: Personal Design Journal
assessment_task_5.intent: A reflective journal documenting the student’s process, learning, and experiences in the studio.

31242 Advanced Internet Programming.description: In this subject, students create sophisticated web applications for deployment to production. It provides knowledge and skills in advanced internet technologies related to server-side programming and business-to-business systems. The subject focuses on hands-on development using web development stacks, n-tier architectures, security, web service integration, and deployment strategies.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and implement a medium-sized web application incorporating multiple data sources, transaction integrity, data and application security.
2. Describe at a conceptual level, multi-tier and distributed web applications, and the components and technologies used to build such applications.
3. Describe the features of a web-based application system that provides scalability, robustness, high availability, and security.
4. Compare and contrast competing web application architectures and list their advantages and disadvantages.
5. Explain how transactions are used in web applications.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective

Two-hour laboratory sessions for technical demonstrations, programming challenges, and feedback.
Self-directed learning with additional online readings, research activities, and use of the discussion board for ongoing communication.

assessment_task_2.intent: Develop a real-world web application, incorporating the concepts learned throughout the subject.

31269 Business Requirements Modelling.description: This subject introduces information system concepts and describes how these concepts can be used to model business requirements. It covers agile and non-agile software engineering principles, methods, tools, and techniques, with a focus on various analysis approaches including object-oriented methods, business process modelling, and entity-relationship modelling. Students work in small teams to apply these techniques to case studies.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify stakeholders, understand their needs, and learn how to capture requirements in the system development process.
2. Apply modelling and systems analysis techniques that help understand the working of a business system.
3. Document and specify various requirements via Software Requirements Specification (SRS).
4. Develop various models using a range of systems analysis techniques to analyse and specify system and user requirements.
5. Work effectively in a small team.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes to meet specified requirements.
D.1: Technically Proficient - FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, software tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - FEIT graduates work effectively as members or leaders of diverse teams, communicating effectively within cross-disciplinary contexts.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: A combination of formal seminars and collaborative workshops based on a practical case study.
Active learning through role-playing, think-pair-share, quizzes, and group discussions.
Regular feedback during seminars and workshops on work done for case study assignments.
Weekly quizzes with immediate feedback to track progress.
Students are expected to spend 9-12 hours per week on study, including class time and independent reading.

assessment_task_1.title: Short Quizzes and Professional Engagement
assessment_task_1.intent: To evaluate understanding and application of key concepts through weekly quizzes.

assessment_task_2.title: Requirements Analysis Report
assessment_task_2.intent: To analyze and document system requirements for a case study.
assessment_task_2.length: Maximum 1000 words excluding diagrams, bibliography, and appendices.

assessment_task_3.title: OO Requirements Analysis and Specification Report
assessment_task_3.intent: To develop object-oriented analysis and specification for a case study.
assessment_task_3.length: Maximum 3000 words excluding diagrams, bibliography, and appendices.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: To test knowledge and understanding of requirements engineering and modelling techniques.

41001 Cloud Computing and Software as a.description: This subject introduces students to cloud computing fundamentals, including cloud architecture, infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), software-as-a-service (SaaS), virtualization, and multi-tenancy. Students work in groups to develop research reports and cloud-based software applications.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Articulate the need for cloud computing and its applications in various fields such as e-business, e-government, e-banking, e-health, and e-learning.
2. Describe the architecture of different types of Cloud Services (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) and virtualization technologies.
3. Critically analyze current issues in Cloud Computing for informed business decision making.
4. Create a Cloud Computing prototype on a cloud platform in areas such as e-government, e-banking, e-health, and e-learning.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs and cultural perspectives to define the system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop systems and processes.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - FEIT graduates work effectively in teams, communicating within cross-disciplinary contexts.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1.5-hour lecture and 1.5-hour lab/tutorial per week.
Lectures focus on theoretical discussions, while tutorials and labs emphasize practical exercises.
Group discussions, case studies, and lab-based programming on cloud platforms.
Pre-reading materials are provided to support lectures and practical work.

assessment_task_5.intent: Test understanding of cloud computing concepts.

41900 Cryptography.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

recommended_studies: Foundation Mathematics or equivalent

41900 Cryptography.description: This subject introduces students to modern security issues and technologies, covering aspects like security principles, policies, network/system security, and intrusion detection. Students apply programming skills to implement secure communications in a group project.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the theories and principles of information security by examining the mathematics behind encryption algorithms.
2. Identify programmatic flaws by examining and exploiting flawed software routines.
3. Implement secure protocols and techniques to prevent data interception by modifying and improving provided software.
4. Discuss the impact of evolving cryptographic techniques on contemporary security protocols.
5. Assess system design aspects that affect or compromise security principles.
6. Collaborate effectively in a software development team.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - Identifying and analyzing stakeholder needs to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - Applying problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems.
D.1: Technically Proficient - Applying mathematics, discipline fundamentals, and software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - Working as an effective member of diverse teams and communicating effectively.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1-hour weekly lecture to discuss theory and concepts.
2-hour lab each week for project work and group programming.
Self-organized group meetings outside class (at least 2 hours per week) to work on the project.
Students must check UTSOnline regularly for additional learning resources and dedicate time outside class.
programming_skills: Opportunities and tools will be provided to learn programming early in the course.
Programming is essential for the group project but not required in the final exam.
41900 Cryptography.active_learning: The primary project involves group programming where students collaborate to implement secure protocols and improve security in peer-to-peer communication by modifying example code.

assessment_task_1.title: Quizzes
assessment_task_1.intent: Motivate continuous learning and recall of technical knowledge relevant to the subject.

assessment_task_2.title: Group Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Apply theoretical knowledge by designing and implementing secure algorithms and protocols.
assessment_task_2.length: Due in two parts from weeks 4 to 12

assessment_task_3.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess understanding of cryptographic standards, applications, and technologies.

48730 Cybersecurity.description: This subject consolidates students' understanding of cyber security by considering security principles from both people management and technical perspectives, and explores security technologies commonly used in industry. Topics include cyber attacks and defenses, web security, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and security services such as confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the major theories and principles used in implementing a secure network.
2. Explain the underlying algorithms used to construct Security Protocols.
3. Identify and explain the major threats and their mitigation associated with cyber security.
4. Explain the major methodologies for secure networks and what threats they address.
5. Compare and contrast the technologies used in achieving network security across various network layers following OSI/TCP/IP architecture.
6. Implement and reflect on solutions for cyber security.

48436 Digital Forensics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

subject_learning_objectives: Evaluate theories of digital forensics
Understand the structure of forensic evidence
Implement forensically sound digital security practices in industry
Demonstrate competence in applying industry-standard forensic analysis techniques

Blended curriculum with research and hands-on labs focusing on digital forensics principles

48434 Embedded Software.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48434 Embedded Software.description: This subject focuses on the design, implementation, and testing of software modules for embedded systems. Students work in teams to develop software, interpret specifications, and test applications for embedded systems using hardware abstraction layers and data structures. A project-based approach enables students to design embedded systems software and gain debugging skills.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, write, and test various software modules such as hardware abstraction layers, data structures, and interrupt service routines.
2. Design, write, and test an embedded application that is modular, hierarchical, and meets real-time constraints.
3. Use various software tools to write, execute, and test embedded software applications.
4. Test software performance in embedded systems using appropriate laboratory equipment.
5. Research and evaluate knowledge from various sources.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop skills in handling microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupts, and interfacing.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz

assessment_task_3.title: Project

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.description: This subject introduces students to high-level procedural programming using C. Topics include conditional statements, iteration, functions, arrays, file processing, data structures, and memory management using pointers. Students also learn to compile C source code using the GNU toolchain, link binary object files, and run executables, following the complete development cycle, from problem analysis to testing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, develop, and test programs in C to solve data-related problems.
2. Identify and explain the use of programming tools, standard libraries, and OS functions to support program execution.
3. Follow professional programming practices to align with industry expectations.
4. Collaborate effectively as a team member to solve complex problems using C.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and decision-making methodologies to develop systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and operate systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams and communicate across contexts. (E.1)
content_topics: Fundamental programming concepts: program development cycle, GNU toolchain, compiling C source code, linking, debugging, and testing.
Procedural programming in C: primitive data types, operators, typecasting, functions, pass by reference/value.
Control and loop statements: logical expressions, conditionals, and loops.
Arrays: creation, manipulation, and string handling.
Structures and file processing: user-defined structures, binary/text file handling.
Pointers: dynamic memory management, linked lists.
Advanced topics: user-defined libraries, command line parsing, programming in the large.

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz

31256 Image Processing and Pattern Recog.faculty: UTS: Information Technology: Electrical and Data Engineering
31256 Image Processing and Pattern Recog.description: This subject teaches students principles of image processing and pattern recognition, enabling them to develop software for automatic image and video analysis in real-world applications.
subject_learning_objectives: Use foundational techniques of image processing and analysis to solve real-world problems.
Build and use statistical classifiers.
Apply techniques to detect objects and activities in images and video.
Collaborate effectively in teams.
Utilise Matlab for development in image processing and pattern recognition.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)

41903 Internet Science.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
Requisite(s): 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Degree owned by FEIT OR 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Honours Embedded owned by FEIT OR 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Combined Degree owned by FEIT OR 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Combined Honours owned by FEIT OR 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Combined Degree co-owned by FEIT OR 96 credit points of completed study in Bachelor's Combined Honours co-owned by FEIT
41903 Internet Science.Description: This subject exposes students to the latest developments in networking, with a particular focus on the Internet and its measurement, using the research literature as a vehicle. Students learn through working to understand, reproduce, and extend existing research work. Students work with research papers, and Internet-derived data sets, in diverse ways using a master-apprentice style model in tutorial and lab sessions. Tutorials combine mathematical and practical tool-building. Assessment includes reports, an oral exam, lab findings, and an online quiz. Extensive use of Matlab and Unix CLI is required. Internet measurement was one of the founding areas of 'Big Data', and this subject covers Internet-flavoured Data Science.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Clearly describe and explain the significance of contemporary areas of network science.
2. Access public datasets and explore them with mathematical and software tools.
3. Critically evaluate research papers and verify results.
4. Develop mathematical and practical skills of the Internet researcher.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): Mathematical, methodological, and practical tools for Internet Science.
State-of-the-art topics in Internet Science and networking.

Assessment task 1: Research Review.Intent: To provide students the opportunity to observe and learn about contemporary Internet research activity.

Assessment task 2: Laboratory Report.Intent: To report on weekly lab activities and investigations undertaken by lab teams.
Criteria: Part 2 (Chosen Data Set): accuracy, correctness, completeness, clarity, ambition, novelty.

Assessment task 3: Oral Exam.Intent: To test the student's ability to understand and communicate research paper results.

Assessment task 4: Quiz.Intent: To test familiarity with tutorial content.

41903 Internet Science.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48033 Internet of Things.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48033 Internet of Things.Description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a distributed system in which autonomous devices collect environmental or medical data. This subject explores sensor networks, telemetry, distributed data, machine vision, AI, and analytics for applications like environmental monitoring, medical monitoring, and military surveillance. Students learn theory, concepts, and the practice of IoT through designing and developing an IoT-based application, learning new skills, understanding the benefits of the technology, and exploring new models of service deployment and data delivery.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Integrate skills and knowledge gained in the course as a whole.
2. Explain an integrated, multidisciplinary approach for IoT-based solutions and apply it to real-world scenarios.
3. Analyse, design, and implement a distributed IoT system, its components, and address connectivity issues.
4. Explain the principles of sensing/actuation, data transmission, processing, visualization, analytics, and cybersecurity issues in IoT.
5. Execute independent investigation of new IoT applications, methods, technologies, programming models, and tools.
6. Recognize and appreciate the collaborative nature of IoT development and teamwork involved.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): IoT theory, concepts, components, and delivery models
Fundamentals of Localisation, Aggregation, Clustering, and Routing
Issues and Challenges in building IoT applications
IoT in Context of Cloud Computing and Analytics

Assessment task 1: Project.Intent: To demonstrate understanding and skills required for the design and implementation of an IoT-based solution.

Assessment task 2: Labs.Intent: Completion of weekly lab activities and demonstration of working programs to the tutor.

Assessment task 3: Short Quizzes.Intent: To assess understanding of topics covered during the preceding lectures.

Assessment task 4: Examination.Intent: To assess student understanding of topics covered throughout the session.

48033 Internet of Things.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41025 Introduction to Software Developme.Description: This subject introduces students to the fundamentals of contemporary software development. An overview of agile and non-agile software development principles, methods, tools, and techniques is presented. Students learn how to design, develop, and evaluate software based on commercially realistic but manageable requirements, often modifying or extending existing software. Peer learning and collaboration are encouraged, but each student is responsible for completing their individual tasks. The primary objective is for students to experience and apply professional practices in software development.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Investigate and solve software development problems with minimal supervision.
2. Determine and balance the competing goals of software development activities within their constraints.
3. Plan and manage a software development task to create, modify, or extend a software feature or function within constraints.
4. Apply sound software engineering practices to successfully create, modify, or extend a software feature or function.
5. Communicate clearly software and task information to interested stakeholders.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Reflective (F.1)

Assessment task 1: Project – Analysis, P.Intent: To demonstrate the ability to analyse, plan, architect, and design a software application.
Assessment task 1: Project – Analysis, P.Length: Recommended maximum of 5000 words, excluding diagrams, bibliography, logbooks, and appendices.

Assessment task 2: Project – Implementat.Intent: To demonstrate the ability to implement and test a software application using professional development practices.

Assessment task 3: Online Quiz.Intent: To demonstrate understanding of the theory and practice of software development.

41025 Introduction to Software Developme.Minimum requirements: To pass this subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50 or greater.

31005 Machine Learning.Description: Data analytics is an exciting new field combining databases, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and visualisation among others. It is applied in many fields of business, industry, and science to discover new information and knowledge. This subject builds on previous data analytics subjects to give an understanding of how both basic and more powerful algorithms work. It takes a research-inspired approach so that students learn to apply state-of-the-art algorithms to their professional practice. It also introduces data analytics approaches for specific domains such as social network analysis and text mining.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe the scope, limitations, and application of several advanced data analytics methods.
2. Demonstrate their ability to read, understand, and critique a data analytics approach from an academic research publication.
3. Use or program an advanced data analytics method.
4. Design an approach to data analytics problems in specialised domains.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of the issues underlying data analytics to successfully outline an approach to solving a data analytics problem.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): 1. Data analytics and its relationship to machine learning and optimisation.
4. Data analytics approaches: neural networks, Bayesian approaches, sparse linear methods.

Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Intent: Demonstrate understanding of the literature and critique data analytics methods.
Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Length: A report of 10 pages in an 11 or 12 point font.

Assessment task 2: Practical Data Analyt.Intent: Apply data analytics methods to real-world data.

Assessment task 3: Examination.Intent: Assess understanding of key concepts and methods covered in the course.

31005 Machine Learning.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31275 Mobile Networking.Faculty: UTS: Information Technology: Electrical and Data Engineering
31275 Mobile Networking.Recommended studies: Basic understanding of networking and telecommunication concepts
31275 Mobile Networking.Description: Wireless networks, such as cellular, WiFi, sensor, satellite, and near field communication networks, provide ubiquitous connections to devices and end-users, and are the underlying technologies and systems for almost every industry today. This subject covers the principles and applications of wireless telecommunication networks, and their integration with the internet. The emphasis is on the concepts, infrastructure, and protocols of these networks, and the use of these networks in applications with different requirements of supporting devices and mobility. This subject also offers extensive hands-on experience via solving industry-related problems and provides opportunities for research innovation via group project work.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Explain the concepts, techniques, and protocols employed in various wireless networks to perform consulting tasks involving support roles for wireless technologies.
2. Analyze the network infrastructure requirements to support mobile devices and users.
3. Develop and roadshow innovative solutions for practical applications of wireless technologies.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): Introduction and Wireless data transmission principles.
Wireless Personal Area Networks: Bluetooth and Zigbee.
Wireless Wide Area Networks: Cellular and Satellite.
Radio Frequency Identification and Near-field Communications.
Develop an innovative solution for practical problems using mobile networking technologies.

Assessment task 1: Quizzes.Intent: Encourage pre-class preparation and develop better self-learning capabilities. Establish a foundation for subsequent project work and allow students to become competent and knowledgeable wireless engineers.

Assessment task 2: Mobile Application De.Intent: Apply theory to develop innovative solutions to real problems and create a wireless industrial design report. Assess overall knowledge and capabilities in problem abstraction, modeling, and applying the learned knowledge. Promotes teamwork by mimicking real collaborative and competitive work environments.

31275 Mobile Networking.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31274 Network Management.Faculty: UTS: Information Technology: Electrical and Data Engineering
31274 Network Management.Requisite(s): 31277 Routing and Switching Essentials OR 31471 Networking 2
31274 Network Management.Recommended studies: Familiarity with Microsoft Windows; basic Linux commands; router configuration commands and network protocols
31274 Network Management.Description: This subject explains the role of the network manager and the network management system. It discusses the components of network management, i.e. fault management, performance management, configuration management, security management and accounting management. The integration of the components into an enterprise management system is addressed. The lecture material is integrated with laboratory sessions throughout, which allows students to experience aspects of network management including the skills of using basic network management tools and application for network maintenance.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): Explain the role of network management in enterprise-scale networks
Explain basic network models, protocols and database concepts
Identify the requirements of tools required to manage small to medium sized networks
Demonstrate proficiency in using standard tools for performing network management tasks
Configure basic network management on a network and manage the network using basic tools
Content (topics): Overview of Network Management: Management models, protocols and tools
Network management process: network discovery, the network as an object base, network agent messages and their role in automation of the network management process
Management Tasks: Fault management, Configuration management, Performance management, Security management and Accounting management
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP), Management Information Base (MIB)
Remote Monitoring, Desktop Management and Web-based Management
Integrated enterprise network management, Software Defined Network (SDN) Management

Assessment task 1.Intent: Quizzes are used in this subject to help students receive regular feedback on their learning of the weekly topics.

Assessment task 2.Intent: The case study project will involve students working in groups to explore a case study based on a current industry scenario, and will be required to develop network management solutions for the case study.

Assessment task 3.Intent: The skills examination allows students to demonstrate their proficiency with using network management tools to manage a small to medium sized network.

Assessment task 4.Intent: The final written exam allows students to demonstrate their understanding of the concepts covered in the subject, and the ability to apply that knowledge in different scenarios.

31274 Network Management.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48023 Programming Fundamentals.anti-requisites: 31267 Programming Fundamentals AND 31465 Object-oriented Programming AND 31488 Programming Foundations AND 31508 Programming Fundamentals AND 37171 Introduction to Programming for Mathematics AND 41039 Programming 1
48023 Programming Fundamentals.description: This subject provides basic skills in Java programming and software design, with no assumed knowledge of programming. It covers the topics of object-oriented (OO) programming concepts, data flow, control flow, arrays, and the basics of sorting and searching algorithms. The subject teaches and illustrates a design process using a set of design notations and design rules, and shows how to develop a correct, readable and reusable solution from a problem specification.
48023 Programming Fundamentals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate a working knowledge of the basic constructs in the object-oriented language Java by being able to complete small programs. 2. Use the BlueJ programming environment to build simple software systems. 3. Design and code a software system that correctly implements a solution to a small problem defined by a specification, and follows specific design rules. 4. Comprehend and use basic program control constructs of sequence, selection and iteration. 5. Comprehend and use code that implements arrays and the basic sorting and searching algorithms.
48023 Programming Fundamentals.content: 1. The BlueJ environment. 2. Data Flow: assignment; input, output; numeric expressions, and calculations. 3. OO Programming: class; object; constructor; visibility modifiers; local variables. 4. Control Flow: selection and repetition. 5. Data Structures and Basic Algorithms: arrays; sorting and searching. 6. Design notations, processes, and rules.

assessment_3.name: Additional lab exercises
assessment_3.length: One or more hours each week

48023 Programming Fundamentals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more. Students who complete all the pass/fail tests (Assessment Task 1) are guaranteed a minimum mark/grade for this subject of 50/PASS.

Requisite(s): (31267 Programming Fundamentals OR 31465 Object-oriented Programming OR 31488 Programming Foundations OR 31508 Programming Fundamentals OR 48023 Programming Fundamentals)
31748 Programming on the Internet.Recommended studies: Basic knowledge of programming languages and Unix systems
31748 Programming on the Internet.Description: This subject introduces students to the specifics of the World Wide Web (WWW) and internet-based programming. The evolution of the internet and its technical foundation is studied as well as basic techniques for presenting data, text, and pictures on the WWW. The subject focuses on PHP (hypertext preprocessor), MySQL (backend database), JavaScript, AJAX, XML, and Object Oriented PHP. This subject provides a sound basis for understanding how the WWW functions, how to construct websites, and how to write software for the WWW using advanced scripting techniques.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand the general concepts pertaining to the Internet and World Wide Web.
2. Possess an insight into the development and security of non-trivial websites.
3. Have a good working knowledge of DHTML, JavaScript, AJAX, and website design principles.
4. Gain introductory knowledge of XML on the Web.
5. Gain experience in using PHP as a server-side scripting language.
6. Gain sufficient knowledge of Unix to manage websites on Unix systems.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
Content (topics): The Internet and World Wide Web – General Principles
Introduction to dynamic web programming; PHP; JavaScript
MySQL database; extending the power of PHP
31748 Programming on the Internet.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48450 Real-time Operating Systems.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48450 Real-time Operating Systems.Description: This subject addresses the purposes, design alternatives and uses of computer operating systems for programming in embedded systems, PC, and servers. Topics include process management, scheduling and inter-process communication, memory management, and I/O device management, with an emphasis on real-time systems.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Show competence in using and writing application programs in POSIX compliant C on a Unix operating system
2. Illustrate the basic principles of the design and implementation of an operating system to create an experimental analysis report
3. Solve quantitative and qualitative problems related to operating system design and use
4. Identify the basic principles of real-time systems analysis to understand Linux systems
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design and decision-making methodologies
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement and operate systems

42913 Social and Information Network Ana.Description: This subject introduces students to basic concepts in social and information networks, metrics to characterise networks, models to explain the generation of networks, and methods to analyse networks. Students learn to use software tools to visualise and analyse real-world network data and explore a variety of applications in social and information networks such as user recommendation and web search.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand basic concepts in social and information networks.
2. Use important metrics and models to characterize networks.
3. Utilize software tools to visualize real-life network data.
4. Apply the concepts and techniques learned in class to analyse networks of their interest.
5. Understand behaviour of social and information networks.
6. Communicate in the form of technical report.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design thinking and decision-making methodologies
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply theoretical, conceptual, software and physical tools
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams and cross-disciplinary contexts

48433 Software Architecture.Recommended studies: Students should have knowledge of object-oriented design and unified modelling language (UML). A quiz is provided to check mastery of this knowledge.
48433 Software Architecture.Description: This subject teaches students current industry practices to design, develop, and evaluate software architecture that meets predefined quality characteristics. Concepts, theories, and technologies underlying the methods and techniques are introduced and explained. Students apply these practices to develop an architecture of a business system.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe the factors that affect the architectural context and requirements, including stakeholders and their interests.
2. Develop and refine multiple views of a software system architecture.
3. Understand key issues in choosing and implementing architectural patterns.
4. Reason about alternative architectural designs to satisfy a system's quality attributes.
5. Develop a complete software architecture for a proposed solution to a realistic industry problem.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams.
Content (topics): Software architecture for specific needs (e.g., product lines, real-time systems, web-based systems)

Assessment task 1.Intent: Encourages students to progressively engage and learn the subject content.

Assessment task 2.Intent: Encourages students to understand and apply specialised software architecture concepts.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Work in a team to develop an architecture for a specific system in a given context.

Assessment task 4.Intent: Develop and practice the skill of reviewing and critiquing peers' work.

Assessment task 5.Intent: Assess a student's knowledge of software architecture and the ability to apply it to a given problem.

41905 Software Defined Networks.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41905 Software Defined Networks.Description: This subject introduces students to Software Defined Networking (SDN) and programming SDN applications. Students learn key concepts in SDN, Network Function Virtualisation (NFV), and develop applications over leading SDN controllers through hands-on labs and exercises. It addresses the demand for SDN skills in the industry and covers core topics such as SDN architectures, controllers, NFV technologies, and real-world use cases.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Design, program, simulate, and implement Software Defined Networking applications.
2. Differentiate and evaluate Software Defined Networking Architectures, Controller Environments, Application Programming Interfaces, and Platforms.
3. Use tools for modelling Software Defined Networks.
4. Explain Network Function Virtualisation technologies, applications, and benefits.
5. Present project investigation, design, and implementation to technical and lay audiences.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating effectively.
Content (topics): SDN and NFV Applications and Scenarios
Introduction to Python and Python Networking

Assessment task 1.Intent: Students demonstrate their ability to develop SDN scripts and applications.

Assessment task 2.Intent: The quiz assesses the student’s knowledge of the theoretical aspects of the subject.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Students apply skills learned in class to develop and demonstrate an SDN application.

31282 Systems Testing and Quality Manage.Description: This subject provides students with the practical knowledge and skills necessary to effectively measure and control the quality of software products. It covers software quality assurance and management principles along with systems and software testing approaches.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Plan and execute specific processes, types, and phases of testing to assure quality in software products.
2. Apply exploratory and smoke testing to evaluate system operations and functions.
3. Apply quality assurance and management principles to Agile and Waterfall test processes.
4. Work collaboratively to plan, develop, apply, and document test systems.
5. Understand the principles and approaches to testing and quality management and their support for developers, projects, and business outcomes.
6. Communicate professionally in all aspects of testing.

41091 Data Systems.Description: This subject introduces the concepts of systems engineering for complex, data-centric systems. It covers the lifecycle of data-centric systems from design through development, production, and ongoing management. Students engage in project-based learning with a combination of individual and team work.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Define requirements and specifications of data systems.
2. Demonstrate systematic design and thinking for data system development.
3. Prototype or implement data systems according to system specifications.
4. Communicate effectively with data system project stakeholders.
5. Work effectively in a team to develop data systems, showing continuous improvement and independence.

D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, and discipline fundamentals to systems.

48210 Interrogating Technology: Sustaina.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Professional Practice and Leadership
Requisite(s): (25115 Economics for Business OR 23115 Economics for Business)
48210 Interrogating Technology: Sustaina.Description: This subject focuses on developing engineering students' approaches to understanding the interactions between engineering and society from philosophical, sociological, and political perspectives. It introduces theoretical frameworks and research tools for researching these interactions. Case studies of new technologies and engineering projects are examined to ground the learning in real-world engineering contexts.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Use appropriate research tools to interpret philosophical, sociological, and political perspectives.
2. Apply relevant theoretical frameworks to interrogate and represent major ethical positions on technology, society, and the environment.
3. Evaluate diverse methods and techniques used to assess and mitigate technology impacts on the environment, society, and the global commons to secure sustainable futures.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs and perspectives.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving and decision-making methodologies.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member of diverse teams, communicating across contexts.
Content (topics): Critical perspectives on sustainability, environment, and social change.
Technology as a driver for policy change.
Public participation and consultation in technological development.

Assessment task 1.Intent: Examine how technological change is being discussed and understood in the public arena, focusing on stakeholder engagement.

Assessment task 2.Intent: Monitor the development of students' social literacy.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Evaluate learning strategies through an in-depth investigation of a relevant topic.

48210 Interrogating Technology: Sustaina.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41039 Programming 1.Description: This subject introduces core programming concepts using an object-oriented approach to programming. It prioritises project-based learning and independent research, encouraging experimentation and communication skills. Students also learn how their initial programming explorations may eventually expand to making fixes or improvements in complex industry-scale projects.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Apply basic programming concepts of state, iteration, and decision.
2. Solve computational problems by using abstract modelling and conceptualisation.
3. Design and create simple functioning programs to achieve objectives.
4. Interpret, describe, and document programs using clear communication.
5. Reflect on programming decisions and formulate alternatives.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs.

31241 3D Computer Animation.Recommended studies: Basic knowledge of drawing and 2D digital image processing (e.g., Photoshop) is useful.
31241 3D Computer Animation.Description: This subject explores storytelling through 3D computer animation. It covers the complete animation production pipeline, including ideation, storyboarding, 3D animation, lighting, rendering, and VFX. Students practice pre-production planning, production management, and post-production of an animation project. This subject is project-based and focuses on learning by doing.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the theory behind 3D digital animation design and production.
2. Develop animation skills and the ability to analyze motion.
3. Design and rig a basic character for 3D animation using appropriate processes and workflows.
4. Create a character-based 3D Animation from the planning stage (storyboarding) to the final rendered 3D short.

31777 Advanced Interaction Design.Description: This subject focuses on user experience (UX) in Interaction Design, covering how UX influences the adoption of digital products, systems, or services. Students learn to describe, analyse, critique, and design for UX across a range of human-computer interactions, such as mobile and social computing, pervasive computing, IoT, and quantified self. Through project-based learning, students apply UX design principles to create engaging, user-focused technology solutions.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Use conceptual tools to describe, critique, and evaluate user experiences arising through interactions with technology.
2. Identify appropriate user experiences for different human-computer interactions.
3. Apply methods and techniques to design interactive technologies that support engaging user experiences.
4. Describe the social/technical and experiential concepts relevant to positive user experiences.
5. Identify and apply theoretical concepts to inspire more engaging design solutions.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - evaluate, implement, and operate systems using software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural teams.
F.1: Reflective - review personal and team performance to improve outcomes.

Teaching and learning strategies.Lecture format: Students engage with pre-recorded video lectures covering the theory of User Experience and Interaction Design.
Teaching and learning strategies.Tutorials: Hands-on design activities with formative feedback and guidance from tutors.
Teaching and learning strategies.Personal Portfolio: Students maintain a portfolio throughout the session, demonstrating progress in understanding UX design tools and techniques.
Teaching and learning strategies.Collaborative work: Online discussions and a session-long group project to solve real-life design problems.

Content (topics): Understanding UX and its differences from Usability
Designing for mobile, social, pervasive computing, IoT, and quantified self
Researching and representing user experiences in design

Assessment task 1.Length: 2-4 pages per journal entry using a provided template.

Assessment task 2.Criteria: Peer assessments determine individual contribution within group projects.

Assessment task 3.Criteria: Reflection on learning progress and tools used in UX design.

31777 Advanced Interaction Design.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31242 Advanced Internet Programming.description: In this subject, students create sophisticated web applications for deployment to production. It provides knowledge and skills in advanced internet technologies related to server-side programming and business-to-business systems. The subject focuses on hands-on development using web development stacks, n-tier architectures, security, web service integration, and deployment strategies.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and implement a medium-sized web application incorporating multiple data sources, transaction integrity, data and application security.
2. Describe at a conceptual level, multi-tier and distributed web applications, and the components and technologies used to build such applications.
3. Describe the features of a web-based application system that provides scalability, robustness, high availability, and security.
4. Compare and contrast competing web application architectures and list their advantages and disadvantages.
5. Explain how transactions are used in web applications.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective

Two-hour laboratory sessions for technical demonstrations, programming challenges, and feedback.
Self-directed learning with additional online readings, research activities, and use of the discussion board for ongoing communication.

2. Understand how the .NET framework implements object-oriented concepts and its implications for new language design.
3. Understand the mechanisms and techniques for the deployment and configuration of .NET applications.
4. Utilize the .NET libraries.
5. Gain practical experience in writing C# programs in the .NET environment.

31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Recommended studies: Knowledge of C++ or Java, and elementary two- and three-dimensional graphics algorithms.
31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Description: This subject covers the three major rendering techniques in computer graphics: rasterization, ray tracing, and radiosity, with an emphasis on ray tracing. Topics include reflection models, ray-object intersections, recursive ray tracing, transparency and refraction, textures, anti-aliasing, shadows, acceleration techniques, triangle meshes, global illumination, and radiosity.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand the strengths, weaknesses, and uses of rasterization, ray tracing, and radiosity algorithms.
2. Gain practical knowledge of ray tracing by implementing a substantive ray tracer.
31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Teaching and learning strategies: Weekly lectures focusing on ray tracing theory, algorithms, and techniques, with informal tutorials as needed.

Assessment task 1.Intent: To extend an existing ray tracer and produce images.

Assessment task 2.Type: Extending the ray tracer from Assignment 1
Assessment task 2.Intent: To further extend the ray tracer from Assignment 1 and produce images.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To extend the ray tracer from Assignment 2 by implementing additional topics from the textbook and creating images.

Criteria.Report: 1-2 pages detailing the implementation, problems, and solutions.
Criteria.Images: Short description of each image or group of related images.

41900 Cryptography.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

recommended_studies: Foundation Mathematics or equivalent

41900 Cryptography.description: This subject introduces students to modern security issues and technologies, covering aspects like security principles, policies, network/system security, and intrusion detection. Students apply programming skills to implement secure communications in a group project.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the theories and principles of information security by examining the mathematics behind encryption algorithms.
2. Identify programmatic flaws by examining and exploiting flawed software routines.
3. Implement secure protocols and techniques to prevent data interception by modifying and improving provided software.
4. Discuss the impact of evolving cryptographic techniques on contemporary security protocols.
5. Assess system design aspects that affect or compromise security principles.
6. Collaborate effectively in a software development team.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - Identifying and analyzing stakeholder needs to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - Applying problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems.
D.1: Technically Proficient - Applying mathematics, discipline fundamentals, and software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - Working as an effective member of diverse teams and communicating effectively.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1-hour weekly lecture to discuss theory and concepts.
2-hour lab each week for project work and group programming.
Self-organized group meetings outside class (at least 2 hours per week) to work on the project.
Students must check UTSOnline regularly for additional learning resources and dedicate time outside class.
programming_skills: Opportunities and tools will be provided to learn programming early in the course.
Programming is essential for the group project but not required in the final exam.
41900 Cryptography.active_learning: The primary project involves group programming where students collaborate to implement secure protocols and improve security in peer-to-peer communication by modifying example code.

assessment_task_1.title: Quizzes
assessment_task_1.intent: Motivate continuous learning and recall of technical knowledge relevant to the subject.

assessment_task_2.title: Group Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Apply theoretical knowledge by designing and implementing secure algorithms and protocols.
assessment_task_2.length: Due in two parts from weeks 4 to 12

assessment_task_3.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess understanding of cryptographic standards, applications, and technologies.

48730 Cybersecurity.description: This subject consolidates students' understanding of cyber security by considering security principles from both people management and technical perspectives, and explores security technologies commonly used in industry. Topics include cyber attacks and defenses, web security, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and security services such as confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the major theories and principles used in implementing a secure network.

3. Identify and explain the major threats and their mitigation associated with cyber security.
4. Explain the major methodologies for secure networks and what threats they address.
5. Compare and contrast the technologies used in achieving network security across various network layers following OSI/TCP/IP architecture.
6. Implement and reflect on solutions for cyber security.

Discussion sessions and hands-on group activities in labs.

41083 Data Engineering Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

41091 Data Systems.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41091 Data Systems.Description: This subject introduces the concepts of systems engineering for complex, data-centric systems. It covers the lifecycle of data-centric systems from design through development, production, and ongoing management. Students engage in project-based learning with a combination of individual and team work.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Define requirements and specifications of data systems.
2. Demonstrate systematic design and thinking for data system development.
3. Prototype or implement data systems according to system specifications.
4. Communicate effectively with data system project stakeholders.
5. Work effectively in a team to develop data systems, showing continuous improvement and independence.

31061 Database Principles.description: This subject introduces students to basic database design and implementation concepts, database design techniques, and using a relational design via Entity Relationship Diagram. Students also learn to access a database using SQL to retrieve and manipulate data.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and manage structured data to manage a database.
2. Produce an Entity-Relationship (E-R) model from specifications and perform transformation of the conceptual model into logical data structures.
3. Apply data normalisation principles and understand the impact of data redundancy.
4. Construct SQL statements to retrieve data.
5. Demonstrate use of a simple database using SQL and maintain database integrity rules.
6. Understand principles of database transaction management and recovery.
7. Distinguish between good and bad database design.
8. Communicate database designs effectively.
content_topics: SQL: data modification statements and views
Conceptual database design using E-R modelling

31253 Database Programming.description: This subject teaches students how to design, develop, and evaluate database programming and administration solutions. subject_learning_objectives: Describe the benefits of Database Programming
Understand programming constructs available in PL/SQL
Understand how triggers, stored procedures, stored functions, and database packages operate
Understand the current development methodology in modern database systems
Describe the use of supplied packages in the Oracle database
Have a basic understanding of the roles and responsibilities of a database administrator
