48436 Digital Forensics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48436 Digital Forensics.recommended_studies: Confident in using Windows command line utilities (netstat, nslookup, net, ipconfig) and Linux command line tools (grep, ls, uname, ps)
48436 Digital Forensics.description: This practice-based subject focuses on digital forensics applications. Students assess if a crime has been committed, acquire digital evidence, analyze the evidence, and prepare forensic reports. Key areas include web visit forensics, eDiscovery, and network intrusion investigation.
subject_learning_objectives: Evaluate theories of digital forensics
Understand the structure of forensic evidence
Implement forensically sound digital security practices in industry
Demonstrate competence in applying industry-standard forensic analysis techniques
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret and analyze stakeholder needs and cultural perspectives, establishing priorities and goals. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design thinking, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems. (D.1)
Reflective: FEIT graduates critically self-review their performance to improve themselves, their teams, and society. (F.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 3 hours of class per week, with lecture material available online
Blended curriculum with research and hands-on labs focusing on digital forensics principles
Emphasis on practical labs, where students apply forensic tools and techniques
content_topics: Legal Process in forensic investigation, Digital Evidence, Australian Privacy Principles
Data Acquisition from Hard Disks and Networks
Disk file systems: FAT32 and NTFS
Metadata in Graphics, Documents, and Camera images

assessments.intent: Test knowledge of forensic theories and principles.
Demonstrate skills in collecting digital forensic evidence.
Locate forensic evidence on digital devices.
Assess understanding of digital forensics theories and practices.
Master weekly lab concepts through practical assessments.

48434 Embedded Software.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48434 Embedded Software.description: This subject focuses on the design, implementation, and testing of software modules for embedded systems. Students work in teams to develop software, interpret specifications, and test applications for embedded systems using hardware abstraction layers and data structures. A project-based approach enables students to design embedded systems software and gain debugging skills.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, write, and test various software modules such as hardware abstraction layers, data structures, and interrupt service routines.
2. Design, write, and test an embedded application that is modular, hierarchical, and meets real-time constraints.
3. Use various software tools to write, execute, and test embedded software applications.
4. Test software performance in embedded systems using appropriate laboratory equipment.
5. Research and evaluate knowledge from various sources.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop skills in handling microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupts, and interfacing.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz

assessment_task_3.title: Project

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic digital systems and microprocessor/computer architecture is essential for this subject.
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.description: This subject focuses on the analysis, design, and implementation of an advanced computing node. It provides an in-depth understanding of digital hardware design at the medium scale computer system building block level. Students will engage in computer-aided design using VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable VLSI implementation technologies, and will explore topics such as digital design processes, functional design, advanced digital architectures, and memory and I/O systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse, design, and implement a programmable digital system based on a user requirement specification, and investigate advanced digital systems architectures.
2. Demonstrate in-depth understanding of the analysis, design, and implementation of advanced digital hardware at the medium scale computer system building block level.
3. Utilise computer-aided design, including the use of VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable FPGA implementation technologies, Register transfer level, Data path and control units.

problem_based_learning.method: Weekly lectures, tutorials, and laboratory assignments, focusing on developing solutions to complex design challenges.
problem_based_learning.approach: A series of staged laboratory tasks allows students to build up a complete system, culminating in a framework used for the final assignment.

student_support.preparation: Students are required to study notes, readings, and prepare questions prior to teaching activities.
student_support.collaboration: In labs, students work in groups of 2, engaging in collaborative discussions facilitated by academic staff.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.feedback: Academic staff provide immediate feedback during lectures, tutorials, and labs, with assignment demonstrations and one-on-one consultations for specific tasks.

content_topics: Review of basic digital techniques and their application to the design of state machines used in control units
Digital hardware design process and Programmable Logic

assessment_task_1.title: Assignments

assessment_task_2.title: Class Quizzes

assessment_task_2.criteria: Criteria will be included in the quiz paper.

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.description: This subject introduces students to high-level procedural programming using C. Topics include conditional statements, iteration, functions, arrays, file processing, data structures, and memory management using pointers. Students also learn to compile C source code using the GNU toolchain, link binary object files, and run executables, following the complete development cycle, from problem analysis to testing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, develop, and test programs in C to solve data-related problems.
2. Identify and explain the use of programming tools, standard libraries, and OS functions to support program execution.
3. Follow professional programming practices to align with industry expectations.
4. Collaborate effectively as a team member to solve complex problems using C.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and decision-making methodologies to develop systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and operate systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams and communicate across contexts. (E.1)
content_topics: Fundamental programming concepts: program development cycle, GNU toolchain, compiling C source code, linking, debugging, and testing.
Procedural programming in C: primitive data types, operators, typecasting, functions, pass by reference/value.
Control and loop statements: logical expressions, conditionals, and loops.
Arrays: creation, manipulation, and string handling.
Structures and file processing: user-defined structures, binary/text file handling.
Pointers: dynamic memory management, linked lists.
Advanced topics: user-defined libraries, command line parsing, programming in the large.

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz
assessment_task_1.intent: Reinforce and assess understanding of basic and fundamental C programming concepts.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignment
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess understanding of C programming concepts and application to real-world Data Engineering.

assessment_task_3.title: Group Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess ability to deliver programming solutions as a group.
assessment_task_3.length: Project report no more than 10 pages.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Evaluate understanding of fundamental programming concepts and C programming, along with professional coding practices.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Recommended studies: Knowledge of interactive technologies, design, and programming skills.
31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Description: This subject focuses on designing, evaluating, and implementing interactive computing systems for human use in real situations. Students learn human-computer interaction (HCI) and interaction design principles, including tools and techniques for building human-centered systems.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Critique and evaluate the usability and usefulness of information technology.
2. Design and evaluate usable digital systems by applying Human-Centered Design skills.
3. Discuss what Interaction Design, Human-Computer Interaction, and Design Thinking are.
4. Describe the crucial processes within a Human-Centered technology design approach.
5. Identify and utilize constraints and resources that human activities bring to technology design and use.
6. Recognize the range of approaches, techniques, tools, and methods available for designing useful and usable technology.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - identify and analyze stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply tools and techniques to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review to improve performance.
31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Teaching and learning strategies: Workshop sessions with lecture presentations (1 hour) and tutorials (1.5 hours). The subject emphasizes group work and collaborative problem-solving through tutorials and practical design projects. Students are expected to use online resources and engage in interactive discussions, assignments, and journal entries to deepen their understanding of Interaction Design.
Content (topics): 1. What is Interaction Design and Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)
2. Design principles, concepts, and theories of Interaction Design and HCI
3. Human-Centered design process and Design Thinking

Assessment task 1.Intent: To develop sensitivities and perceptions about technology use in everyday activities and articulate design issues.
Assessment task 1.Length: Single-page journal entries for #1-#3, 3-4 pages for entry #4.

Assessment task 2.Intent: To apply design and usability principles to critique and evaluate technology in a live setting.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To practice Human-Centered Design methodology by solving a real-world problem through research, prototyping, and evaluation.

31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

41090 Information and Signals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41090 Information and Signals.description: This subject provides the theoretical foundations of information theory and signal processing that prepare students for both industry- and research-oriented careers. It emphasizes a strong laboratory component to give students hands-on experience in applying theoretical concepts to practical communication and signal/image processing systems. It also encourages collaborative research projects in information and signal theory.
41090 Information and Signals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply fundamental concepts in information theory and signal processing. 2. Use Fourier, Laplace, and Z-transforms to analyze practical signals and systems. 3. Develop abstraction models of practical information and signal processing systems. 4. Apply the basic concepts of data and signal processing to identify specific requirements in designing components. 5. Simulate and test communications, data, and information processing systems. 6. Apply critical thinking to propose creative ideas in signal research.
41090 Information and Signals.content: Topics include: introduction to information theory, source coding and compression, channel capacity, introduction to signal and systems, Fourier series and Fourier transform, frequency analysis, Laplace transform and system analysis, Z-transform, discrete systems.
41090 Information and Signals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31080 Interactive Media.Description: This subject introduces students to the fundamental principles of interactive media and associated tools. Students use creative coding to design and develop interactive media systems incorporating digital audio, images, animation, and video, focusing on creating engaging user experiences.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Apply knowledge of digital sampling, storage, and mapping techniques for still images, video, sound, and sensor data.
2. Use digital sound, image, and video processing to alter digital media.
3. Design and develop interactive media applications that create effective and engaging user experiences.
4. Identify and explain the applications of digital media and prepare proposals for new systems.
5. Work in a team of digital media developers.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply software tools and techniques to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review to improve performance.
31080 Interactive Media.Teaching and learning strategies: Students will participate in a weekly 1-hour workshop and a 2-hour tutorial. They will engage with online activities, practical coding, and design projects, with continuous feedback throughout. Peer assessments will be applied in group assignments.
Content (topics): Enabling technologies: digital representations and signal processing
Computer graphics: vector graphics, 3D graphics, image manipulation
Interaction: motion capture, video analysis, mapping

Assessment task 1.Intent: Capture and reflect on learning throughout the semester.

Assessment task 2.Intent: Demonstrate the ability to work in a team on an interactive media project.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Develop an individual creative approach to a design task using interactive media concepts.

31080 Interactive Media.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48033 Internet of Things.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48033 Internet of Things.Description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a distributed system in which autonomous devices collect environmental or medical data. This subject explores sensor networks, telemetry, distributed data, machine vision, AI, and analytics for applications like environmental monitoring, medical monitoring, and military surveillance. Students learn theory, concepts, and the practice of IoT through designing and developing an IoT-based application, learning new skills, understanding the benefits of the technology, and exploring new models of service deployment and data delivery.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Integrate skills and knowledge gained in the course as a whole.
2. Explain an integrated, multidisciplinary approach for IoT-based solutions and apply it to real-world scenarios.
3. Analyse, design, and implement a distributed IoT system, its components, and address connectivity issues.
4. Explain the principles of sensing/actuation, data transmission, processing, visualization, analytics, and cybersecurity issues in IoT.
5. Execute independent investigation of new IoT applications, methods, technologies, programming models, and tools.
6. Recognize and appreciate the collaborative nature of IoT development and teamwork involved.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): IoT theory, concepts, components, and delivery models
Fundamentals of Localisation, Aggregation, Clustering, and Routing
Issues and Challenges in building IoT applications
IoT in Context of Cloud Computing and Analytics

Assessment task 1: Project.Intent: To demonstrate understanding and skills required for the design and implementation of an IoT-based solution.

Assessment task 2: Labs.Intent: Completion of weekly lab activities and demonstration of working programs to the tutor.

Assessment task 3: Short Quizzes.Intent: To assess understanding of topics covered during the preceding lectures.

Assessment task 4: Examination.Intent: To assess student understanding of topics covered throughout the session.

48033 Internet of Things.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Recommended studies: Familiarity with computer graphics and experience with designing interactive systems.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Description: This subject covers theoretical concepts and practical methodologies needed to ideate, communicate, implement, and improve computer game designs. Students will develop both a physical board game and a digital game. The subject emphasizes an iterative, player-centric design approach.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Critique games in terms of their function as dynamic systems of formal and dramatic elements.
2. Create computer games in a team by applying an iterative player-centric design approach.
3. Evaluate games by applying playtesting techniques.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyze stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply tools and techniques to develop systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - self-review to improve performance.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Teaching and learning strategies: The subject is highly collaborative and hands-on, with students working in groups to produce a physical board game and a digital game. Weekly labs and playtesting sessions foster continuous feedback and improvement. Lectures focus on game design theories and the practical application of these concepts.
Content (topics): The Process of Designing a Game: Conceptualization, prototyping, playtesting, game balance.
Game Design Basics: Role of game designer, structure of games, formal and dramatic elements.
Working as a Game Designer: Local and international game industry, serious games.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31263 Introduction to Computer Game Deve.Description: This subject introduces game development using a commercial-grade game engine, focusing on intermediate programming, vector and matrix mathematics for 2D/3D transformations, and engine API use. It builds a generalizable understanding of virtual interactive simulations, preparing students for group projects in subsequent games-related subjects.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Illustrate an understanding of the language and concepts of game development technology and techniques.
2. Apply mathematical and game programming knowledge to solve development tasks.
3. Build familiarity and appreciation of the programmatic components of an industry-standard game engine.
4. Seek new knowledge of games development through self-directed study.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
F.1: Reflective - self-review performance to improve oneself and the team.
31263 Introduction to Computer Game Deve.Teaching and learning strategies: Students will engage in a combination of lectures, pre-class video learning, and lab sessions. Game programming topics follow a 3-step process: learning in lectures, expanding knowledge through self-study, and reviewing learning via class discussions. Major assessments involve recreating a classic game and enhancing it with a novel twist.
Content (topics): Introduction to Unity – Unity interface, game cycle, components, GameObject, Transform
Fundamentals – asset instantiation, input management, vectors, translation/rotation/scale
Working with Time – time, delta time, co-routines
Animation and Audio Assets – animation state machines, audio function calls
UI Programming – UI canvas space, event registration/listening
Game State Managers – game managers, scene management
Physics Programming – rigid body physics, physics materials
Save Games – PlayerPrefs, JSON utility, file writing

Assessment task 4.Title: Classic Game Recreation - Enhancing and Innovating

Knowledge of linear algebra (e.g., vectors, matrices and their manipulation), data structures (e.g., multi-dimensional arrays, stack) is strongly recommended.
Good programming skills in at least one programming language are required.
31264 Introduction to Computer Graphics.Description: This subject introduces students to computer graphics, focusing on 3D shape representation, manipulation, and visualization. Students gain a theoretical and practical understanding of computer graphics technology, learning to design and implement 3D images using modern tools such as WebGL and the ThreeJS framework. The subject also covers fundamental principles of graphical pipelines, 3D model representations, and interactive web applications.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Discern possible applications of Computer Graphics and current trends.
2. Explain the different stages of the OpenGL graphics pipeline.
3. Understand how linear Algebra is important in the context of Computer Graphics.
4. Demonstrate foundational knowledge of modeling and representations of 3D shapes.
5. Understand how real-time shading and lighting is implemented.
6. Implement an interactive application using ThreeJS and WebGL.
7. Communicate design ideas, models, implementations, and outcomes.
8. Reflect critically on their own work.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - self-review performance to improve oneself and the team.
31264 Introduction to Computer Graphics.Teaching and learning strategies: The subject offers one 2-hour face-to-face interactive workshop and one 1.5-hour lab each week. Workshops include traditional lectures and live programming sessions in ThreeJS. Labs focus on implementing components of the project. Students are encouraged to actively participate and follow along during live coding sessions to deepen their understanding.

recommended_studies: Knowledge of database technologies
31250 Introduction to Data Analytics.description: Data analytics is the art and science of transforming large datasets into meaningful and valuable information. This subject offers foundational knowledge in data analytics, data mining, and knowledge discovery, focusing on practical applications and techniques. Students will explore statistical methods, database management, and intelligent technologies, with a focus on solving real-world problems and communicating results professionally.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the background of data analytics, including the business and society context.
2. Use data analytics to explore and gain a broad understanding of a dataset.
3. Outline the scope and limitations of state-of-the-art data analytics methods.
4. Use data analytics methods to make predictions for a dataset.
5. Organise and implement a data analytics project in a business environment.
6. Communicate the results of a data analytics project.
content_topics: Introduction to data mining: problems, concepts, and methodologies.
Visual data exploration and mining: data visualization techniques.
Data pre-processing and transformation: techniques for data cleaning, dealing with noisy or missing data.
Classification and prediction: decision trees, support vector machines, ensemble methods.
Clustering: partitioning methods, hierarchical methods, density-based methods, k-means.
Deployment of results: representing patterns as rules or functions, model deployment, industry applications.

assessments.name: Dream Jobs
assessments.intent: Understand the application of data analytics in various industries.

assessments.name: Data Exploration and Preparation
assessments.intent: Apply data exploration techniques and prepare data for analytics.

assessments.name: Data Mining in Action
assessments.intent: Apply data mining techniques and communicate the results of a data analytics project.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48441 Introductory Digital Systems.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

requisites.prerequisite: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering

48441 Introductory Digital Systems.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic electrical engineering circuits and soldering skills.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.description: This subject enables students to master the fundamentals of digital and programmable electronic circuits, small computer system hardware architecture, and low-level programming. Topics include digital sequential circuits, microcontroller hardware, assembly language, interrupts, input/output, and hardware interfacing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design combinational and sequential logic circuits.
2. Implement and evaluate logic circuits using appropriate software tools.
3. Analyse digital logic circuits.
4. Design and implement programmable logic devices and microcontrollers and related input/output components.
5. Identify basic assembly programming techniques to construct and implement basic assembly programs.
6. Write and evaluate assembly programs using appropriate software tools.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, and risks. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and software tools to evaluate and implement systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams, communicating and collaborating in cross-disciplinary contexts. (E.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Problem-based learning approach involving designing and analysing digital logic and microcontroller circuits.
Interactive lectures, face-to-face tutorials, and hands-on lab activities.
Students are expected to watch videos on UTSOnline and prepare before attending classes and labs.
Lab activities include hardware kit use, circuit design, and assembly language programming.
Immediate feedback from lab tutors during lab sessions.
content_topics: State diagrams and their application in digital circuit design.
Basic hardware architectures of digital computers.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31005 Machine Learning.Description: Data analytics is an exciting new field combining databases, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and visualisation among others. It is applied in many fields of business, industry, and science to discover new information and knowledge. This subject builds on previous data analytics subjects to give an understanding of how both basic and more powerful algorithms work. It takes a research-inspired approach so that students learn to apply state-of-the-art algorithms to their professional practice. It also introduces data analytics approaches for specific domains such as social network analysis and text mining.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe the scope, limitations, and application of several advanced data analytics methods.
2. Demonstrate their ability to read, understand, and critique a data analytics approach from an academic research publication.
3. Use or program an advanced data analytics method.
4. Design an approach to data analytics problems in specialised domains.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of the issues underlying data analytics to successfully outline an approach to solving a data analytics problem.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): 1. Data analytics and its relationship to machine learning and optimisation.
4. Data analytics approaches: neural networks, Bayesian approaches, sparse linear methods.

Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Intent: Demonstrate understanding of the literature and critique data analytics methods.
Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Length: A report of 10 pages in an 11 or 12 point font.

Assessment task 2: Practical Data Analyt.Intent: Apply data analytics methods to real-world data.

Assessment task 3: Examination.Intent: Assess understanding of key concepts and methods covered in the course.

41092 Network Fundamentals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41092 Network Fundamentals.recommended_studies: Basic programming skills, e.g., C++ or Python, are recommended to complete the programming projects.
41092 Network Fundamentals.description: This subject provides a modern introduction to computer networking, including layered network architecture and the TCP/IP protocol suite. Students develop practical skills in network traffic observation, building network applications through socket programming, and working with Cisco network equipment. Problem-solving and design skills are also emphasized to help students select appropriate network services and develop network applications for optimized data performance.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the key architectural principles of the Internet, namely protocol layering and service models.
2. Analyse various components of the Internet, including Applications, Transport, Network, Addressing, and Data Link, to select the most appropriate network services.
3. Examine and explain end-to-end packet delivery throughout the network system to gain insight into the behaviour of the Internet.
4. Design and implement network applications to provide a service, such as web and email.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: A 1-hour lecture and 2-hour tutorial/laboratory each week.
Hands-on workshops using Cisco network equipment and network traffic observation tools.
Pre-class preparation, including textbook reading and video notes.
Teamwork and group activities to simulate real-world engineering workplaces.
Quizzes and project assessments to test understanding and practical skills.
content: 1. Computer Networks and the Internet: The network edge and core, protocol layers, network performance measures.
2. Application Layer: Web and HTTP, Email and DNS, socket programming for network applications.
3. Transport Layer: UDP, TCP, principles of congestion control, reliable data transfer.
4. Network Layer: IP, IPv4 and IPv6 addressing, routers, service models.
6. Link Layer: Ethernet, VLANs, multiple access links, error detection, and correction techniques.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Wireshark and hands-on labs for experiments, observations, and analysis.

assessment_task_2.title: Projects
assessment_task_2.intent: Develop skills in network design, development, and implementation.

assessment_task_3.title: Quiz
assessment_task_3.intent: Test conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Written Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess overall understanding of network concepts and problem-solving skills.

41092 Network Fundamentals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31748 Programming on the Internet.Recommended studies: Basic knowledge of programming languages and Unix systems
31748 Programming on the Internet.Description: This subject introduces students to the specifics of the World Wide Web (WWW) and internet-based programming. The evolution of the internet and its technical foundation is studied as well as basic techniques for presenting data, text, and pictures on the WWW. The subject focuses on PHP (hypertext preprocessor), MySQL (backend database), JavaScript, AJAX, XML, and Object Oriented PHP. This subject provides a sound basis for understanding how the WWW functions, how to construct websites, and how to write software for the WWW using advanced scripting techniques.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand the general concepts pertaining to the Internet and World Wide Web.
2. Possess an insight into the development and security of non-trivial websites.
3. Have a good working knowledge of DHTML, JavaScript, AJAX, and website design principles.
4. Gain introductory knowledge of XML on the Web.
5. Gain experience in using PHP as a server-side scripting language.
6. Gain sufficient knowledge of Unix to manage websites on Unix systems.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative

Introduction to dynamic web programming; PHP; JavaScript
MySQL database; extending the power of PHP

41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.description: This subject introduces students to programming hardware devices to collect data, make control decisions and cause actions in the physical world. Students develop theoretical and practical understanding in sensing, actuation, hardware control, signal measurement, data processing, and image processing. Students bring their own devices for practical system implementation, combining virtual learning environments and hands-on activities.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Use real-time systems, understanding their requirements and practical implications.
2. Interface embedded processors to sensors and actuators.
3. Use the C language for creating embedded firmware and software.
4. Select and specify appropriate sensors, actuators, and control hardware.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient

48540 Signals and Systems.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48540 Signals and Systems.recommended_studies: Circuit analysis in both the time and frequency domains, including the use of differential equations and transform methods.
48540 Signals and Systems.description: This subject covers system analysis techniques, focusing on the analysis and design of control and communication systems. Students model, simulate, and test real-world systems and apply theoretical knowledge through laboratory experiments and a group project. Topics include signal types, differential/difference equations, transforms, feedback, stability, and system design techniques.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply mathematical tools associated with transform theory to analyse and design continuous-time and discrete-time systems.
2. Analyse, design, simulate, and test parts of a communication system and a control system in both time-domain and frequency-domain.
3. Model real and complex systems using a hierarchical approach, and simplify them with appropriate assumptions.
4. Measure time and frequency characteristics of signals and systems using laboratory equipment.
5. Communicate technical ideas, decisions, calculations, and experimental results in a written document.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify and analyse stakeholder needs, establish priorities, and define system requirements.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes.
D.1: Apply mathematical and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
E.1: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating across cross-disciplinary contexts.
F.1: Critically self-review performance to improve individually and as part of a team.

lectures_and_tutorials.schedule: Two 2-hour sessions per week, including collaborative problem-solving and hands-on lab activities.
lectures_and_tutorials.preparation: Study notes and readings before each session, complete pre-lab work, and participate in collaborative discussions.
lectures_and_tutorials.labs: Formal lab sessions to apply theory, using appropriate equipment and software tools.

project_work.group_project: A design and implementation project focusing on communication and control systems, culminating in a formal report.

Signals and Systems in the Frequency-Domain

31241 3D Computer Animation.Recommended studies: Basic knowledge of drawing and 2D digital image processing (e.g., Photoshop) is useful.
31241 3D Computer Animation.Description: This subject explores storytelling through 3D computer animation. It covers the complete animation production pipeline, including ideation, storyboarding, 3D animation, lighting, rendering, and VFX. Students practice pre-production planning, production management, and post-production of an animation project. This subject is project-based and focuses on learning by doing.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the theory behind 3D digital animation design and production.
2. Develop animation skills and the ability to analyze motion.
3. Design and rig a basic character for 3D animation using appropriate processes and workflows.
4. Create a character-based 3D Animation from the planning stage (storyboarding) to the final rendered 3D short.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components and systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member of diverse teams and communicate effectively in cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural contexts.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review performance to improve oneself, the team, and society.

Teaching and learning strategies.Interactive components: Students are expected to watch the lecture videos before class and participate in discussions and workshops. Feedback is provided during workshops, and UTSOnline is used for submission, peer critiques, and assessment progression.
Teaching and learning strategies.Agile development: The subject follows four sprint cycles for the animation project, with written feedback provided at key intervals (Weeks 3, 6, 8, 11).

Content (topics): Character animation (walk cycles, interaction with objects)

Assessment task 1.Intent: To become familiar with the lecture content.

Assessment task 2.Intent: To create a storyboard for the animation project.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To present the final animation and receive expert feedback, along with a written report on the process.

31241 3D Computer Animation.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31777 Advanced Interaction Design.Description: This subject focuses on user experience (UX) in Interaction Design, covering how UX influences the adoption of digital products, systems, or services. Students learn to describe, analyse, critique, and design for UX across a range of human-computer interactions, such as mobile and social computing, pervasive computing, IoT, and quantified self. Through project-based learning, students apply UX design principles to create engaging, user-focused technology solutions.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Use conceptual tools to describe, critique, and evaluate user experiences arising through interactions with technology.
2. Identify appropriate user experiences for different human-computer interactions.
3. Apply methods and techniques to design interactive technologies that support engaging user experiences.
4. Describe the social/technical and experiential concepts relevant to positive user experiences.
5. Identify and apply theoretical concepts to inspire more engaging design solutions.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - evaluate, implement, and operate systems using software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural teams.
F.1: Reflective - review personal and team performance to improve outcomes.

Teaching and learning strategies.Lecture format: Students engage with pre-recorded video lectures covering the theory of User Experience and Interaction Design.
Teaching and learning strategies.Tutorials: Hands-on design activities with formative feedback and guidance from tutors.
Teaching and learning strategies.Personal Portfolio: Students maintain a portfolio throughout the session, demonstrating progress in understanding UX design tools and techniques.
Teaching and learning strategies.Collaborative work: Online discussions and a session-long group project to solve real-life design problems.

Content (topics): Understanding UX and its differences from Usability
Designing for mobile, social, pervasive computing, IoT, and quantified self
Researching and representing user experiences in design

Assessment task 1.Length: 2-4 pages per journal entry using a provided template.

Assessment task 2.Criteria: Peer assessments determine individual contribution within group projects.

Assessment task 3.Criteria: Reflection on learning progress and tools used in UX design.

31777 Advanced Interaction Design.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31242 Advanced Internet Programming.description: In this subject, students create sophisticated web applications for deployment to production. It provides knowledge and skills in advanced internet technologies related to server-side programming and business-to-business systems. The subject focuses on hands-on development using web development stacks, n-tier architectures, security, web service integration, and deployment strategies.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and implement a medium-sized web application incorporating multiple data sources, transaction integrity, data and application security.
2. Describe at a conceptual level, multi-tier and distributed web applications, and the components and technologies used to build such applications.
3. Describe the features of a web-based application system that provides scalability, robustness, high availability, and security.
4. Compare and contrast competing web application architectures and list their advantages and disadvantages.
5. Explain how transactions are used in web applications.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Weekly one-hour collaborative lecture with technical discussions and reflective analysis.
Two-hour laboratory sessions for technical demonstrations, programming challenges, and feedback.
Self-directed learning with additional online readings, research activities, and use of the discussion board for ongoing communication.

assessment_task_1.title: Portfolio of Reflection and Analysis
assessment_task_1.intent: Reflect on and analyze the design and implementation of web applications using advanced internet technologies.

assessment_task_2.title: Advanced Internet Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Develop a real-world web application, incorporating the concepts learned throughout the subject.

31242 Advanced Internet Programming.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31927 Application Development with .NET.description: This subject introduces C#, Visual Studio, and the .NET development environment. The focus is on examining the .NET framework and the practicalities of developing software in this setting using the C# language.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the .NET framework architecture.
2. Understand how the .NET framework implements object-oriented concepts and its implications for new language design.
3. Understand the mechanisms and techniques for the deployment and configuration of .NET applications.
4. Utilize the .NET libraries.
5. Gain practical experience in writing C# programs in the .NET environment.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented - FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes to meet specified requirements.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1.5-hour lecture
1.5-hour lab
UTS Online Discussion board
content: .NET framework: Common Language Runtime, Common Type System, Common Language Specification
Introduction to C# within the .NET Framework
Object-Oriented Programming and Design concepts in the .NET Framework

assessment_task_1.intent: Practical experience in writing C# programs and utilizing the .NET libraries.

31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Recommended studies: Knowledge of C++ or Java, and elementary two- and three-dimensional graphics algorithms.
31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Description: This subject covers the three major rendering techniques in computer graphics: rasterization, ray tracing, and radiosity, with an emphasis on ray tracing. Topics include reflection models, ray-object intersections, recursive ray tracing, transparency and refraction, textures, anti-aliasing, shadows, acceleration techniques, triangle meshes, global illumination, and radiosity.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand the strengths, weaknesses, and uses of rasterization, ray tracing, and radiosity algorithms.
2. Gain practical knowledge of ray tracing by implementing a substantive ray tracer.
31249 Computer Graphics Rendering Techni.Teaching and learning strategies: Weekly lectures focusing on ray tracing theory, algorithms, and techniques, with informal tutorials as needed.

Assessment task 1.Intent: To extend an existing ray tracer and produce images.

Assessment task 2.Type: Extending the ray tracer from Assignment 1
Assessment task 2.Intent: To further extend the ray tracer from Assignment 1 and produce images.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To extend the ray tracer from Assignment 2 by implementing additional topics from the textbook and creating images.

Criteria.Report: 1-2 pages detailing the implementation, problems, and solutions.
Criteria.Images: Short description of each image or group of related images.

41900 Cryptography.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering

recommended_studies: Foundation Mathematics or equivalent

41900 Cryptography.description: This subject introduces students to modern security issues and technologies, covering aspects like security principles, policies, network/system security, and intrusion detection. Students apply programming skills to implement secure communications in a group project.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the theories and principles of information security by examining the mathematics behind encryption algorithms.
2. Identify programmatic flaws by examining and exploiting flawed software routines.
3. Implement secure protocols and techniques to prevent data interception by modifying and improving provided software.
4. Discuss the impact of evolving cryptographic techniques on contemporary security protocols.
5. Assess system design aspects that affect or compromise security principles.
6. Collaborate effectively in a software development team.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - Identifying and analyzing stakeholder needs to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - Applying problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems.
D.1: Technically Proficient - Applying mathematics, discipline fundamentals, and software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - Working as an effective member of diverse teams and communicating effectively.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 1-hour weekly lecture to discuss theory and concepts.
2-hour lab each week for project work and group programming.
Self-organized group meetings outside class (at least 2 hours per week) to work on the project.
Students must check UTSOnline regularly for additional learning resources and dedicate time outside class.
programming_skills: Opportunities and tools will be provided to learn programming early in the course.
Programming is essential for the group project but not required in the final exam.
41900 Cryptography.active_learning: The primary project involves group programming where students collaborate to implement secure protocols and improve security in peer-to-peer communication by modifying example code.

assessment_task_1.title: Quizzes
assessment_task_1.intent: Motivate continuous learning and recall of technical knowledge relevant to the subject.

assessment_task_2.title: Group Project
assessment_task_2.intent: Apply theoretical knowledge by designing and implementing secure algorithms and protocols.
assessment_task_2.length: Due in two parts from weeks 4 to 12

assessment_task_3.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess understanding of cryptographic standards, applications, and technologies.

41900 Cryptography.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48730 Cybersecurity.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48730 Cybersecurity.recommended_studies: A sound knowledge of computer systems and networking protocols
48730 Cybersecurity.description: This subject consolidates students' understanding of cyber security by considering security principles from both people management and technical perspectives, and explores security technologies commonly used in industry. Topics include cyber attacks and defenses, web security, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and security services such as confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the major theories and principles used in implementing a secure network.
2. Explain the underlying algorithms used to construct Security Protocols.
3. Identify and explain the major threats and their mitigation associated with cyber security.
4. Explain the major methodologies for secure networks and what threats they address.
5. Compare and contrast the technologies used in achieving network security across various network layers following OSI/TCP/IP architecture.
6. Implement and reflect on solutions for cyber security.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - Identifying and analyzing stakeholder needs to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - Applying problem-solving and design methodologies to develop systems.
D.1: Technically Proficient - Applying mathematics, discipline fundamentals, and software tools.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - Working as an effective member of diverse teams.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Interactive lectures supported by PowerPoint slides and learning materials.
Lab sessions for hands-on practice related to lecture topics.
Pre-reading lecture materials and answering online questions before lectures.
Discussion sessions and hands-on group activities in labs.

network_level_security: Access control, Wireless, and Mobile security

assessment_task_1.intent: Motivate continuous learning, analysis, and recall of technical knowledge relevant to cyber security.

assessment_task_2.title: Skills Based Assessment
assessment_task_2.intent: Demonstrate practical skills in identifying and resolving network security issues.

assessment_task_3.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess knowledge and understanding of cyber security concepts and solutions.

41083 Data Engineering Design.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41083 Data Engineering Design.description: This subject focuses on the creation and prototyping of new data engineering systems, with an emphasis on human-centred design and innovation. Students are encouraged to explore real-world applications of data-intensive systems and present their solutions through prototypes. The subject encourages collaboration and interdisciplinary problem-solving using design thinking approaches.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Build technical capability in design and innovative development techniques to prototype future applications of data-intensive systems.
2. Reflect on and identify learning needs and seek answers independently.
3. Explain results and outcomes through multiple modes of reflection and communication.
4. Critically apply communication skills (written and verbal).
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
F.1: Reflective

Students participate in iterative idea generation, feedback, and critical reflection.
Projects are presented by students and teams work on prototyping solutions, guided by feedback from peers and teaching staff.
The subject emphasizes teamwork, project management, communication, and real-world problem-solving.

41091 Data Systems.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41091 Data Systems.Description: This subject introduces the concepts of systems engineering for complex, data-centric systems. It covers the lifecycle of data-centric systems from design through development, production, and ongoing management. Students engage in project-based learning with a combination of individual and team work.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Define requirements and specifications of data systems.
2. Demonstrate systematic design and thinking for data system development.
3. Prototype or implement data systems according to system specifications.
4. Communicate effectively with data system project stakeholders.
5. Work effectively in a team to develop data systems, showing continuous improvement and independence.

31061 Database Principles.description: This subject introduces students to basic database design and implementation concepts, database design techniques, and using a relational design via Entity Relationship Diagram. Students also learn to access a database using SQL to retrieve and manipulate data.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design and manage structured data to manage a database.
2. Produce an Entity-Relationship (E-R) model from specifications and perform transformation of the conceptual model into logical data structures.
3. Apply data normalisation principles and understand the impact of data redundancy.
4. Construct SQL statements to retrieve data.
5. Demonstrate use of a simple database using SQL and maintain database integrity rules.
6. Understand principles of database transaction management and recovery.
7. Distinguish between good and bad database design.
8. Communicate database designs effectively.
content_topics: SQL: data modification statements and views
Conceptual database design using E-R modelling

assessments.intent: To test SQL skills.

assessments.name: SQL Lab Test 2
assessments.intent: To test SQL skills.

assessments.intent: Test advanced entity relationship design skills.

assessments.intent: To test all advanced database development skills.

31253 Database Programming.recommended_studies: Familiarity with SQL and basic database concepts; experience with at least one higher-level programming language is required
31253 Database Programming.description: This subject teaches students how to design, develop, and evaluate database programming and administration solutions. Students will use Oracle 11G, SQL*Plus, and PL/SQL to implement these solutions, covering areas such as stored procedures, triggers, packages, and database administration.
subject_learning_objectives: Describe the benefits of Database Programming
Understand programming constructs available in PL/SQL
Understand how triggers, stored procedures, stored functions, and database packages operate
Understand the current development methodology in modern database systems
Describe the use of supplied packages in the Oracle database
Have a basic understanding of the roles and responsibilities of a database administrator
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs and cultural perspectives, establishing priorities and goals. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design thinking, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes. (C.1)

Lab sessions to support lectures with illustrative examples and exercises.

PL/SQL language fundamentals, variables, and built-in functions
Database procedures, functions, triggers, and packages
Introduction and awareness of performance tuning

assessments.intent: Analyze business requirements and build a robust database-centric application using PL*SQL.
Test students' knowledge of tasks covered during the session, focusing on the programming environment.

31253 Database Programming.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48436 Digital Forensics.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48436 Digital Forensics.recommended_studies: Confident in using Windows command line utilities (netstat, nslookup, net, ipconfig) and Linux command line tools (grep, ls, uname, ps)
48436 Digital Forensics.description: This practice-based subject focuses on digital forensics applications. Students assess if a crime has been committed, acquire digital evidence, analyze the evidence, and prepare forensic reports. Key areas include web visit forensics, eDiscovery, and network intrusion investigation.
subject_learning_objectives: Evaluate theories of digital forensics
Understand the structure of forensic evidence
Implement forensically sound digital security practices in industry
Demonstrate competence in applying industry-standard forensic analysis techniques
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret and analyze stakeholder needs and cultural perspectives, establishing priorities and goals. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design thinking, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems. (D.1)
Reflective: FEIT graduates critically self-review their performance to improve themselves, their teams, and society. (F.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: 3 hours of class per week, with lecture material available online
Blended curriculum with research and hands-on labs focusing on digital forensics principles
Emphasis on practical labs, where students apply forensic tools and techniques
content_topics: Legal Process in forensic investigation, Digital Evidence, Australian Privacy Principles
Data Acquisition from Hard Disks and Networks
Disk file systems: FAT32 and NTFS
Metadata in Graphics, Documents, and Camera images

assessments.intent: Test knowledge of forensic theories and principles.
Demonstrate skills in collecting digital forensic evidence.
Locate forensic evidence on digital devices.
Assess understanding of digital forensics theories and practices.
Master weekly lab concepts through practical assessments.

48436 Digital Forensics.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48434 Embedded Software.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48434 Embedded Software.description: This subject focuses on the design, implementation, and testing of software modules for embedded systems. Students work in teams to develop software, interpret specifications, and test applications for embedded systems using hardware abstraction layers and data structures. A project-based approach enables students to design embedded systems software and gain debugging skills.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, write, and test various software modules such as hardware abstraction layers, data structures, and interrupt service routines.
2. Design, write, and test an embedded application that is modular, hierarchical, and meets real-time constraints.
3. Use various software tools to write, execute, and test embedded software applications.
4. Test software performance in embedded systems using appropriate laboratory equipment.
5. Research and evaluate knowledge from various sources.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Develop skills in handling microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupts, and interfacing.

assessment_task_2.title: Quiz
assessment_task_2.intent: Test knowledge in microcontroller modules, serial I/O, non-volatile memory, interrupt handling, and interfacing.

assessment_task_3.title: Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Design, implement, and test a complete embedded system.

48434 Embedded Software.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic digital systems and microprocessor/computer architecture is essential for this subject.
48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.description: This subject focuses on the analysis, design, and implementation of an advanced computing node. It provides an in-depth understanding of digital hardware design at the medium scale computer system building block level. Students will engage in computer-aided design using VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable VLSI implementation technologies, and will explore topics such as digital design processes, functional design, advanced digital architectures, and memory and I/O systems.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Analyse, design, and implement a programmable digital system based on a user requirement specification, and investigate advanced digital systems architectures.
2. Demonstrate in-depth understanding of the analysis, design, and implementation of advanced digital hardware at the medium scale computer system building block level.
3. Utilise computer-aided design, including the use of VHDL specification, simulation, and programmable FPGA implementation technologies, Register transfer level, Data path and control units.

problem_based_learning.method: Weekly lectures, tutorials, and laboratory assignments, focusing on developing solutions to complex design challenges.
problem_based_learning.approach: A series of staged laboratory tasks allows students to build up a complete system, culminating in a framework used for the final assignment.

student_support.preparation: Students are required to study notes, readings, and prepare questions prior to teaching activities.
student_support.collaboration: In labs, students work in groups of 2, engaging in collaborative discussions facilitated by academic staff.

teaching_and_learning_strategies.feedback: Academic staff provide immediate feedback during lectures, tutorials, and labs, with assignment demonstrations and one-on-one consultations for specific tasks.

content_topics: Review of basic digital techniques and their application to the design of state machines used in control units
Digital hardware design process and Programmable Logic

assessment_task_1.title: Assignments
assessment_task_1.intent: To gain practical experience in hardware design through design, simulation, and implementation of an application-specific digital system in hardware (FPGA or CPLD).
assessment_task_1.criteria: Assessment criteria will be published with each assignment's requirements.

assessment_task_2.title: Class Quizzes
assessment_task_2.intent: To test students' knowledge of digital systems, RTL, and VHDL language, as well as their ability to code for PLD and FPGA systems.
assessment_task_2.length: Each quiz will take up to two hours
assessment_task_2.criteria: Criteria will be included in the quiz paper.

48451 Embedded Systems Studio A.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.description: This subject introduces students to high-level procedural programming using C. Topics include conditional statements, iteration, functions, arrays, file processing, data structures, and memory management using pointers. Students also learn to compile C source code using the GNU toolchain, link binary object files, and run executables, following the complete development cycle, from problem analysis to testing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design, develop, and test programs in C to solve data-related problems.
2. Identify and explain the use of programming tools, standard libraries, and OS functions to support program execution.
3. Follow professional programming practices to align with industry expectations.
4. Collaborate effectively as a team member to solve complex problems using C.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and decision-making methodologies to develop systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and operate systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams and communicate across contexts. (E.1)
content_topics: Fundamental programming concepts: program development cycle, GNU toolchain, compiling C source code, linking, debugging, and testing.
Procedural programming in C: primitive data types, operators, typecasting, functions, pass by reference/value.
Control and loop statements: logical expressions, conditionals, and loops.
Arrays: creation, manipulation, and string handling.
Structures and file processing: user-defined structures, binary/text file handling.
Pointers: dynamic memory management, linked lists.
Advanced topics: user-defined libraries, command line parsing, programming in the large.

assessment_task_1.title: Quiz
assessment_task_1.intent: Reinforce and assess understanding of basic and fundamental C programming concepts.

assessment_task_2.title: Assignment
assessment_task_2.intent: Assess understanding of C programming concepts and application to real-world Data Engineering.

assessment_task_3.title: Group Project
assessment_task_3.intent: Assess ability to deliver programming solutions as a group.
assessment_task_3.length: Project report no more than 10 pages.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Evaluate understanding of fundamental programming concepts and C programming, along with professional coding practices.

48430 Fundamentals of C Programming.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Recommended studies: Knowledge of interactive technologies, design, and programming skills.
31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Description: This subject focuses on designing, evaluating, and implementing interactive computing systems for human use in real situations. Students learn human-computer interaction (HCI) and interaction design principles, including tools and techniques for building human-centered systems.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Critique and evaluate the usability and usefulness of information technology.
2. Design and evaluate usable digital systems by applying Human-Centered Design skills.
3. Discuss what Interaction Design, Human-Computer Interaction, and Design Thinking are.
4. Describe the crucial processes within a Human-Centered technology design approach.
5. Identify and utilize constraints and resources that human activities bring to technology design and use.
6. Recognize the range of approaches, techniques, tools, and methods available for designing useful and usable technology.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - identify and analyze stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply tools and techniques to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review to improve performance.
31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Teaching and learning strategies: Workshop sessions with lecture presentations (1 hour) and tutorials (1.5 hours). The subject emphasizes group work and collaborative problem-solving through tutorials and practical design projects. Students are expected to use online resources and engage in interactive discussions, assignments, and journal entries to deepen their understanding of Interaction Design.
Content (topics): 1. What is Interaction Design and Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)
2. Design principles, concepts, and theories of Interaction Design and HCI
3. Human-Centered design process and Design Thinking

Assessment task 1.Intent: To develop sensitivities and perceptions about technology use in everyday activities and articulate design issues.
Assessment task 1.Length: Single-page journal entries for #1-#3, 3-4 pages for entry #4.

Assessment task 2.Intent: To apply design and usability principles to critique and evaluate technology in a live setting.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To practice Human-Centered Design methodology by solving a real-world problem through research, prototyping, and evaluation.

31260 Fundamentals of Interaction Design.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.
