41902 Image Processing and Computer Visi.description: For subject description, contact UTS: Engineering.

41090 Information and Signals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41090 Information and Signals.description: This subject provides the theoretical foundations of information theory and signal processing that prepare students for both industry- and research-oriented careers. It emphasizes a strong laboratory component to give students hands-on experience in applying theoretical concepts to practical communication and signal/image processing systems. It also encourages collaborative research projects in information and signal theory.
41090 Information and Signals.subject_learning_objectives: Upon successful completion of this subject students should be able to: 1. Apply fundamental concepts in information theory and signal processing. 2. Use Fourier, Laplace, and Z-transforms to analyze practical signals and systems. 3. Develop abstraction models of practical information and signal processing systems. 4. Apply the basic concepts of data and signal processing to identify specific requirements in designing components. 5. Simulate and test communications, data, and information processing systems. 6. Apply critical thinking to propose creative ideas in signal research.
41090 Information and Signals.content: Topics include: introduction to information theory, source coding and compression, channel capacity, introduction to signal and systems, Fourier series and Fourier transform, frequency analysis, Laplace transform and system analysis, Z-transform, discrete systems.
41090 Information and Signals.minimum_requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31080 Interactive Media.Description: This subject introduces students to the fundamental principles of interactive media and associated tools. Students use creative coding to design and develop interactive media systems incorporating digital audio, images, animation, and video, focusing on creating engaging user experiences.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Apply knowledge of digital sampling, storage, and mapping techniques for still images, video, sound, and sensor data.
2. Use digital sound, image, and video processing to alter digital media.
3. Design and develop interactive media applications that create effective and engaging user experiences.
4. Identify and explain the applications of digital media and prepare proposals for new systems.
5. Work in a team of digital media developers.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply software tools and techniques to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review to improve performance.
31080 Interactive Media.Teaching and learning strategies: Students will participate in a weekly 1-hour workshop and a 2-hour tutorial. They will engage with online activities, practical coding, and design projects, with continuous feedback throughout. Peer assessments will be applied in group assignments.
Content (topics): Enabling technologies: digital representations and signal processing
Computer graphics: vector graphics, 3D graphics, image manipulation
Interaction: motion capture, video analysis, mapping

Assessment task 1.Intent: Capture and reflect on learning throughout the semester.

Assessment task 2.Intent: Demonstrate the ability to work in a team on an interactive media project.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Develop an individual creative approach to a design task using interactive media concepts.

31080 Interactive Media.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48033 Internet of Things.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48033 Internet of Things.Description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a distributed system in which autonomous devices collect environmental or medical data. This subject explores sensor networks, telemetry, distributed data, machine vision, AI, and analytics for applications like environmental monitoring, medical monitoring, and military surveillance. Students learn theory, concepts, and the practice of IoT through designing and developing an IoT-based application, learning new skills, understanding the benefits of the technology, and exploring new models of service deployment and data delivery.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Integrate skills and knowledge gained in the course as a whole.
2. Explain an integrated, multidisciplinary approach for IoT-based solutions and apply it to real-world scenarios.
3. Analyse, design, and implement a distributed IoT system, its components, and address connectivity issues.
4. Explain the principles of sensing/actuation, data transmission, processing, visualization, analytics, and cybersecurity issues in IoT.
5. Execute independent investigation of new IoT applications, methods, technologies, programming models, and tools.
6. Recognize and appreciate the collaborative nature of IoT development and teamwork involved.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Socially Responsible (B.1)
Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): IoT theory, concepts, components, and delivery models
Fundamentals of Localisation, Aggregation, Clustering, and Routing
Issues and Challenges in building IoT applications
IoT in Context of Cloud Computing and Analytics

Assessment task 1: Project.Intent: To demonstrate understanding and skills required for the design and implementation of an IoT-based solution.

Assessment task 2: Labs.Intent: Completion of weekly lab activities and demonstration of working programs to the tutor.

Assessment task 3: Short Quizzes.Intent: To assess understanding of topics covered during the preceding lectures.

Assessment task 4: Examination.Intent: To assess student understanding of topics covered throughout the session.

48033 Internet of Things.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Recommended studies: Familiarity with computer graphics and experience with designing interactive systems.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Description: This subject covers theoretical concepts and practical methodologies needed to ideate, communicate, implement, and improve computer game designs. Students will develop both a physical board game and a digital game. The subject emphasizes an iterative, player-centric design approach.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Critique games in terms of their function as dynamic systems of formal and dramatic elements.
2. Create computer games in a team by applying an iterative player-centric design approach.
3. Evaluate games by applying playtesting techniques.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyze stakeholder needs and constraints.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving and design methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply tools and techniques to develop systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - self-review to improve performance.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Teaching and learning strategies: The subject is highly collaborative and hands-on, with students working in groups to produce a physical board game and a digital game. Weekly labs and playtesting sessions foster continuous feedback and improvement. Lectures focus on game design theories and the practical application of these concepts.
Content (topics): The Process of Designing a Game: Conceptualization, prototyping, playtesting, game balance.
Game Design Basics: Role of game designer, structure of games, formal and dramatic elements.
Working as a Game Designer: Local and international game industry, serious games.
31262 Introduction to Computer Game Desi.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31263 Introduction to Computer Game Deve.Description: This subject introduces game development using a commercial-grade game engine, focusing on intermediate programming, vector and matrix mathematics for 2D/3D transformations, and engine API use. It builds a generalizable understanding of virtual interactive simulations, preparing students for group projects in subsequent games-related subjects.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Illustrate an understanding of the language and concepts of game development technology and techniques.
2. Apply mathematical and game programming knowledge to solve development tasks.
3. Build familiarity and appreciation of the programmatic components of an industry-standard game engine.
4. Seek new knowledge of games development through self-directed study.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
F.1: Reflective - self-review performance to improve oneself and the team.
31263 Introduction to Computer Game Deve.Teaching and learning strategies: Students will engage in a combination of lectures, pre-class video learning, and lab sessions. Game programming topics follow a 3-step process: learning in lectures, expanding knowledge through self-study, and reviewing learning via class discussions. Major assessments involve recreating a classic game and enhancing it with a novel twist.
Content (topics): Introduction to Unity – Unity interface, game cycle, components, GameObject, Transform
Fundamentals – asset instantiation, input management, vectors, translation/rotation/scale
Working with Time – time, delta time, co-routines
Animation and Audio Assets – animation state machines, audio function calls
UI Programming – UI canvas space, event registration/listening
Game State Managers – game managers, scene management
Physics Programming – rigid body physics, physics materials
Save Games – PlayerPrefs, JSON utility, file writing

Assessment task 4.Title: Classic Game Recreation - Enhancing and Innovating

31263 Introduction to Computer Game Deve.Minimum requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

Knowledge of linear algebra (e.g., vectors, matrices and their manipulation), data structures (e.g., multi-dimensional arrays, stack) is strongly recommended.
Good programming skills in at least one programming language are required.
31264 Introduction to Computer Graphics.Description: This subject introduces students to computer graphics, focusing on 3D shape representation, manipulation, and visualization. Students gain a theoretical and practical understanding of computer graphics technology, learning to design and implement 3D images using modern tools such as WebGL and the ThreeJS framework. The subject also covers fundamental principles of graphical pipelines, 3D model representations, and interactive web applications.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Discern possible applications of Computer Graphics and current trends.
2. Explain the different stages of the OpenGL graphics pipeline.
3. Understand how linear Algebra is important in the context of Computer Graphics.
4. Demonstrate foundational knowledge of modeling and representations of 3D shapes.
5. Understand how real-time shading and lighting is implemented.
6. Implement an interactive application using ThreeJS and WebGL.
7. Communicate design ideas, models, implementations, and outcomes.
8. Reflect critically on their own work.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - self-review performance to improve oneself and the team.
31264 Introduction to Computer Graphics.Teaching and learning strategies: The subject offers one 2-hour face-to-face interactive workshop and one 1.5-hour lab each week. Workshops include traditional lectures and live programming sessions in ThreeJS. Labs focus on implementing components of the project. Students are encouraged to actively participate and follow along during live coding sessions to deepen their understanding.

recommended_studies: Knowledge of database technologies
31250 Introduction to Data Analytics.description: Data analytics is the art and science of transforming large datasets into meaningful and valuable information. This subject offers foundational knowledge in data analytics, data mining, and knowledge discovery, focusing on practical applications and techniques. Students will explore statistical methods, database management, and intelligent technologies, with a focus on solving real-world problems and communicating results professionally.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Explain the background of data analytics, including the business and society context.
2. Use data analytics to explore and gain a broad understanding of a dataset.
3. Outline the scope and limitations of state-of-the-art data analytics methods.
4. Use data analytics methods to make predictions for a dataset.
5. Organise and implement a data analytics project in a business environment.
6. Communicate the results of a data analytics project.
content_topics: Introduction to data mining: problems, concepts, and methodologies.
Visual data exploration and mining: data visualization techniques.
Data pre-processing and transformation: techniques for data cleaning, dealing with noisy or missing data.
Classification and prediction: decision trees, support vector machines, ensemble methods.
Clustering: partitioning methods, hierarchical methods, density-based methods, k-means.
Deployment of results: representing patterns as rules or functions, model deployment, industry applications.

assessments.name: Dream Jobs
assessments.intent: Understand the application of data analytics in various industries.

assessments.name: Data Exploration and Preparation
assessments.intent: Apply data exploration techniques and prepare data for analytics.

assessments.name: Data Mining in Action
assessments.intent: Apply data mining techniques and communicate the results of a data analytics project.

minimum_requirements.description: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

requisites.prerequisite: 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering

48441 Introductory Digital Systems.recommended_studies: Knowledge of basic electrical engineering circuits and soldering skills.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.description: This subject enables students to master the fundamentals of digital and programmable electronic circuits, small computer system hardware architecture, and low-level programming. Topics include digital sequential circuits, microcontroller hardware, assembly language, interrupts, input/output, and hardware interfacing.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Design combinational and sequential logic circuits.
2. Implement and evaluate logic circuits using appropriate software tools.
3. Analyse digital logic circuits.
4. Design and implement programmable logic devices and microcontrollers and related input/output components.
5. Identify basic assembly programming techniques to construct and implement basic assembly programs.
6. Write and evaluate assembly programs using appropriate software tools.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: Socially Responsible: FEIT graduates identify, interpret and analyse stakeholder needs, constraints, and risks. (B.1)
Design Oriented: FEIT graduates apply problem-solving and design methodologies to develop components and systems. (C.1)
Technically Proficient: FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, and software tools to evaluate and implement systems. (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative: FEIT graduates work effectively in diverse teams, communicating and collaborating in cross-disciplinary contexts. (E.1)
teaching_and_learning_strategies: Problem-based learning approach involving designing and analysing digital logic and microcontroller circuits.
Interactive lectures, face-to-face tutorials, and hands-on lab activities.
Students are expected to watch videos on UTSOnline and prepare before attending classes and labs.
Lab activities include hardware kit use, circuit design, and assembly language programming.
Immediate feedback from lab tutors during lab sessions.
content_topics: State diagrams and their application in digital circuit design.
Basic hardware architectures of digital computers.
48441 Introductory Digital Systems.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, students must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31005 Machine Learning.Description: Data analytics is an exciting new field combining databases, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and visualisation among others. It is applied in many fields of business, industry, and science to discover new information and knowledge. This subject builds on previous data analytics subjects to give an understanding of how both basic and more powerful algorithms work. It takes a research-inspired approach so that students learn to apply state-of-the-art algorithms to their professional practice. It also introduces data analytics approaches for specific domains such as social network analysis and text mining.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe the scope, limitations, and application of several advanced data analytics methods.
2. Demonstrate their ability to read, understand, and critique a data analytics approach from an academic research publication.
3. Use or program an advanced data analytics method.
4. Design an approach to data analytics problems in specialised domains.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of the issues underlying data analytics to successfully outline an approach to solving a data analytics problem.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: Design Oriented (C.1)
Technically Proficient (D.1)
Collaborative and Communicative (E.1)
Content (topics): 1. Data analytics and its relationship to machine learning and optimisation.
4. Data analytics approaches: neural networks, Bayesian approaches, sparse linear methods.

Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Intent: Demonstrate understanding of the literature and critique data analytics methods.
Assessment task 1: Understanding the Lit.Length: A report of 10 pages in an 11 or 12 point font.

Assessment task 2: Practical Data Analyt.Intent: Apply data analytics methods to real-world data.

Assessment task 3: Examination.Intent: Assess understanding of key concepts and methods covered in the course.

41092 Network Fundamentals.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41092 Network Fundamentals.recommended_studies: Basic programming skills, e.g., C++ or Python, are recommended to complete the programming projects.
41092 Network Fundamentals.description: This subject provides a modern introduction to computer networking, including layered network architecture and the TCP/IP protocol suite. Students develop practical skills in network traffic observation, building network applications through socket programming, and working with Cisco network equipment. Problem-solving and design skills are also emphasized to help students select appropriate network services and develop network applications for optimized data performance.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Understand the key architectural principles of the Internet, namely protocol layering and service models.
2. Analyse various components of the Internet, including Applications, Transport, Network, Addressing, and Data Link, to select the most appropriate network services.
3. Examine and explain end-to-end packet delivery throughout the network system to gain insight into the behaviour of the Internet.
4. Design and implement network applications to provide a service, such as web and email.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: A 1-hour lecture and 2-hour tutorial/laboratory each week.
Hands-on workshops using Cisco network equipment and network traffic observation tools.
Pre-class preparation, including textbook reading and video notes.
Teamwork and group activities to simulate real-world engineering workplaces.
Quizzes and project assessments to test understanding and practical skills.
content: 1. Computer Networks and the Internet: The network edge and core, protocol layers, network performance measures.
2. Application Layer: Web and HTTP, Email and DNS, socket programming for network applications.
3. Transport Layer: UDP, TCP, principles of congestion control, reliable data transfer.
4. Network Layer: IP, IPv4 and IPv6 addressing, routers, service models.
6. Link Layer: Ethernet, VLANs, multiple access links, error detection, and correction techniques.

assessment_task_1.title: Labs
assessment_task_1.intent: Wireshark and hands-on labs for experiments, observations, and analysis.

assessment_task_2.title: Projects
assessment_task_2.intent: Develop skills in network design, development, and implementation.

assessment_task_3.title: Quiz
assessment_task_3.intent: Test conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Written Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: Assess overall understanding of network concepts and problem-solving skills.

31748 Programming on the Internet.Recommended studies: Basic knowledge of programming languages and Unix systems
31748 Programming on the Internet.Description: This subject introduces students to the specifics of the World Wide Web (WWW) and internet-based programming. The evolution of the internet and its technical foundation is studied as well as basic techniques for presenting data, text, and pictures on the WWW. The subject focuses on PHP (hypertext preprocessor), MySQL (backend database), JavaScript, AJAX, XML, and Object Oriented PHP. This subject provides a sound basis for understanding how the WWW functions, how to construct websites, and how to write software for the WWW using advanced scripting techniques.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Understand the general concepts pertaining to the Internet and World Wide Web.
2. Possess an insight into the development and security of non-trivial websites.
3. Have a good working knowledge of DHTML, JavaScript, AJAX, and website design principles.
4. Gain introductory knowledge of XML on the Web.
5. Gain experience in using PHP as a server-side scripting language.
6. Gain sufficient knowledge of Unix to manage websites on Unix systems.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible
C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative
Content (topics): The Internet and World Wide Web – General Principles
Introduction to dynamic web programming; PHP; JavaScript
MySQL database; extending the power of PHP

48450 Real-time Operating Systems.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48450 Real-time Operating Systems.Description: This subject addresses the purposes, design alternatives and uses of computer operating systems for programming in embedded systems, PC, and servers. Topics include process management, scheduling and inter-process communication, memory management, and I/O device management, with an emphasis on real-time systems.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Show competence in using and writing application programs in POSIX compliant C on a Unix operating system
2. Illustrate the basic principles of the design and implementation of an operating system to create an experimental analysis report
3. Solve quantitative and qualitative problems related to operating system design and use
4. Identify the basic principles of real-time systems analysis to understand Linux systems

41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41081 Sensing, Actuation and Control.description: This subject introduces students to programming hardware devices to collect data, make control decisions and cause actions in the physical world. Students develop theoretical and practical understanding in sensing, actuation, hardware control, signal measurement, data processing, and image processing. Students bring their own devices for practical system implementation, combining virtual learning environments and hands-on activities.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Use real-time systems, understanding their requirements and practical implications.
2. Interface embedded processors to sensors and actuators.
3. Use the C language for creating embedded firmware and software.
4. Select and specify appropriate sensors, actuators, and control hardware.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: C.1: Design Oriented
D.1: Technically Proficient
teaching_and_learning_strategies: The subject is based on three key elements: a knowledge base, virtual laboratories, and practical system implementation.
Students use the Zybook interactive textbook 'Programming Embedded Systems' to learn concepts through weekly activities before class.
Virtual Laboratory: Students apply their knowledge using the RI Tools for Programming Embedded Systems, a companion system to the online book.

48540 Signals and Systems.faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
48540 Signals and Systems.recommended_studies: Circuit analysis in both the time and frequency domains, including the use of differential equations and transform methods.
48540 Signals and Systems.description: This subject covers system analysis techniques, focusing on the analysis and design of control and communication systems. Students model, simulate, and test real-world systems and apply theoretical knowledge through laboratory experiments and a group project. Topics include signal types, differential/difference equations, transforms, feedback, stability, and system design techniques.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Apply mathematical tools associated with transform theory to analyse and design continuous-time and discrete-time systems.
2. Analyse, design, simulate, and test parts of a communication system and a control system in both time-domain and frequency-domain.
3. Model real and complex systems using a hierarchical approach, and simplify them with appropriate assumptions.
4. Measure time and frequency characteristics of signals and systems using laboratory equipment.
5. Communicate technical ideas, decisions, calculations, and experimental results in a written document.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Identify and analyse stakeholder needs, establish priorities, and define system requirements.
C.1: Apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes.
D.1: Apply mathematical and discipline fundamentals, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
E.1: Work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams, communicating across cross-disciplinary contexts.
F.1: Critically self-review performance to improve individually and as part of a team.

lectures_and_tutorials.schedule: Two 2-hour sessions per week, including collaborative problem-solving and hands-on lab activities.
lectures_and_tutorials.preparation: Study notes and readings before each session, complete pre-lab work, and participate in collaborative discussions.
lectures_and_tutorials.labs: Formal lab sessions to apply theory, using appropriate equipment and software tools.

project_work.group_project: A design and implementation project focusing on communication and control systems, culminating in a formal report.

Signals and Systems in the Frequency-Domain

41095 Software Engineering Studio 2A.Description: In this studio subject, students extend a system using professional practices developed in previous Software Engineering Studio subjects by adding features or resolving software issues. The subject focuses on developing skills for solving large-scale, complex software problems through design, development, and management. Students are tasked with learning to balance problem exploration with design convergence and are encouraged to understand the longer-term consequences of selected software development methods and tools.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Apply established engineering methods to complex software engineering problem solving.
2. Apply software engineering techniques, tools, and resources.
3. Apply systematic software engineering synthesis and design processes.
4. Apply systematic approaches to the conduct and management of software engineering projects.
5. Work efficiently in a team.

Formal assessments of project outcomes occur at mid-term and end of term. Students also participate in peer evaluations of teamwork.

41097 Software Engineering Studio 3A.Description: This subject focuses on practical software engineering and agile management. Students will build a software/system/solution, develop features, or resolve software issues using professional skills developed in previous subjects. It emphasizes teamwork, logical thinking, field research, user needs, system analysis, and problem-solving, with a goal of preparing students for professional roles with agile management experience.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Explore users’ requirements in daily life.
2. Apply established engineering methods, techniques, tools, resources to complex software engineering problem solving.
3. Apply systematic and logical software engineering synthesis and design processes for software development.
4. Apply systematic approaches to the conduct and management of software engineering projects.
5. Engage highly and efficiently in a team.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, and discipline fundamentals.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams.
F.1: Reflective - critically self-review performance to improve oneself and teams.
41097 Software Engineering Studio 3A.Teaching and learning strategies: This studio-based subject simulates real-world software development practices suited to small projects. Students work in self-managed teams, leveraging agile project planning to build prototypes, problem solve, and develop minimum viable products. Mentors (tutors, industry partners, and researchers) guide the process. Weekly meetings are held to track progress, and students are expected to document their design thinking. Feedback is provided by lecturers, mentors, tutors, and peers.

41033 Integrated Electronic Systems Desi.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
41033 Integrated Electronic Systems Desi.Description: This subject introduces students to the foundations of electronics engineering through lab and project-based learning. It covers fundamental principles of analogue circuits, circuit simulation, and layout software like Cadence, ADS, and Matlab. Students gain practical skills in electronics signal processing and circuit design.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Obtain basic electronics circuitry knowledge and skills for future electronics engineering.
2. Interpret and classify electronics engineering problems and identify corresponding software solutions.
3. Understand the nature, scope, and history of electronics engineering, including emerging technologies.
4. Develop critical thinking in component and system-level design using modelling and simulation.
5. Gain project management, teamwork, and effective communication skills.
6. Demonstrate teamwork and communication capability.

C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving and design decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply tools and techniques to evaluate and operate systems.
41033 Integrated Electronic Systems Desi.Teaching and learning strategies: This subject includes workshops, laboratories, and project-based practical work. Students work in teams on real-world design tasks, supported by online resources. Lab classes provide access to advanced circuit design software for system and component design, supplemented by case studies and simulations.
Content (topics): 4. Applications of electronics in various industries

41034 IoT Components and Fabrication.Faculty: UTS: Engineering: Electrical and Data Engineering
Requisite(s): 48510 Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering
41034 IoT Components and Fabrication.Description: This subject focuses on the hardware technologies used in Internet of Things (IoT) systems at the component level. Students explore miniaturization, nanotechnology, semiconductor physics, sensor fabrication, packaging, and testing in the context of IoT nodes.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe doping, junctions, diodes, and transistors, and their fabrication in semiconductor technologies.
2. Investigate the principles of sensing and transduction, and how sensors are fabricated in electronics and photonics.
3. Perform failure analysis by deconstructing a microcomponent's fabrication, packaging, and testing.
4. Model a component/system and identify performance limitations.
5. Select components and approaches for designing a specific IoT system.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
41034 IoT Components and Fabrication.Teaching and learning strategies: Lectures introduce component-level electronics and photonics systems, while tutorials focus on modeling capabilities for electronics components and integrated systems. Industry guest lectures provide real-world examples of cutting-edge IoT technologies. Assessments encourage individual research and exploration of components within IoT systems, including peer feedback during presentations.
Content (topics): 1. Semiconductor technologies: doping, junctions, and logic devices.
2. MEMS: sensing, transduction, accuracy, and sensitivity.
3. Photonics components: Optical fibers, waveguides, and lasers.
5. Modeling of components and integrated circuits.
6. Industry case studies in electronics and photonics.
41034 IoT Components and Fabrication.Minimum requirements: To pass, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31269 Business Requirements Modelling.description: This subject introduces information system concepts and describes how these concepts can be used to model business requirements. It covers agile and non-agile software engineering principles, methods, tools, and techniques, with a focus on various analysis approaches including object-oriented methods, business process modelling, and entity-relationship modelling. Students work in small teams to apply these techniques to case studies.
subject_learning_objectives: 1. Identify stakeholders, understand their needs, and learn how to capture requirements in the system development process.
2. Apply modelling and systems analysis techniques that help understand the working of a business system.
3. Document and specify various requirements via Software Requirements Specification (SRS).
4. Develop various models using a range of systems analysis techniques to analyse and specify system and user requirements.
5. Work effectively in a small team.
course_intended_learning_outcomes: B.1: Socially Responsible - FEIT graduates identify, engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs and constraints to define system requirements.
C.1: Design Oriented - FEIT graduates apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies to develop components, systems, and processes to meet specified requirements.
D.1: Technically Proficient - FEIT graduates apply abstraction, mathematics, software tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - FEIT graduates work effectively as members or leaders of diverse teams, communicating effectively within cross-disciplinary contexts.
teaching_and_learning_strategies: A combination of formal seminars and collaborative workshops based on a practical case study.
Active learning through role-playing, think-pair-share, quizzes, and group discussions.
Regular feedback during seminars and workshops on work done for case study assignments.
Weekly quizzes with immediate feedback to track progress.
Students are expected to spend 9-12 hours per week on study, including class time and independent reading.

assessment_task_1.title: Short Quizzes and Professional Engagement
assessment_task_1.intent: To evaluate understanding and application of key concepts through weekly quizzes.

assessment_task_2.title: Requirements Analysis Report
assessment_task_2.intent: To analyze and document system requirements for a case study.
assessment_task_2.length: Maximum 1000 words excluding diagrams, bibliography, and appendices.

assessment_task_3.title: OO Requirements Analysis and Specification Report
assessment_task_3.intent: To develop object-oriented analysis and specification for a case study.
assessment_task_3.length: Maximum 3000 words excluding diagrams, bibliography, and appendices.

assessment_task_4.title: Final Exam
assessment_task_4.intent: To test knowledge and understanding of requirements engineering and modelling techniques.

31269 Business Requirements Modelling.minimum_requirements: To pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48024 Applications Programming.Description: This subject teaches students how to design, develop and evaluate software systems to meet predefined quality characteristics of functionality (suitability) and usability (understandability, learnability, operability, compliance). Software solutions are implemented using Java. Concepts, theories and technologies underlying the methods and techniques are introduced and explained as required. Students apply all that they have learned to develop and implement the architecture of a business system.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Judge if a solution is well-designed.
2. Design a good OO solution from a specification.
3. Demonstrate a working knowledge of lists in Java.
4. Use inheritance in Java.
5. Construct a GUI interface.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving and design decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, mathematics, software, tools, and techniques to evaluate, implement, and operate systems.
48024 Applications Programming.Teaching and learning strategies: The subject has one contact hour in Week 1 and three contact hours per week in the remaining weeks. A weekly online study module presents new material in the form of videos and written articles. Regular face-to-face lectures include interactive quizzes and illustrations of key topics. A weekly two-hour lab session gives students practice in analysing software specifications and writing, debugging, and running code.

Assessment task 1.Title: Labs
Assessment task 1.Length: Each weekly lab should take about 2 hours.
Assessment task 1.Criteria: Labs are marked for correctness only. The early labs are marked by PLATE, while GUI labs are marked by PLATE, peer marking, and the Subject Coordinator.

Assessment task 2.Title: Programming assignment 1
Assessment task 2.Criteria: Marked on correctness by PLATE, based on the match to the model solution’s IO trace.

Assessment task 3.Title: Programming assignment 2
Assessment task 3.Criteria: Marked on correctness. The minimum essential requirement is to complete tasks worth more than half the marks.

Assessment task 4.Title: Final Examination
Assessment task 4.Criteria: Multiple choice questions are marked for correctness only.

48024 Applications Programming.Minimum requirements: To pass, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

31282 Systems Testing and Quality Manage.Description: This subject provides students with the practical knowledge and skills necessary to effectively measure and control the quality of software products. It covers software quality assurance and management principles along with systems and software testing approaches.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Plan and execute specific processes, types, and phases of testing to assure quality in software products.
2. Apply exploratory and smoke testing to evaluate system operations and functions.
3. Apply quality assurance and management principles to Agile and Waterfall test processes.
4. Work collaboratively to plan, develop, apply, and document test systems.
5. Understand the principles and approaches to testing and quality management and their support for developers, projects, and business outcomes.
6. Communicate professionally in all aspects of testing.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem-solving, design, and decision-making methodologies.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work effectively in diverse teams and cross-disciplinary contexts.

Assessment task 1.Intent: To demonstrate understanding of FMEA and Static testing.

Assessment task 2.Intent: To demonstrate the ability to perform exploratory testing.

Assessment task 3.Intent: To perform and document smoke testing collaboratively.

Assessment task 4.Intent: To encourage participation in tutorials and demonstrate understanding of tutorial content.

Assessment task 5.Intent: To assess knowledge via multiple choice questions.

31282 Systems Testing and Quality Manage.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.

48433 Software Architecture.Recommended studies: Students should have knowledge of object-oriented design and unified modelling language (UML). A quiz is provided to check mastery of this knowledge.
48433 Software Architecture.Description: This subject teaches students current industry practices to design, develop, and evaluate software architecture that meets predefined quality characteristics. Concepts, theories, and technologies underlying the methods and techniques are introduced and explained. Students apply these practices to develop an architecture of a business system.
Subject learning objectives (SLOs): 1. Describe the factors that affect the architectural context and requirements, including stakeholders and their interests.
2. Develop and refine multiple views of a software system architecture.
3. Understand key issues in choosing and implementing architectural patterns.
4. Reason about alternative architectural designs to satisfy a system's quality attributes.
5. Develop a complete software architecture for a proposed solution to a realistic industry problem.
Course intended learning outcomes (CILOs: B.1: Socially Responsible - engage, interpret, and analyse stakeholder needs.
C.1: Design Oriented - apply problem solving, design and decision-making methodologies.
D.1: Technically Proficient - apply abstraction, software, and tools to evaluate and implement systems.
E.1: Collaborative and Communicative - work as an effective member or leader of diverse teams.
Content (topics): Software architecture for specific needs (e.g., product lines, real-time systems, web-based systems)

Assessment task 1.Intent: Encourages students to progressively engage and learn the subject content.

Assessment task 2.Intent: Encourages students to understand and apply specialised software architecture concepts.

Assessment task 3.Intent: Work in a team to develop an architecture for a specific system in a given context.

Assessment task 4.Intent: Develop and practice the skill of reviewing and critiquing peers' work.

Assessment task 5.Intent: Assess a student's knowledge of software architecture and the ability to apply it to a given problem.

48433 Software Architecture.Minimum requirements: In order to pass the subject, a student must achieve an overall mark of 50% or more.
